questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in a person struck with lightning while walking in an open field?
questions.solution:
Flash or spark burns are not seen in a person struck by lightning and are seen in a person affected by electric shock.

Lightning injuries over a person can lead to the following findings such as burnt clothes or torn at the point of entry and exit, linear burns, filigree burns, and surface burns occur beneath the metallic objects worn or carried by the person (Option B) 

Lichtenberg's flowers (Option C), also called arborescent (Option D) or filigree burns are superficial, thin, irregular, and tortuous markings over the skin that resemble the branches of a tree. They usually appear within minutes to an hour of a lightning injury and are observed as having a fern-like pattern of erythema over the skin of the shoulders or the flanks. 

They occur due to the staining of the tissues by hemoglobin released by lysed red blood cells along the path of the lightning strike. They can also appear due to the rupture of smaller blood vessels in several places giving rise to ecchymoses.

The image below shows a filigree burn pattern:


Flash or Spark burn (option A) occurs in electrical burns or electrocution when the contact is less firm, a narrow air gap exists between skin and conductor, and the current jumps the gap as a spark. This causes the outer skin keratin to melt over a small area. On cooling, the keratin fuses into a hard brownish nodule, usually raised above the surrounding surface, the so-called spark lesion. The heat generated by the current may melt the calcium phosphate, which is radiologically seen as typical round dense foci known as bone pearls or wax drippings.

Filigree burns are never seen in an electric shock. High voltage burns are very severe and lead to charring off the body. This leads to multiple burnt or punched-out lesions in large body surface areas called "crocodile flash burns".

questions.text:
An ophthalmologist does the test shown below while evaluating a case of squint. What is the utility of this test?

BSV - Binocular single vision

ARC - Anomalous retinal correspondence

choices.text: To measure direction and degree of deviation
To differentiate between BSV, ARC and suppression

questions.solution:
The given image shows  Worth's four-dot test done to differentiate between Binocular single vision (BSV), Anomalous retinal correspondence (ARC) and suppression. It is a sensory function test. It is performed as mentioned below:

  • Patient wears goggles with
    • Red lens: Right eye
    • Green lens: Left eye
  • A box is viewed having 4 lights: one red, two green, and one white
  • Inference:
    • A: Normal—All 4 lights seen
    • B: Abnormal retinal correspondence—All 4 lights seen in the presence of manifest squint
    • C: Left Suppression—2 red lights seen
    • D: Right suppression—3 green lights seen
    • E: Diplopia—5 lights seen (2 red, 3 green)

ARC occurs as sensory adaptation in case of small angle squint whereas in diplopia corresponding points change. Over of the normal eye corresponds with the extra foveal point of a slightly deviated eye to adapt for diplopia. 

Suppression occurs as sensory adaptation in confusion where 2 images are formed. The brain will suppress the image from the deviated eye. 

Other options :

Option A: To measure direction and degree of deviation we use Hirschberg's test. It gives a rough estimate of the angle of manifest strabismus. A pen torch is used to shine light from an arm's distance and the patient is asked to fixate. The corneal reflection of the light will be decentered in the squinting eye in the direction opposite to the deviation.

Option B: To measure heterophoria and cyclophoria we use Maddox rod. It consists of parallel red or colorless cylinders stacked together. It is a macular function test. 

Option D: To assess ocular motility we use Hess chart. It is use to diagnose and monitor patients with incomitant strabismus by assessing a binocular single vision field. In its interpretation, a smaller chart indicates the eye with the paretic muscle and a larger chart indicates the eye with an overacting muscle.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding non-tuberculous mycobacterium (NTM) organisms?

choices.text: They show false positive Mantoux test
All of them produce pigmented colonies on LJ media

questions.solution:
Non-tuberculous mycobacterium (NTM) organisms show false positive Mantoux test (Option A).

False positive Mantoux test is seen in NTM infections and BCG vaccination after 8-14 weeks.

Other options:

Option B - BCG is not protective against non-tuberculous mycobacterium(NTM) infections. Infact, BCG does not provide protection from the risk of tuberculosis infection but protects infants and young children against the development of complications such as tuberculous meningitis and disseminated tuberculosis. 

Option C - All NTM organisms grow on LJ media but all of them do not produce pigmented colonies. They are classified under Runyon classification based on pigment production and the rate of growth.

Option D - M.chelonae and M.fortuitum causes injection site abscess and not M.abscessus.

M.abscessus causes pulmonary infections and other cutaneous infections.

questions.text: A 50-year-old obese smoker presents with heartburn and epigastric pain. The gastroenterologist performs an endoscopic biopsy and confirms the diagnosis of Barrett's esophagus. The endoscopic appearance of the affected mucosa before and after the application of Lugol's iodine is?
questions.solution:
The affected mucosa in Barrett's esophagus is velvety red on gross or endoscopic examination and pale white after the application of lugol's iodine.

In contrast, the normal esophageal mucosa is glossy and pale which becomes dark brown due to glycogen content after application of lugol's iodine.

Normal stomach mucosa is light brown on gross examination.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man has to undergo renal transplant surgery. You were asked to collect his blood samples for HLA matching in a yellow-colored vacutainer. Which of the following is present in the yellow-colored vacutainers?
questions.solution:
The most commonly used vacutainer for HLA typing is a yellow vacutainer containing acid-citrate dextrose.

Other uses of yellow vacutainers are DNA sampling and paternity testing. Other components that can be used in yellow vacutainers include Sodium polyanethol sulfonate (SPS) which is used to collect blood culture for microbiology specimens.

Other options:

  1. Ethylenediamine tetraacetic acid (EDTA) - It is used for routine hematology samples and is a part of violet vacutainers.
  2. Sodium fluoride - It is used for the determination of glucose and is a part of grey vacutainers
  3. Sodium citrate - It is used for coagulation studies and is a part of blue vacutainers.

Related Pearl: Anticoagulants in Vacutainers and their Uses

questions.text: A 36-year-old P2L2 woman visits the OPD requesting sterilization surgery.  Of the many methods available, the doctor suggests the procedure described in the image given below. Identify this method of tubal sterilization.
questions.solution:
The method of tubal sterilization shown in the image is the Uchida technique.

In this method, the serosa over the mid segment of the fallopian tube is stripped off exposing the muscular layer. The exposed part is ligated and excised. The proximal end is buried in the broad ligament and the distal end is left open outside the mesosalpinx. An advantage of this method is that the minimal excision of the tube provides scope for tuboplasty in the future.

An image showing the Uchida technique is given below.


Option A - Irving procedure involves ligating and excising the mid-portion of the tube after which the proximal stump is buried into the myometrium and the distal stump is buried in the broad ligament. It is an irreversible technique and may require a laparotomy incision.

The procedure described in the image below is the Irving procedure.


Option B - Pomeroy procedure is the most popular technique of tubal sterilization. In this method, the fallopian tube is identified on each side, brought out through the incision, and the middle portion is formed into a loop which is tied at the base with catgut and excised as shown in the image below.


Option D - Madlener procedure is a simple procedure but is associated with high rates of failure. In this procedure, the fallopian tube is identified on each side, brought out through the incision. A loop is made, and is crushed and ligated with a nonabsorbable suture as shown below.


Other methods of sterilization:

  • Laparotomy/Minilaparotomy:
    • Kroener's technique: It refers to the excision of fimbriae (fimbriectomy). 
    • Aldridge method: A hole is made in the anterior leaf of the broad ligament and the fimbrial end is buried into this.
    • Cornual resection: The cornual part of the tube is resected where it is attached to uterus.
  • Laparoscopic techniques:
    • Using Falope ring, Hulka clip, and Filshie clip.
  • Hysteroscopic sterilization with the Essure permanent device: It causes a benign local fibrous tissue growth that occludes the fallopian tube. It takes 3 months to occlude the tube, which is confirmed with hysterosalpingography. During this period of 3 months, other methods of contraception should be used. It is an irreversible technique.

questions.text: The bronchoscopy findings in a patient with long-standing goiter show a narrow tracheal lumen and loss of semicircular shape, suggestive of tracheal collapsibility. What is incorrect regarding this condition?

choices.text: Prolonged intubation is a secondary cause

questions.solution:
The given bronchoscopy finding of narrowing of the tracheal lumen with loss of semicircular shape and increased tracheal collapsibility in a patient with long-standing goiter is suggestive of tracheomalacia. Mitomycin C is used in the management of subglottic stenosis, and not tracheomalacia.

Tracheomalacia is an anatomical defect of the trachea characterized by increased trachea collapsibility due to the trachea's structural abnormality. Long-standing goitre can cause tracheomalacia due to constant pressure over the tracheal cartilage leading to pressure necrosis and destruction of the tissue.

Primary tracheomalacia is congenital and associated with connective tissue disorders, like Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, Marfan syndrome, and cutis laxa (option B). Tracheomalacia can also be caused secondarily due to acquired causes that apply extrinsic pressure on the trachea like a goiter, neoplasm, and causes that weaken the tracheal structure like tracheobronchitis or prolonged intubation (option D).

The symptoms of primary tracheomalacia first develop between 4-6 weeks. It presents with high-pitched expiratory stridor, which develops when the airflow in the trachea increases due to crying, feeding, or physical activity (option A).

Tracheomalacia can be treated conservatively with medical and surgical methods, based on the extent of the disease and other associated conditions. Conservative management includes symptomatic management for breathlessness and infections such as bronchodilators, anti-muscarinic agents, mucolytics, and antibiotics. Chest physiotherapy may be necessary to help the management of secretions and prevent airway infections.

Prevention and management of gastroesophageal reflux is mandatory, and specific feeding regimes are required to avoid aspiration and ensure adequate growth and development. Continuous positive pressure ventilation (CPAP) is an option for those who fail conservative management. Surgery is the last resort for these patients.

questions.text:
A 44-year-old female patient with Sjogren's syndrome presents to your clinic with complaints of severe fatigue and generalized pruritus. Laboratory examination reveals elevated GGT, ALP, IgM, and the presence of anti-mitochondrial antibodies. A liver biopsy was performed, which shows the following histopathological findings. What is the most likely diagnosis?

GGT - Gamma-glutamyltransferase

ALP - Alkaline phosphatase
questions.solution:
The histopathological findings demonstrate chronic non-suppurative destructive cholangitis. Lymphocyte (arrow) and plasma cell (bold arrow) infiltration into the bile duct along with clinical history, is strongly suggestive of primary biliary cirrhosis (PBC).

Primary biliary cirrhosis is an autoimmune destructive condition of the small and medium-sized intrahepatic bile ducts. It is most commonly seen in women who are 40-50 years of age. It is also found in association with other autoimmune diseases such as-

  • Sjogren syndrome
  • Thyroiditis
  • Scleroderma 
  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Raynaud phenomenon
  • Celiac disease.

Clinical features of PBC include: 

  • Fatigue is out of proportion to liver disease
  • Debilitating pruritis
  • Jaundice
  • Hyperpigmentation of the trunk and arms in areas of repeated scratching
  • Xanthelasma and Xanthoma

Investigations reveal elevated liver enzymes such as GGT and ALP are significantly elevated with only mild elevation of AST and ALT enzymes. About 90% of the patients will have anti-mitochondrial antibodies. Biopsy of the liver may confirm the diagnosis and shows a florid duct lesion (as given in the image). This is due to the destruction of interlobular bile ducts with lymphoplasmacytic inflammation with or without granuloma formation. In PBC bile accumulation is seen in peri-portal areas, unlike drug-induced or obstructive cholestasis, where bile is accumulated in the centrizonal areas. Mallory–Denk bodies may also be seen. Cirrhosis usually develops in long-standing diseases.

Ursodeoxycholic acid when started in the early phase of the disease, improves both biochemical and histological features. If there is marked cirrhosis, then liver transplantation is the only definitive treatment. Anti-histamines, narcotic receptor antagonists (naltrexone), and rifampin may be used to manage pruritis. 

 Other options:

Option A - Acute cholangitis (as well as suppurative cholangitis or ascending cholangitis) is a disorder associated with recurrent fever, abdominal pain, and jaundice. This clinical combination has been traditionally known as Charcot’s triad. Acute cholangitis is primarily an infectious disease characterized by the proliferation of bacteria within the bile ducts and with the secondary blockage of biliary tracts. The Reynolds' pentad is defined as the occurrence of confusion and shock along with Charcot’s triad. Lab investigations reveal elevated liver enzymes and pro-inflammatory markers. 

Option B - Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is defined as the presence of hepatic steatosis in individuals who do not consume alcohol or do so in small quantities. Histopathological diagnosis requires steatosis (≥5% of hepatocytes), lobular inflammation, and ballooned hepatocytes. Serum AST and ALT are elevated in most patients with NASH. 

Option D - Primary sclerosing cholangitis presents with fatigue, pruritus, steatorrhea similar to PBC. It is more common in men in the 3-5th decade. It is characterized by diffuse inflammation and fibrosis involving the entire biliary tree. The perinuclear antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody (p-ANCA), is positive and anti-mitochondrial antibodies aren't seen. Diagnosis is usually done by magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) and definitive management is by liver transplantation.

questions.text:
An 30 year old female has booked an appointment to discuss about a bariatric surgery called sleeve gastrectomy. In which of the following scenarios would the surgery be offered to her?

BMI - Body Mass Index

choices.text: BMI of 45kg/m2 with Bulimia nervosa unresponsive to psychotherapy
BMI of 30 kg/m2 with bilateral knee osteoarthritis
BMI of  38kg/m2 with non alcoholic steatohepatitis

questions.solution:
The correct option is a BMI of 38kg/m2 with non-alcoholic steatohepatitis.

BMI ≥35 kg/m2 with obesity-associated comorbidity is an indication for bariatric surgeries.

Nonalcoholic staetohepatitis(NASH) is a known complication of obesity. Bariatric surgery is beneficial for NASH, where the resulting weight loss improves the prognosis.

Indications for bariatric surgery include : 

  • BMI ≥40 kg/m2 with no comorbid conditions 
  • BMI ≥35 kg/m2 with obesity-associated comorbidity 
  • Failure of previous nonsurgical attempts at weight reduction, including nonprofessional programs 
  • Expectation that patient will adhere to postoperative care 

Contraindications to bariatric surgery are :

  • Prohibitive surgical risk, ASA IV(American Society of Anesthesiologists)
  • Reversible endocrine or other disorders that can cause obesity
  • Current drug or alcohol misuse
  • Uncontrolled, severe psychiatric illness
  • Uncontrolled, severe bulimia
  • Lack of comprehension of risks, benefits, expected outcomes, alternatives, and lifestyle changes

Other options:

Option A: Uncontrolled bulimia nervosa indicates psychiatric instability which would make any bariatric surgery futile. 

Option B: BMI of 30 kg/m2 is below the cut-off of 35 kg/m2 as an indication for bariatric surgery in obesity with comorbidities. However, there are certain scenarios where bariatric surgery can be indicated below this cut-off:

  • Recommended in patients with type 2 diabetes and a BMI ≥30 kg/m2.
  • Should be considered in patients with a BMI of 30-34.9 kg/m2 who are refractory to nonsurgical approaches.

Option D: Barrett's esophagus is a contraindication for sleeve gastrectomy. Sleeve gastrectomy results in a high-pressure system in the stomach, which increases acid reflux. Hence patients with long-standing severe gastroesophageal reflux and Barrett’s esophagus are not suitable candidates for the procedure, since the potential for future esophageal dysplasia and the need for an available intact stomach for esophageal reconstruction outweigh the potential advantages.

questions.text: A 54-year-old male patient presented with quadriparesis for 6 months. Symptoms began as dysarthria and a stiff tongue, lower limb weakness which progressed to all four limbs. Bilateral extensor plantar response, exaggerated reflexes, fasciculations, and severe muscle atrophy are present. Bladder, bowel, and sensory functions are intact. Which of the following is used in the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) and riluzole is used in its treatment.

Progressive upper motor neuron (UMN) palsy (exaggerated reflexes, extensor plantar), lower motor neuron (LMN) palsy (muscle weakness, atrophy, fasciculations), and pseudobulbar palsy (dysarthria, tongue spasticity), with normal bladder, bowel and sensory function are suggestive of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS).

Treatment:

  1. Riluzole acts by reducing excitotoxicity by diminishing glutamate release. It lengthens the survival of the patient. Side effects are minimal that include nausea, vomiting, dizziness, and elevated liver enzymes occasionally. 
  2. Edaravone (IV infusion) works in the central nervous system as a potent scavenger of oxygen radicals and is a newer drug that has the capability of slowing down ALS progression and improving survival.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is the most common form of progressive motor neuron disease. Genetic mutations in genes encoding cytosolic enzyme SOD1 (superoxide dismutase). The pathologic hallmark of motor neuron degenerative disorders is the death of lower motor neurons (consisting of anterior horn cells in the spinal cord and their brainstem homologs innervating bulbar muscles) and upper, or corticospinal, motor neurons (originating in layer five of the motor cortex and descending via the pyramidal tract to synapse with lower motor neurons, either directly or indirectly via interneurons).

Although at its onset, ALS may involve selective loss of function of only upper or lower motor neurons, it ultimately causes progressive loss of both categories of motor neurons.

Even in the late stages of ALS, sensory, bowel & bladder functions are preserved.

Clinical features:

  • LMN lesion: Fasciculations, muscle cramps, weakness, atrophy, and bulbar palsy
  • UMN lesion: Spasticity, increased reflexes, flexor spasms, and pseudobulbar palsy
  • Another frequent bulbar UMN symptom is the syndrome of the pseudobulbar effect. This is manifested as inappropriate laughing, crying, or yawning. 

Other options:

Option A- Tetrabenazine is a reversible VMAT2 inhibitor that depletes presynaptic catecholamines. It is used for chorea in Huntington's disease. The dosage is adjusted when it is given with CYP2D6 inhibitors like paroxetine, fluoxetine, bupropion as they decrease the metabolism of tetrabenazine. Adverse effects include hypotension and depression. 

Option B- Memantine acts by reducing excitotoxicity through use-dependent blockade of NMDA receptors. It is used in cases of moderate to severe Alzheimer's disease.

Option D- Rivastigmine is a carbamate derivative of physostigmine. It inhibits predominantly acetyl choline esterase enzyme (AChE). It is prescribed in cases of mild-moderate cases of Alzheimer's disease.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with fever, myalgia, and enlarged lymph nodes over the groin. He gives a history of handling rodents as a part of his job. Fluid from the lymph node showed bipolar bacilli with Wayson's stain. The spreading  potential of the underlying disease is assessed by which of the following?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a man with buboes (enlarged groin nodes) and Wayson's stain showing bipolar bacilli are suggestive of bubonic plague caused by Yersinia pestis, and the spreading potential of the disease is assessed by the Cheopis index. 

A plague is a zoonotic infection caused by Yersinia pestis and is usually transmitted by the bite of an infected rat flea. Rodent burrows serve as a favorable surface for the bacteria to grow and thus get transmitted by rat fleas. The most common vector that effectively spreads the infection is Xenopsylla cheopis. Flea indices are used to assess the density of the vector. One of the most specific indices is the Cheopis index. It is the measure of the average number of Xenopsylla cheopis per rat.  

There are three forms of plague: 

  1. Bubonic plague- Characterized by fever, chills, and buboes (more commonly in the groin and less commonly in the axilla) 
  2. Pneumonic plague- Occurs as a complication of septic plague or bubonic plague and bacilli can be isolated from sputum as well
  3. Septic plague - Occurs in an overwhelming infection leading to sudden onset sepsis

Investigations include the demonstration of bacillus from the samples of blood, sputum, and buboes. Yersinia is a coccobacillus that exhibits bipolar staining with Wayson's stain. Culture and serology can also be done.

Treatment should be started without awaiting investigations due to the high rate of mortality. Streptomycin is the drug of choice to treat plague, and it should be given intramuscularly in two doses (30 mg/kg). Other preventive measures include regular usage of rodenticides, proper application of effective insecticides, and disinfection. If a patient is suspected to have symptoms suggestive of plague, isolation is advised.

Related Pearl: Flea Indices

They are useful in measurements of density of fleas.

They include: 

  • Total flea index – it is the average number of fleas of all species per rat
  • Cheopis index - it is the average number of Xenopsylla cheopis species per rat,hence it is a specific flea index. It indicates the maximum explosiveness of the situation
  • Specific percentage of fleas – it is a precentage of different species of fleas that are found on rats.
  • Burrow index – It is the average  number of free living flea per species per rodent burrow.

Related Pearl: Rat Fleas

  • Rat fleas (Xenopsylla cheopis) belong to the genus Xenopsylla.
  • Their morphology includes a conical head, absent neck, a thorax with 3 segments, and an abdomen with 10 segments. They have three pairs of legs and no wings.
  • The four stages in their life cycle are egg, larva, pupa, and adult.
  • They cannot fly but can leap up to 6 inches horizontally.
  • They transmit diseases by biting, mechanical transmission, and feces.
  • Flea indices that are used in flea surveys are the general flea index, specific flea index, percentage incidence of flea species, and rodent infestation rate.
  • Rat fleas are vectors for endemic typhus (murine typhus), chiggerosis, bubonic plague, and Hymenolepis diminuta.
  • Insecticidal control is mainly by 10% DDT.
  • Resistance to DDT, gamma-HCH, and dieldrin has been recorded.
  • Repellants like diethyltoluamide and benzyl benzoate are efficient.
  • Rodent control also aims to reduce flea infestation.

questions.text: The given instrument is used for suction and evacuation of uterine contents. Which of the following statements is false with respect to it?

choices.text: The size used corresponds to the duration of pregnancy in weeks
Used for medical termination of pregnancy in the first trimester
The end of suction is detected by the grating sensation of the instrument against the uterus
800mm Hg pressure is used during suction

questions.solution:
The given image is that of Karman’s cannula which is used during suction and evacuation procedures. The pressure generated during the procedure is 400 - 600 mm Hg.

It is used for the medical termination of pregnancy in the first trimester (option B)and removal of hydatidiform mole, by suction and evacuation. The appropriate size of the cannula(diameter in mm) corresponds to the duration of pregnancy in weeks(option A).

The end of suction is denoted by - 

  • No more material being sucked out
  • Gripping of the cannula by contracting smaller uterus
  • Grating sensation(option C)
  • Apperance of bubbles in the cannula

questions.text: Identify the correct statement regarding the structure enclosing the testicular artery and vas deferens in the inguinal canal.

choices.text: Internal spermatic fascia is derived from internal oblique muscle
Cremastric fascia is derived from external oblique muscle
Femoral branch of genitofemoral nerve is a content of this structure
Enters the inguinal canal through deep inguinal ring

questions.solution:
The structure that protects the testicular artery and vas deferens is the spermatic cord which enters the inguinal canal through the deep inguinal ring and passes out through the superficial inguinal ring.

The spermatic cord is a structure that passes through the inguinal canal in males. The inguinal canal is a natural passageway between the muscle layers of the anterior abdominal wall in the region of the groin. It transmits the spermatic cord in males, the round ligament of the uterus in females, and the ilioinguinal nerve in both sexes.

Coverings of the spermatic cord from inside to outside are:

  • Internal spermatic fascia is derived from fascia transversalis (option A)
  • Cremasteric fascia is derived from the Internal oblique (Option B)
  • External spermatic fascia is derived from the external oblique aponeurosis 

The image below shows the contents of the spermatic cord:


Other options:

Option C: The femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve is not a content of the spermatic cord. It is a cutaneous nerve and supplies most of the skin over the femoral triangle. Genital branch of genitofemoral nerve is a content of the spermatic cord.

Related Pearl: Inguinal canal and spermatic cord contents

questions.text: Which of the following Couinaud segments of the liver drains directly into the inferior vena cava?
questions.solution:
Segment 1 ( Caudate lobe) drains directly into the Inferior vena cava(IVC).

Couinaud classification is the commonly used classification of the liver. It divides the liver into eight segments. It is based on the distribution of portal venous branches in the liver parenchyma. Each segment has its own dual vascular inflow, biliary drainage, and lymphatic drainage.

The left lobe is composed of the left lateral segment (Couinaud’s segments II and III) and the left medial segment (segment IV). The right lobe is composed of segments V, VI, VII, and VIII, with segments V and VIII making up the right anterior lobe and segments VI and VII making up the right posterior lobe.

Segment I corresponds to the caudate lobe of the liver and segment IV corresponds to the quadrate lobe of the liver. Segment IV is divided into segments IVa and IVb.

All the Couinaud segments are supplied by the portal vein and hepatic artery for the arterial supply. Venous drainage of Couinaud segments II to VIII drained into right and left hepatic veins except for segment I (Caudate lobe) which drains directly into the Inferior vena cava. All segments drained lymph into respective right and left hepatic ducts.

Related Pearl: Couinaud's liver segments

The Couinaud classification is currently the most widely used system to describe functional liver anatomy.

  • Based on the distribution of hepatic portal venous branches in the parenchyma
  • Each segment has its own dual vascular inflow, biliary drainage and lymphatic drainage

Segment I corresponds to the gross anatomical caudate lobe and is considered as posterior segment.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding selectins?

choices.text: P-selectins are expressed on platelets only
Selectin ligand interactions are of high-affinity
L-selectin ligands are expressed on endothelial cells

questions.solution:
L-selectins are expressed on leukocytes and their complementary ligands (Sialyl-Lewis glycoproteins) are expressed on endothelial cells.

Selectins are of 3 types: L-selectin present on leukocytes, E-selectin present on the endothelium, and P-selectin present in platelets and on the endothelium (option A). 

Selectins mediate the weak rolling action due to their low-affinity interactions with their ligands (option B), which slows down the leukocytes and allows them to bind more firmly to the endothelium with the help of integrins.

The recruitment of leukocytes to the site of injury involves the following steps:

  • Lumen of the vessel to the endothelium:
    • Margination: Leukocytes assume a peripheral position along the endothelial surface because of the stasis of blood flow.
    • Rolling: Leukocytes start rolling on the vessel wall because of signaling molecules from the endothelium. Factors involved in leukocyte rolling include selectins and their ligands (Sialyl-Lewis glycoproteins).
    • Adhesion: Leukocytes are attached to the endothelium because of the interaction between integrins and their endothelial ligands.
  • Transmigration of the leukocytes across the vascular endothelium. This is mediated by PECAM-1 or CD31, which is a member of the immunoglobulin superfamily.
  • Migration towards a chemotactic stimulus in the extravascular tissues.


Other options: 

Option D: Leukocyte adhesion deficiency 1 is caused by defective beta 2 integrin (CD18). This leads to abnormal neutrophil chemotaxis and defective tight adhesion.

questions.text: A young patient is being evaluated for medical fitness to participate in a sports event. Laboratory investigations reveal low levels of thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) and normal levels of unbound T3 and T4. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Low levels of thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH), along with normal levels of unbound T3 and T4, suggest subclinical hyperthyroidism.(Option D)

The first step in the evaluation of thyrotoxicosis is to measure TSH and unbound T4 levels.

If the TSH is low and T4 is high, then it is a case of primary thyrotoxicosis. Patients with Graves' disease may have additional features like diffuse goiter on palpation, ophthalmopathy, and a personal or family history of autoimmune disorders. Primary thyrotoxicosis due to multinodular goiter or toxic adenoma can be identified using a radionuclide (99mTc, 123I, or 131I) scan. 

If the TSH is low and unbound T4 is normal, then measure unbound T3 levels. Elevated unbound T3 levels mean T3 thyrotoxicosis, whereas normal T3 levels mean that the patient has subclinical hyperthyroidism.

If the TSH levels are normal or increased with high unbound T4 levels, it means that increased T4 is a result of increased actions of TSH. It is caused due to TSH-secreting pituitary adenoma or thyroid hormone resistance syndrome.

If the TSH is high and unbound T4 and T3 is normal , it indicates subclinical hypothyroidism. Symptoms of hypothyroidism usually appear at TSH levels >10 mIU/L with accompanying fall in unbound T4 levels, which is referred to as clinical hypothyroidism or overt hypothyroidism. 

Related Pearl: Thyroid storm / Thyrotoxic crisis:

It is an emergency caused by an acute exacerbation of hyperthyroidism. 

Precipitating factors:

  • When a thyrotoxic patient has been inadequately prepared for thyroidectomy
  • Abrupt cessation of antithyroid medications
  • Stress
    • Infection
    • Thyroid or non-thyroid surgery
    • Trauma in patients with untreated thyrotoxicosis
  • Acute iodine load
    • Amiodarone administration 
    • Exposure to iodinated contrast agents
    • Following RAI therapy

Clinical features:

  • Fever
  • Tachycardia
  • Altered mentation (delirium, psychosis, coma)
  • GI symptoms (nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea)
  • Atrial fibrillation and cardiac failure - most common causes of death

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the clinic with the findings below. He was born at 38 weeks of gestation to a mother who was retropositive. Which other condition can this child develop in the clinical stage that he is currently in?
questions.solution:
This child with oesophageal candidiasis and Kaposi's sarcoma as shown in the images respectively is most likely suffering from AIDS (acquired immunodeficiency syndrome) clinical stage 4. The other feature seen in this stage is CMV (cytomegalovirus) retinitis. This is according to the WHO (World Health Organization) staging of AIDS in children with confirmed HIV infection.

CMV retinitis is a common opportunistic ocular infection seen in patients who are retro-positive. Ocular symptoms of CMV infection include reduced vision, floaters, and anterior uveitis. In the later stages, the patient can develop cataracts. Retinitis usually starts in the periphery with flame-shaped retinal hemorrhages. The direct spread of the infection can lead to optic neuritis. It can result in visual loss if left untreated.

Option B: Persistent oral candidiasis is seen in Stage 3

questions.text:
Which of the following indicates the therapeutic index of a drug?

ED50 - Median effective dose

LD50 - Median lethal dose
questions.solution:
The therapeutic index is calculated with the following equation = LD50/ED50.

The therapeutic index (TI) describes a relationship between the doses of a drug that causes lethal or toxic effects with the dose that causes therapeutic effects. It is also called the therapeutic ratio. The therapeutic index is used to assess the safety of the drug administered.

Mathematically, you can calculate TI in the following way:

Therapeutic Index = LD50/ED50 or TD50/ED50

where LD50 is the mean lethal dose, TD50 is the mean toxic dose, and ED50 is the median effective dose 

Median lethal dose (LD50) and median toxic dose (TD50)

  • LD50 is the dose of the drug at which 50% of the experimental animals die.
  • In human trials, TD50 can be considered. It is the dose of the drug that causes adverse effects in 50% of the population.
  • Larger the LD50 or TD50, the safer the drug. 

Median effective dose (ED50)

  • The dose of the drug at which 50% of the experimental animals show the specific or desired effect
  • ED50 is the quantity of a drug that can produce the desired therapeutic effects in 50% of the population.

The therapeutic window refers to a range of concentrations at which the likelihood of efficacy is high and the probability of adverse effects is low.

Related Pearl: Drugs which need Therapeutic Drug Monitoring (TDM)

Drugs with a narrow therapeutic index require therapeutic drug monitoring (TDM).

The mnemonic "DATLAAT MC" can be used.

  • A: Anti-arrhythmic

questions.text: Which of the following signs is unlikely to be seen in the radiograph of a patient suspected to have pneumoperitoneum?
questions.solution:
The spinnaker sign (also known as the angel wing sign) is a sign of pneumomediastinum seen on neonatal chest radiographs. It refers to the thymus being outlined by air with each lobe displaced laterally and appearing like spinnaker sails (given in the image below).

Pneumoperitoneum refers to air within the peritoneal cavity. Rigler's sign, telltale triangle sign, falciform ligament sign are the radiological findings seen in a supine abdominal x-ray.

Signs of pneumoperitoneum:

  • Bowel-related signs
    • Double-wall sign / Rigler's sign / bas-relief sign - air is seen on both sides of the bowel wall
    • Telltale triangle sign / triangle sign
  • Peritoneal ligament-related signs
    • Football sign - air outlines the confines of the peritoneal cavity
    • Falciform ligament sign - air outlines the falciform ligament
    • Lateral umbilical ligament sign / inverted "V" sign - air outlines the lateral umbilical ligament
    • Urachus sign
  • Right upper quadrant signs
    • Cupola sign - air outlines the median subphrenic space
    • Fissure for ligamentum teres sign
    • Hepatic edge sign
    • Lucent liver sign
    • Morison's pouch sign / Doge cap sign
    • Periportal free gas sign.

The image given below is an abdominal radiograph showing Rigler's sign in pneumoperitoneum. Here both the inner and the outer walls of the bowel are visible.

The below image is a supine abdominal radiograph is showing the presence of air in the bilateral subphrenic spaces and a linear density on the ventral surface of the liver (arrow). This is known as the falciform ligament sign.

questions.text: Identify the surgical procedure depicted in the image below.
questions.solution:
The image depicts low anterior resection. 

Low anterior resection is a surgery done for the treatment of rectal cancers, where the rectum is excised and a coloanal anstomosis is created with the help of a circular stapling device.

Other options:

1) Stapled hemorrhoidopexy is an intervention for the treatment of internal hemorrhoids. It involves excision of a strip of the mucosa and the submucosa(together with the vessels travelling with them) circumferentially above the dentate line and stapling the edges together. 

3) Anal sphincterotomy is done for the treatment of anal fissure, where the internal anal sphincter is divided away from the fissure.

4) Resection rectopexy is an abdominal approach for the treatment of rectal prolapse. It involves resection of the sigmoid colon and fixing the rectum in its normal anatomical position at the sacrum using a mesh, Teflon sling or interrupted sutures.

NOTE: In stapled hemorroidopexy, the colon would NOT be disconnected from the rectum/anal canal during the staple fire. Therefore option A is incorrect.

questions.text: A 1-month-old infant was brought to you with hypotonia, a weak cough, and tongue fasciculations. A diagnosis of spinal muscular atrophy was made. Which of the following marked regions is affected in this condition?
questions.solution:
The region marked 1 which shows the anterior horn of the spinal cord is affected in spinal muscular atrophy.

Spinal muscular atrophy (SMA) is an autosomal recessive pattern disease characterized by progressive degeneration of the motor neurons. It results from a continuation of apoptosis that normally occurs in the embryonal period. This results in extensive neuronal degeneration and gliosis of the anterior horns of the spinal cord and brainstem motor nuclei.

Clinically SMA is classified into four types:

  • SMA type I/ Werdnig-Hoffmann disease
  • SMA type II
  • SMA type III/ Kugelberg-Welander disease
  • SMA type IV

SMA type I is seen before the age of six months. Children present with hypotonia, proximal muscle weakness, frog-leg posture, and tongue fasciculations. Involvement of the intercostal respiratory muscles causes a paradoxical abdominal breathing pattern and weak cough. Deep tendon reflexes are usually absent. It should be kept as one of the differential diagnoses for floppy infant syndrome.

SMA type II is seen between the age of 6-18 months. Children present with developmental delay, scoliosis, speech, and deglutition problems.

The proximal muscles involving the shoulder girdle are affected in SMA type III. Muscle hypertrophy might be present rather than atrophy.

SMA type IV (adult phenotype) presents with mild muscle weakness in the second or third decade of life. 

The gold standard for diagnosis is testing for SMN1 (survival motor neuron) gene deletion/ mutation. Supportive therapy enabling the patient to be maximally functionally independent is the mainstay in management.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy was brought with multiple ring-shaped lesions in the scalp with patchy hair loss and pruritis for a few weeks. He was started on an oral antifungal drug acting on point A in the following diagram. This drug is most likely to be:
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of multiple ring-shaped lesions in the scalp with patchy hair loss and pruritis is suggestive of tinea capitis. The drug acting on point A in the above diagram is griseofulvin. 

Griseofulvin is a fungistatic antifungal agent. Griseofulvin disrupts the fungal cell division by inhibiting microtubule function and thereby disrupts the assembly of the mitotic spindle. 

It is administered orally and its absorption is improved when taken with a fatty meal. It gets deposited in the keratin precursor cells and binds tightly to keratin. Thereby, it provides prolonged resistance to fungal invasion. 

They are only effective against dermatophytes Microsporum, Epidermophyton, and Trichophyton. It is the drug of choice for tinea capitis and tenia pedis.

Griseofulvin induces hepatic CYPs and thereby increases the rate of metabolism of warfarin and low-estrogen oral contraceptive agents. Side effects of griseofulvin include headache, gastrointestinal disturbance, and hepatotoxicity.

Other options:

Option A: Amphotericin B binds to ergosterol in the fungal membrane and forms pores or channels (point C) in the fungal cell membrane and allows the leakage of cytosolic molecules and ions, leading to loss of membrane integrity.

It is a broad-spectrum antifungal that can be used against Candida, Cryptococcus neoformans, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Histoplasma capsulatum, Sporothrix schenckii, Coccidioides, Paracoccidioides braziliensis, Aspergillus, Penicillium marneffei, Fusarium, and Mucorales.

Option B: Itraconazole is triazole that inhibits 14-alpha-sterol demethylase (point D) and impairs the biosynthesis of ergosterol which leads to accumulation of the toxic product 14 alpha-methyl-3,6-diol resulting in growth arrest. 

Itraconazole is the drug of choice for nonmeningeal infections due to B. dermatitidis, H. capsulatum, P. brasiliensis, and Coccidioides immitis. The drug also is useful in the therapy of invasive aspergillosis particularly after the infection has been treated with amphotericin B.

Option C: Terbinafine inhibits fungal squalene epoxidase (point B) and reduces ergosterol biosynthesis. They are more effective against nail onychomycosis than itraconazole.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of Antifungal drugs

questions.text: Which of the following is the requirement to give mass treatment for trachoma in a community?

choices.text: Prevalance of more than 5% of cases in adolescent age groups
Prevelance of more than 5% of cases in children of 1-9 years
Prevalance of more than 10% of cases in children of age 1-9 years
Prevalance of more than 10% of cases in adolescent age groups

questions.solution:
Prevalence of trachoma cases of more than 10% in children of age group 1-9 years is an important criterion to start mass prophylaxis of antibiotic treatment in the community according to the WHO program to control trachoma.

Trachoma is a form of chronic infective conjunctivitis and is one of the leading causes of blindness. It has an ‘active’ inflammatory stage and a ‘cicatricial’ chronic stage. The active inflammatory stage is more prevalent in children. They present with conjunctival follicles containing Leber cells and corneal Herbert's follicles.

The cicatricial chronic stage is seen in middle age. The patient complains of pain, lacrimation, photophobia, and finally loss of vision.

Trachoma is treated according to the WHO classification using the SAFE strategy (Surgery, Antibiotics, Facial hygiene, and Environmental improvement). Azithromycin is the antibiotic of choice, and surgery involves the correction of trichiasis and entropion.

Note: WHO has declared that trachoma has been eliminated as a public health problem in India in October 2024

Related Pearl: WHO Programme to Control Trachoma: SAFE Strategy

  • S—Surgery: Trichiasis and entropion correction surgery → 3° prevention.
  • A—Antibiotics: Oral azithromycin, topical 1% tetracycline, topical 1% azithromycin → 2° prevention
  • F—Facial hygiene → 1° prevention.
  • E—Environmental cleanliness → primordial prevention

The strategy depends on the prevalence of trachoma follicle in children (aged 1–9 yrs)

  • >10% → Mass antibiotic treatment at the community level and FE measures
  • 5 to 10% → Targeted antibiotic treatment (affected families) and FE measures
  • < 5% → FE measures 

Related Pearl: WHO classification of trachoma (FISTO)

WHO grading of trachoma

  • TF = trachomatous inflammation (follicular): five or more follicles (>0.5 mm) on the superior tarsal conjunctiva.
  • TI = trachomatous inflammation (intense): diffuse involvement of the tarsal conjunctiva, obscuring 50% or more of the normal deep tarsal vessels; papillae are present
  • TS = trachomatous conjunctival scarring: easily visible fibrous white tarsal bands
  • TT = trachomatous trichiasis: at least one lash touching the globe
  • CO = corneal opacity sufficient to blur details of at least part of the pupillary margin

questions.text: CO2 is released in which of the following steps of the tricarboxylic acid (TCA) cycle?
questions.solution:
CO2 is released in steps B and C. Step B is the conversion of isocitrate to ketoglutarate which is catalyzed by isocitrate dehydrogenase. Step C is the conversion of ketoglutarate to succinate which is catalyzed by alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase. In these steps, there are releases of CO2 and conversion of NAD+ to NADH.

The tricarboxylic acid cycle (TCA, Kreb's cycle, or citric acid cycle) refers to a sequence of reactions that take place in the mitochondria. It oxidizes acetyl-CoA to CO2 and reduces coenzymes that are reoxidized through the electron transport chain, with the formation of ATP. It is an aerobic pathway.

The TCA cycle is the final common pathway for the oxidation of carbohydrates, lipids, and proteins. Most amino acids get metabolized either to acetyl CoA or to an intermediate of the cycle. It plays an important role in gluconeogenesis, lipogenesis, and the interconversion of amino acids. Since it functions in both oxidative as well as synthetic processes, it is an amphibolic pathway.

3 molecules of NADH and 1 molecule of FADH2 are produced for each molecule of acetyl-CoA that is catabolized during one turn of the TCA cycle. Each NADH gives approximately 2.5 ATP and FADH2 gives 1.5 ATP when they are reoxidized. In addition, 1 ATP (or GTP) is formed at the substrate level when succinyl CoA is converted to succinate. Thus, 10 ATP are generated for one turn of the TCA cycle (3x2.5 ATP from NADH +1.5 ATP from FADH2+1GTP).

questions.text: Pepsinogen is secreted by which of the following marked cells in the gastric gland from the body of the stomach?
questions.solution:
Pepsinogen is secreted by chief cells marked as 4.

Chief cells are identified by their location towards the base of the gland. These cells secrete pepsinogen and gastric lipase.

The structure marked 1 in the region of the isthmus of a gastric gland. Mucous neck cells and stem cells are present in this region.

The structure marked 2 is the parietal cell (oxyntic cell). It is characterized by the presence of canaliculi. The cell has numerous mitochondria because it is actively involved in the secretion of hydrochloric acid.

The structure marked 3 is the enterochromaffin-like cell (ECL). It is identified by its location in the subepithelial region. The function of this cell is to release histamine which in turn stimulates the parietal cells to secrete HCL. The ECL is stimulated by gastrin secreted by G cells from the pylorus and acetylcholine secreted by the vagus.

questions.text: A neonatologist prescribes the following method to practice to the family of a newborn child with 1.9 kg birth weight. What is incorrect regarding the positioning of the baby in this method?

choices.text: Head-turned to one side and in a slightly extended position.
The abdomen should be at the level of mother's epigastrium.
The legs should be extended and adducted.

questions.solution:
The image shows Kangaroo mother care (KMC), and the baby's legs must be flexed and abducted, not extended and adducted (Option D).

The Kangaroo positioning:

  • Head-turned to one side and in a slightly extended position. It keeps the airway of the baby open and allows eye-to-eye contact with the mother. 
  • The abdomen should be at the level of the mother's epigastrium. The mother's breathing stimulates the baby, thus preventing apnea. 
  • The arms should be flexed.
  • The legs should be flexed and abducted in a 'frog' position. 

KMC was introduced for the prevention of neonatal hypothermia in low birth weight/ premature newborns. It has 4 components:

  • Skin-to-skin positioning of the newborn on the mother’s chest.
  • Adequate nutrition through breastfeeding.
  • Early discharge and ambulatory care.
  • Support for mother and family for child care.

KMC can be carried out by the mother or any other caregiver.

KMC can even be done on mothers who are on IV fluids, CPAP, or even ventilators if they are hemodynamically stable.

Eligibiilty criteria for KMC:

It is indicated for all hemodynamically stable low-birth-weight babies. Short sessions of KMC can be initiated in babies on medical treatment like IV fluids or oxygen therapy. Initiation of KMC can vary with the birth weight of the baby.

  • Birthweight <1200 g - It may take days to weeks for initiation of KMC
  • Birthweight 1200–1800 g - Only a few days may be taken before KMC initiation
  • Birthweight >1800 g - KMC can be initiated immediately after birth

Related Pearl: Baby-friendly hospital initiative (revised 2018)

Ten steps to successful breastfeeding (Revised 2018)

Critical management procedures

1  a. Comply fully with the International Code of Marketing of Breast-milk Substitutes and relevant World Health Assembly resolutions.

    b. Have a written infant feeding policy that is routinely communicated to staff and parents.

    c. Establish ongoing monitoring and data-management systems.

2. Ensure that staff has sufficient knowledge, competence, and skills to support breastfeeding.

Key clinical practices

3. Discuss the importance and management of breastfeeding with pregnant women and their families.

4. Facilitate immediate and uninterrupted skin-to-skin contact and support mothers to initiate breastfeeding as soon as possible after birth.

5. Support mothers to initiate and maintain breastfeeding and manage common difficulties.

6. Do not provide breastfed newborns any food or fluids other than breast milk, unless medically indicated.

7. Enable mothers and their infants to remain together and to practice rooming-in 24 hours a day.

8. Support mothers to recognize and respond to their infants’ cues for feeding.

9. Counsel mothers on the use and risks of feeding bottles, teats, and pacifiers.

10. Coordinate discharge so that parents and their infants have timely access to ongoing support and care.

questions.text: A 2-day-old newborn has an episode of seizure and has signs of microcephaly and chorioretinitis.CT scan revealed intracerebral calcification. What is the nature of the infective organism in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of seizures, chorioretinitis and intracerebral calcifications is suggestive of congenital cytomegalovirus(CMV) infection.CMV has a double-stranded DNA in its structure.

Congenital CMV presents with hepatosplenomegaly, petechial rashes, jaundice, chorioretinitis, and microcephaly. Head neuroimaging shows intracranial periventricular calcifications. One of the long-term sequelae is sensorineural hearing loss. Diagnosis is made by isolating the virus from the urine or blood by polymerase chain reaction (PCR).

CMV is the largest virus in the herpes family of viruses. All the herpes family viruses are enveloped, have icosahedral symmetry and have linear double-stranded DNA. It causes mononucleosis-like illness in children and adults and severe fatal reactions in immunocompromised hosts. Other members of the Herpes family include herpes simplex type 1 and 2, varicella-zoster virus (VZV), Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), Human Bcell lymphotropic virus, RK virus and Human herpes virus-8.

The image given below shows periventricular calcifications seen in congenital CMV infection.

Other options:

Option A: ssDNA(single-stranded) is present in parvovirus. This causes erythema infectiosum(fifth disease), pure red cell aplasia, aplastic crisis and hydrops fetalis.

Option B and D: ssRNA (single-stranded RNA) is present in all the RNA viruses except reoviridae family. Reoviridae which includes human rotavirus has double-stranded RNA (dsRNA) in its structure and is the most common identifiable viral cause of  in children below the age of 5 years and is most frequent between 6-24 months of age.

questions.text: A young woman comes to the Suraksha clinic of the local primary health center. She is examined and the white kit is prescribed to her as treatment. Which of the following symptoms did the patient most likely present with?
questions.solution:
The patient most likely presented with a non-herpetic genital ulcer. 

Kit 3/ White Kit is used to treat patients with a non-herpetic genital ulcer.

All the partners in the last 3 months must be treated.

Contents and course:

Inj. Benzathine penicillin 2.4 MU stat +/ Tab. Azithromycin 1g stat.

questions.text: A new mother presenting with fever, chills, and severe pain in her left breast is diagnosed with acute mastitis. She is prescribed dicloxacillin. What advice will you give her about breastfeeding?

choices.text: Switch to formula feeds until the symptoms subside
Continue feeding only from uninfected breast
Continue feeding after completing antibiotic course

questions.solution:
Patients diagnosed with acute mastitis are prescribed antibiotics (dicloxacillin) and advised to continue normal breastfeeding.

Mastitis refers to the infection of the breast parenchymal tissue. The most common organisms implicated are Staphylococcus aureus, Staphylococcus epidermidis, and Streptococcus viridans.  It occurs commonly in new mothers who are inexperienced with breastfeeding. Poor nursing and cracked nipples are important risk factors. 

It presents with unilateral breast pain and tenderness. Associated features include fever with chills, fatigue, and headache. On examination, the breast is erythematous, hot on palpation, tense, and very tender. 

Management involves supportive measures and antibiotics. Dicloxacillin is the antibiotic of choice. The reported level of dicloxacillin in breast milk is very low and does not cause any adverse effects in infants. Supportive measures include analgesics for pain, breast support, hydration, and continued breastfeeding. 

Women with acute mastitis are recommended to continue breastfeeding with good attachment or use a breast pump to prevent milk stasis. This is done to prevent the progression of the infection which may result in the development of breast abscess. Patients are advised to begin nursing on the uninfected side to allow milk let-down before moving on to the tender, affected side. Continued breastfeeding poses no additional risks to the infant.

questions.text: A 60-year-old obese woman presents with upper right abdominal pain. The pain is dull and associated with fatty food ingestion. A CT scan was done which is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and CT scan showing calcification in the gall bladder wall is suggestive of a porcelain gallbladder.

Porcelain gallbladder refers to dystrophic calcification of the gallbladder wall. The mechanism behind its pathophysiology is thought to be the same as that of gallstone formation.

It has a 5:1 preponderance in women when compared to men. Age > 60 years and obesity are risk factors for this condition. Symptoms are similar to chronic cholecystitis. 

Diagnosis can be made by X-ray or CT scan. Abdominal ultrasound and MRI can also help in the diagnosis. 

It is considered a premalignant lesion for gallbladder carcinoma. Hence, treatment is advised in all cases with laparoscopic cholecystectomy. 

Option A: On USG, a gallbladder polyp is fixed, and does not cast any acoustic shadow. A polyp is more of an incidental finding and is often asymptomatic

Option D: In cholelithiasis, the gallstones appear as echogenic foci, which cast an acoustic shadow on USG. Stone mobility may be demonstrated if it is not impacted.

Option C: In emphysematous cholecystitis, intraluminal gas appears as a bright curvilinear echogenic band with ‘dirty’ shadowing. CT scan shows gas within the wall of the gallbladder (shown below).

questions.text: The given image is a histological section of which of the following organ?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a histological section of the epithelium of the urinary bladder also known as transitional epithelium (urothelium).

Urothelium has 4 -6 layers of thickness of cells extending from the collecting duct of the kidney to the ejaculatory duct in males and to the urogenital membrane in females. It is named transitional epithelium as it apparently changed from a stratified cuboidal epithelium to stratified squamous epithelium. It has 3 distinctive layers as follows:

  • Basal layer made of cuboidal cells which can regenerate.
  • Intermediate layer made of polygonal cells responsible for the stretch of the organ by flattening of cells.
  • Superficial layer made of umbrella-shaped multinucleated cells which are protective and impermeable.

Related Pearl: Various Types of Epithelium, Their Location and Functions

questions.text: Which of the following conditions present with Horner Trantas dots?
questions.solution:
Horner Trantas dots are seen in vernal keratoconjunctivitis. They appear as white dots at the limbus of the cornea. These white dots contain eosinophils and epithelial cellular debris.

Other options:

  • Phlyctenular keratoconjunctivitis: 
    • Type 4 hypersensitivity reaction 
    • Due to endogenous allergens like Staphylococcus aureus (most common) and Mycobacterium tuberculosis
    • Characterized by the following:
      • Phlycten
      • May eventually form ring ulcers
      • Scrofulous ulcer: shallow marginal ulcer due to the breakdown of limbal phlycten
      • Fascicular ulcer: It has a prominent parallel leash of blood vessels. It heals leaving a band-shaped opacity.
  • Giant papillary conjunctivitis:
    • The severe form of mechanically induced papillary conjunctivitis is known as giant papillary conjunctivitis (GPC).
    • It is most frequently encountered with contact lens (CL) wear; in such cases, it is termed contact lens-associated papillary conjunctivitis (CLPC). 
    • It may be caused by ocular prostheses, exposed sutures, and scleral buckles, corneal surface irregularity, or filtering blebs.
  • Lyell syndrome: It is a form of toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN)

questions.text: A child presents to the OPD with the following findings along with generalised depigmentation of the skin. All are true regarding her condition except ?

choices.text: The number of melanocytes are reduced
Pigmentation  increases  with increase in age
Patients usually have reduced visual acuity
It is due to defective melanin biosynthesis

questions.solution:
The above image depicts a depigmented white iris along with the history of generalised depigmentation points towards the diagnosis of oculocutaneous albinism. The total number and distribution of melanocytes remain the same in OCA.

Oculocutaneous albinism (OCA) is a group of inherited disorders characterized by a reduction or complete lack of melanin pigment in the skin, hair, and eyes leading to hypopigmentation. It is  due to defective melanosome biosynthesis or defective protein involved in the formation and transfer of melanin. However the number and distribution of melanocytes are normal. There is an increased sensitivity to UV radiation due to decreased melanin and hence a strong predisposition to skin cancer ( option D ).

There are 7 types of nonsyndromic albinism (OCA1 to OCA7). In some tyrosine positive types pigmentation can increase as the age increases ( Option B) whereas in severe OCA there is complete lack of pigmentation with lack of tendency to tan.

Clinical features include white hair, white skin, and iris appearing blue-grey in oblique light. Ocular manifestations include photophobia, nystagmus, and decreased visual acuity(Option C)

Sun protection and corrective lenses are a general line of management. Surgery for strabismus and dark glasses for photophobia are also important.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male with type 1 diabetes presents with complaints of nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain. He appears dehydrated. Blood tests reveal hyperglycemia and high anion gap metabolic acidosis. Which of the following tests would be most preferred to estimate ketone levels in this condition?
questions.solution:
This is a clinical vignette of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA). In patients with DKA, serum or plasma assays for β-hydroxybutyrate (BOHB) are preferred as they more accurately reflect the true ketone body level.

DKA is a serious complication of type 1 diabetes characterized by hyperglycemia, ketonemia, and high anion gap metabolic acidosis. BOHB is the most abundant ketone body produced during DKA, compared to acetoacetate and acetone.

Serum BOHB measurement provides a more accurate assessment of ketone levels than urine ketone testing or serum acetone levels. It is also useful in monitoring DKA. During the resolution of DKA, the levels of BOHB decrease, and acetoacetate increases, as BOHB is converted to acetoacetate for utilization by peripheral tissues.

Other options: 

Options A and B: Urine ketone testing is unreliable in the diagnosis of DKA for many reasons. They are nonspecific as they are also seen in normal individuals in conditions such as fasting, excessive ethanol use, and during pregnancy. Furthermore, urine ketone body tests rely on the nitroprusside reaction which does not detect BOHB. Patients can have also false positives due to certain drugs, and false negatives if ketones are below the level of detectability or if samples are exposed to air.

Option D: In normal conditions, the levels of BOHB and acetoacetate are equal. However, in DKA the levels are vastly shifted in favor of BOHB production compared to acetoacetate. Hence, measuring serum acetoacetate may underestimate the true level of ketonemia.

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 30 weeks of gestation presented with bleeding per vagina. A sample of the PV bleed is obtained and an Apt test is performed, which is positive. What is the most probable cause of bleeding in this patient?
questions.solution:
Apt test is an alkali denaturation test to detect fetal hemoglobin (HbF). A positive Apt test suggests it is fetal blood. Among the given conditions, vasa previa is the one that would contain blood of fetal origin and therefore, the most likely cause of bleeding in this case. 

Apt test is based on the principle that HbF is resistant to alkali denaturation, while HbA is not. The test is performed by collecting the blood sample in a test tube containing water and adding NaOH. Maternal blood turns yellow-brown, while fetal blood remains pink in the test tube.

Vasa previa is a condition in which umbilical vessels run across the cervical os. This makes them vulnerable to bleeding due to pressure from the presenting part of the fetus or during the rupture of membranes.

Color flow Doppler can be used for diagnosis. If diagnosed before bleeding occurs, the patient can be managed by elective C-section before the onset of labor. Bleeding leads to fetal exsanguination and must be managed immediately with an emergency C-section. 

Other options: Bleeding due to abruptio placenta, cervical polyp, and placenta previa is of maternal origin. Hence, the Apt test will be negative in these cases.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female came to the physician after an episode of hemoptysis. Over the past 4 months, she has had non-productive cough, fatigue, and a 6 kg weight loss. She does not smoke. X-ray chest shows a 2.8 cm nodule with irregular borders in the left lung. CT findings are shown. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a female patient, who is a non-smoker, presenting after an episode of hemoptysis, and associated history of non-productive cough, fatigue, and 6 kg weight loss suggests lung carcinoma. CT scan showing an irregular lesion at the periphery of the lung with no hilar lymphadenopathy is suggestive of adenocarcinoma. 

Adenocarcinoma is the most common tumor of the lung in non-smokers. It is more common in women. Adenocarcinoma of the lung occurs in the periphery of the lung, frequently in areas of chronic scarring caused by chronic inflammatory changes. EGFR oncogene mutations are common in adenocarcinomas of non-smokers.

Clinical features include cough, chest pain, hemoptysis, and symptoms due to metastasis. Some are responsible for paraneoplastic syndromes.

Lung adenocarcinomas are now classified by their predominant pattern:

  • Lepidic pattern (best prognosis; tumors ≤3 cm or with ≤5 mm invasion has near 100% 5-year disease-free survival with complete tumor resection)
  • Acinar pattern
  • Papillary pattern
  • Solid patterns (poor prognosis)

Lung nodules should always be compared with previous films. A CT scan is done for further evaluation and a biopsy is done to confirm the diagnosis.

Other Options:

Option A: Squamous cell cancer most commonly occurs in smokers and is typically centrally located.

Option B: Small cell cancer is a highly aggressive cancer that metastasizes early. It is also often associated with smoking and is generally metastasized by the time it gets diagnosed.

Option D: Sarcoidosis can present with weight loss and non-productive cough. However, there is associated hilar lymphadenopathy, which is absent in this patient.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient presents with recurrent episodes of dizziness and syncope. The patient's ECG is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis based on the ECG findings?
questions.solution:
The ECG shows alternating periods of sinus tachycardia followed by sinus bradycardia, which is characteristic of tachy-brady syndrome. In this ECG, the initial tachycardia is followed by a long offset pause and a junctional escape rhythm.

Tachy-brady syndrome, is a subset of sick sinus syndrome. This syndrome typically presents with symptoms such as dizziness, syncope, and palpitations due to dysfunction of the sinoatrial node, resulting in episodes of tachycardia and bradycardia. 

In this condition, tachycardia is most commonly due to atrial fibrillation (but it is not always present) with alternating symptomatic bradycardia and offset pauses. The presence of tachy-brady syndrome is an indication for pacemaker placement.

Other options: 

Option A: Brugada syndrome refers to a sodium channelopathy with a high risk of arrhythmias that can lead to sudden cardiac death. The ECG abnormality that is potentially diagnostic is a coved ST-segment elevation by >0.2 mV followed by a negative T wave in more than one anterior precordial lead (V1-V3). This has been referred to as the Brugada sign.

Option C: Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome is a congenital condition involving the presence of an abnormal accessory electrical conduction pathway called the Bundle of Kent between the atria & ventricles. ECG shows a short P-R interval <120 ms and a slurred initial upstroke of QRS complex referred to as the delta wave.

Option D: Romano-Ward syndrome is a cause of congenital long QT syndrome.

questions.text:
An unconscious man without any ID on him is brought to the casualty by bystanders after an RTA. His blood pressure is 80/60 mmHg. USG abdomen reveals a ruptured spleen. He is shifted for surgery without obtaining consent. What is the medico-legal justification for this course of action called?

ID - Identity document
RTA - Road traffic accident
questions.solution:
The medico-legal justification for this course of action is the doctrine of implied consent.

According to IPC section 92, if a patient is unconscious and there is an imminent danger to the life of the patient and there is no designated relative or the relative is unavailable, then consent is deemed to have been given. This is called the doctrine of implied consent. However, for this doctrine to be applicable, the patient must require emergency treatment to save life or limb. This doctrine is not applicable in a non-emergency or after the emergency has been handled adequately.

Other options:

Option A: Res ipsa loquitur means 'the thing speaks for itself'. It is used as supportive evidence of negligence on the part of the doctor. Say leaving behind a scalpel or scissors whilst operating leading to sepsis/peritonitis speaks for itself.

Option C: A competent person who is aware of being entitled to informed consent may give up the right to give consent, if he so wishes. This is called a therapeutic waiver.

Option D: If full disclosure is disadvantageous to the patient (e.g. in patients with anxiety), then the doctor can withhold certain information from the patient. However, he should disclose the full information to a competent relative of the patient. This is called therapeutic privilege.

questions.text: A 31-year-old  G3P2 female presents with 12 weeks of amenorrhea. The urine pregnancy test is positive and beta HCG levels are >1 lac mIU/ML. The uterus size is larger than expected for her LMP. Her ultrasound finding is shown below. Which of the following can be most likely seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features, beta HCG levels >1 lac mIU/ml, the uterus size and the ultrasound finding of snow storm appearance suggest a diagnosis of a complete mole. Theca lutein cysts are present in half of the women with complete mole. They occur due to the hyperstimulation of ovaries as a result of high levels of HCG in molar pregnancies.  

Theca lutein cysts, usually regress spontaneously in a period of 2 to 4 months following evacuation of a molar pregnancy. Sometimes,  it can undergo torsion and cause marked pelvic pain. In such instances, laparoscopic untwisting of such cyst has to be done.  

Other effects due to increased levels of HCG:

  • Hyperemesis gravidarum
  • Hyperthyroidism

The preferred treatment would be molar evacuation by suction and curettage.

Preoperative cervical dilatation with an osmotic agent is recommended if the cervix is minimally dilated. Intraoperative sonography is recommended to help ensure that the uterine cavity has been emptied. With large moles, adequate anesthesia, sufficient intravenous access, and blood-banking support is imperative.

Indication for hysterectomy in molar pregnancy:

  • Preferred for women who have completed their family.
  • In women >40 years, who are at high risk for GTN
  • Note: Anti D immunoglobulin to be given to Rh negative women. Dose is 50 micrograms in first trimester and 300 micrograms when gestational age is more than 12 weeks.

Hydatidiform mole is a benign abnormal condition of the placenta characterized by partial degenerative or proliferative changes of the chorionic villi. Though benign, it has malignant potential. It is commonly seen in pregnancies of extreme reproductive age groups - teenage and women above 35 years of age. A previous history of molar pregnancy is also a strong risk factor for recurrence of this condition.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presented with post-menopausal bleeding. To rule out endometrial carcinoma, she underwent a diagnostic procedure that was performed using Hegar's dilator and Sim's curette. This procedure is also done for which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The above-mentioned procedure performed in a patient with post-menopausal bleeding using Hegar's dilator and Sims's curette is dilatation and curettage (D&C). Another indication for this procedure is abnormal uterine bleeding.

D&C is a minor gynecological procedure where the cervix is dilated and endometrial tissue is curetted (scraped) from the uterine cavity. It is used as both a diagnostic and therapeutic measure. It is indicated in many conditions, including: 

  • Abnormal uterine bleeding to study the hormonal pattern that is causing uterine bleeding
  • Post menopausal bleeding to rule out endometrial cancer
  • To rule out endometrial hyperplasia and cancer in a patient on tamoxifen for breast cancer
  • Endometrial cancer to decide stage and treatment modality
  • Secondary amenorrhea to look for tubercular endometritis

Therapeutic indications include removing endometrial polyps, medical termination of pregnancy, and evacuation of missed/incomplete abortion.

The image below shows various instruments used in D&C.


Other options:

Option B: Endometriosis is a condition where there is ectopic benign endometrial tissue outside of the uterine cavity. It is better diagnosed by laparoscopy (gold standard), CA-125 measurement, and ultrasound.

Option C: D&C is contraindicated in pelvic inflammatory disease.

Option D: Cervical carcinoma, in cases where they are suspected or confirmed,  D&C is not the preferred procedure. 

Related Pearl: Instruments in OBG

questions.text:
A patient diagnosed with XDR TB is started on a newer anti-TB drug that inhibits bacterial mycolic acid and protein synthesis under aerobic conditions. Identify the likely drug.

XDR - extensively drug-resistant
TB - tuberculosis
questions.solution:
A newer anti-TB drug that inhibits bacterial mycolic acid and protein synthesis under aerobic conditions is pretomanid. 

Pretomanid is a bicyclic nitroimidazole that has been approved for the management of XDR TB. The drug has two mechanisms of action. Under aerobic conditions, it inhibits bacterial mycolic acid and protein synthesis. Additionally, in non-replicating bacteria, pretomanid generates reactive nitrogen species to aid in the killing of intracellular, persistent bacilli. 

Pretomanid is administered at a dose of 200 mg once daily and is used in combination with bedaquiline and linezolid for the management of MDR and XDR TB.
 
Other options:
 
Option A: Bedaquiline is another newer anti-TB drug that acts by blocking mycobacterial ATP synthase. It inhibits bacillary energy metabolism and is used in the management of MDR and XDR TB.
 
Option B: Delamanid is also a newer bicyclic nitroimidazole like pretomanid. However, it acts by only inhibiting bacterial mycolic acid production. It is used in the management of MDR TB.
 
Option C: Ethionamide is an older anti-TB drug. It also acts by inhibition of mycolic acid synthesis. It is a second-line drug that can be used for some cases of drug-resistant TB.

questions.text: A veterinarian presents with symptoms of myalgia, fatigue and low-grade fever for the past 10 days. On examination, he had non-tender cervical lymphadenopathy. Sabin-Feldman dye test was positive. Identify the parasite responsible for these findings in the patient.
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a veterinarian presenting with myalgia, fatigue and low-grade fever, cervical lymphadenopathy, and a positive Sabin Feldman dye test is indicative of toxoplasmosis caused by Toxoplasma gondii.

Toxoplasma gondii is an obligate intracellular coccidian parasite and is the causative agent of toxoplasmosis. Its definitive hosts are cats and other felines while humans are intermediate hosts.

The life cycle of toxoplasma gondii is shown below.

Humans acquire the infection upon consumption of meat containing tissue cysts, food or water containing mature oocysts, or fingers contaminated by cat feces.

Infection can also be transmitted from the mother to the fetus or from an infected donor to the recipient subsequent to a blood transfusion or organ transplantation.

Manifestations are mostly asymptomatic and if symptomatic can be congenital or acquired. Features such as fever, headache, myalgia, splenomegaly, and lymphade­nopathy commonly affect the cervical lymph nodes.

Central nervous system involvement is observed in toxoplasma infection affecting immunocompromised individuals. Toxoplasma infection in pregnancy can lead to congenital toxoplasmosis that most frequently presents with chorioretinitis. Chorioretinitis can also present in ocular toxoplasmosis.

Trophozoites and tissue cysts can be detected in tissue and body fluids. The tachyzoites appear as crescent-shaped structures with blue cytoplasm and dark nucleus. 

The Sabin Feldman dye test is a serological test done for the detection of IgG antibodies against toxoplasma. It is based on the presence of antibodies that lyse the parasite membrane and hence prevent methylene blue dye from staining the cytoplasm of trophozoites (tachyzoites). If there are no antibodies, trophozoites with an intact membrane are stained and appear blue under the microscope, indicative of a negative result.

A false-positive test is seen in infection with Sarcocystis, Trichomonas vaginalis, and Trypanosoma Lewisi. Other tests done include indirect fluorescent antibody test, latex agglutination test, and ELISA, the latter of which can measure circulating IgG antibodies to Toxoplasma.

MRI and CT are used to diagnose toxoplasmosis with CNS involvement.

Other options:

Option A: In Leishmania infection, Montenegro test/Leishmanin test is positive. It is a skin test based on delayed hypersensitivity to an antigen derived from cultured Leishmania. Features include high-grade fever, splenomegaly, hepatomegaly, and lymphadenopathy.

Option B: In Echinococcus infection, Casoni’s test is done. It is a skin test based on immediate hypersensitivity to an antigen derived from hydatid fluid. It is positive in hydatid disease. The typical features are hepatomegaly, pain, and obstructive jaundice. If lungs are involved, cough and hemoptysis can be present.

Option C: Is Schistosoma infection, Fairley's test is done. It is a skin test that is group-specific to all schistosomiasis. Manifestations include skin rash, anaphylaxis in acute stages. It can be associated with bladder carcinoma and infections in chronic stages.
