questions.text:
A 40-year-old woman complains of shortness of breath and chronic dry cough for the past few months. She has no history of fever, weight loss, or night sweats and she is a non-smoker. Examination reveals erythema nodosum. Laboratory investigations show hypercalcemia. Her chest X-ray is shown below. What is the primary mechanism of hypercalcemia in this condition?

FGF23: Fibroblast growth factor-23
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is that of sarcoidosis, characterized by lung involvement (chronic dry cough, shortness of breath, bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy on chest X-ray), erythema nodosum, and hypercalcemia. The primary mechanism of hypercalcemia in sarcoidosis is increased production of 1,25-dihydroxy vitamin D.

Sarcoidosis is a multisystemic inflammatory disease characterized by the presence of noncaseating granulomas. These granulomas express 1-alpha hydroxylase that converts 25-hydroxyvitamin D to 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D, leading to increased intestinal absorption of calcium which results in hypercalcemia.

The lungs are most commonly affected in sarcoidosis, and the patients commonly present with cough and dyspnea. The involvement of the right paratracheal, right hilar, and left hilar lymph nodes leads to a characteristic pattern of lymph node enlargement known as the Garland triad, 1-2-3 sign, or pawnbroker's sign. 

Other options: 

Option A: While hypercalcemia can result from increased bone resorption in conditions like primary hyperparathyroidism, it is not the primary mechanism in sarcoidosis-associated hypercalcemia.

Option B: Fibroblast growth factor 23 (FGF23) plays a role in phosphate homeostasis and is associated with conditions like tumor-induced osteomalacia, but it is not implicated in sarcoidosis-related hypercalcemia.

Option C: Increased parathyroid hormone secretion leads to hypercalcemia in primary hyperparathyroidism.

questions.text: A 7-month-old child is brought by his parents with the following lesions for one week. On examination, Darier's sign is positive. Lesions are not seen in the palms, soles and face. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis in this patient with positive Darier's sign and reddish‐brown maculopapular lesions on the trunk is urticaria pigmentosa. 

Urticaria pigmentosa is the most common type of cutaneous mastocytosis. It occurs due to an increased number of mast cells in the skin. The symptoms occur due to the release of mast cell-derived mediators. The age of onset is in the first year in the childhood type and 20–40 years in the adult type.

It presents with numerous reddish‐brown or pale monomorphic maculopapules, plaques, or nodules in a symmetrical distribution. Lesions can occur anywhere but are common over the trunk and thighs. The palms and soles are usually spared. Even though the neck and the hairline can be affected, the face is usually spared. It can also present with bullous lesions that heal without scarring.

Other features :

  • Flushing
  • Pruritus
  • Heat or cold intolerance
  • Recurrent diarrhea
  • Dyspepsia
  • Depression
  • Headache

Darier's sign is seen in urticaria pigmentosa. It refers to the development of urticaria and erythema around the lesions after mild trauma, including scratching or rubbing of the lesion. Darier's sign is not specific to mastocytosis as it is also rarely seen in juvenile xanthogranuloma and acute lymphoblastic leukemia.


Treatment of urticaria pigmentosa includes: 

  • Avoiding physical stimuli that trigger mast cell degranulation- temperature extremes, pressure, alcohol
  • Antihistamines
  • Mast cell stabilizers
  • Topical and oral corticosteroids
  • PUVA (Psoralen + ultraviolet light A) therapy
  • Tyrosine kinase inhibitors like imatinib.

Other options:

Option A: Café‐au‐lait macules (CALMs), also called Café‐au‐lait spots, present as well-circumscribed, hyperpigmented, light brown to dark brown macules and patches that range in size. They may appear at birth or in the first decade. They may be present on any body part, but most commonly involve the trunk and the extremities. They are associated with several genetic syndromes such as neurofibromatosis (NF1).

The image below shows Café‐au‐lait spots:


Option B: Tinea corporis is fungal infection of glabrous skin. It includes lesions of the trunk and limbs, excluding ringworms of specialized sites such as the scalp, feet, and groins. Characteristic lesions are circular, usually sharply marginated with a raised edge. 

The image below shows itchy,pink-to-red, round patches with raised scaly borders that tend to be clear in the center of tinea corporis:


Option D: Chronic bullous dermatosis (linear Ig A Dermatosis) of childhood is an autoimmune blistering disease in infants and children. The disease can also be seen in adults and is known as Linear IgA disease of adults or IgA bullous pemphigoid.

It presents as tense blisters and vesicles urticated plaques with erythema. They are arranged annularly in a “crown of jewels” formation. Varying degrees of pruritis may be present. The most common sites are the perioral area and perineum, followed by the trunk and limbs.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presenting with longstanding bloody diarrhea and abdominal pain was diagnosed with inflammatory bowel disease. He was prescribed sulfasalazine. Which of the following side effects is specifically seen with this drug?
questions.solution:
Reversible oligospermia is a side effect of sulfasalazine. 

Sulfasalazine is a prodrug and its active form is 5-ASA (5-Aminosalicylic acid), which has an anti-inflammatory activity in the bowel. The sulfapyridine moiety, however, is responsible for most of the side effects like nausea, vomiting, headache, malaise, and oligozoospermia. Sulfasalazine also interferes with folate absorption.

The other drugs used in the management of in management of inflammatory bowel disease include mesalazine, corticosteroids, azathioprine, methotrexate, TNF alpha inhibitors and cyclosporin.

Other options :

a) Mucositis and diarrhoea are the common side effects of methotrexate, which is a dihydrofolate reductase inhibitor.

c) Nephrotoxicity is a side effect seen with mesalazine.

d) Flare up of tuberculosis is a complication associated with the use of TNF antagonists like infliximab.

questions.text: Which of the following is a correct inference from the following graph?
questions.solution:
The graph shown is a box and whisker plot, and option B represents the correct answer. 

A box and whisker plot is a method for graphically depicting groups of numerical data through their quartiles. The lines extending vertically from the boxes are known as whiskers and indicate variability outside the upper and lower quartiles.

It shows the five-number summary of a set of data including:

  • Minimum score
  • First (lower) quartile
  • Median
  • Third (upper) quartile and
  • Maximum score

 

In the box plot, a simple box extends from the 25th percentile (lower limit of the box) to the 75th percentile (upper limit of the box) and the line through the box indicates the median value (50th percentile). 

The top and bottom ends of the whiskers are the highest and lowest value of that group excluding outliers.

Interpreting the box plot:

  • When the median is in the middle of the box, and the whiskers are about the same on both sides of the box i.e when each quartile is of the same length, then the distribution is symmetric or normal (as shown in box plot-1).
  • When the median is closer to the bottom of the box, and if the whisker is shorter on the lower end of the box, then the distribution is positively skewed (skewed right as shown in boxplot-2).
  • When the median is closer to the top of the box, and if the whisker is shorter on the upper end of the box, then the distribution is negatively skewed (skewed left as shown in boxplot-3).
  • Small circles or unfilled dots are drawn on the chart to indicate where suspected outliers lie. Filled circles are used for known outliers (as shown in boxplot-4 ).

Related Pearl: Box and Whisker Plot

  • A box and whisker plot is used to show variation in a set of data.
  • They can summarize data from various sources and display it in a single graph.
  • A box and whisker plot is usually based on median, quartiles and percentiles.
  • It is also called a box plot.
  • In the box plot as shown in the image, a simple box is divided into two by the median value. Above and below it are the whiskers. The top and bottom ends of the whiskers are the highest and lowest value of that group. 
  • A box plot can help in identifying outliers and the interquartile range (IQR), as shown in the image below.

Related Pearl: Mean, Median, Mode in Different Distribution Shapes

  • The relationship between the mean, median and mode depends upon the distribution.
  • In a unimodal symmetrical distribution like a normal distribution, all the three measures are approximately the same, as shown in Figure (2) in the following image, i.e., mean = median = mode.
  • Figure (3) in the following image shows a positively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the positive direction. In this, the mean will be larger than the median and mode, i.e., mean > median > mode.
  • Figure (1) in the following image shows a negatively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the negative direction. In this, the mean will be smaller than the median, i.e., mean < median < mode.

Unimodal symmetrical distribution

Mean = Median = Mode

Positively (right) skewed distribution

Mean > Median > Mode

Negatively (left) skewed distribution

Mean < Median < Mode
  • As seen in the figures above, in any distribution curve, the mode is generally the highest point. The mean will be pulled up or down based on the values in the distribution. The median will lie between the mode and mean and divide the distribution in two equal halves under the curve.
  • A bimodal distribution will have two high points as shown in the image below.
  • Mathematically, the relationship between mode, median and mean in asymmetrical distributions can be given as:
    Mode = 3 median – 2 mean (or) Mean = ½ (3 median – mode).
  • Outlier is the statistical term used for an observation or value that is very distant from other observations in the distribution.
  • In a distribution with outliers, preferred measure of central tendency is the median.
  • Mode is least affected by outliers but mean is the most affected out of all the measures of location.

questions.text: A 45-year-old known diabetic patient presents with carpal tunnel syndrome. Which muscle is likely to be affected/ paralyzed?
questions.solution:
The muscle that is likely to be affected/paralyzed is opponens pollicis (Option D).

Carpal tunnel syndrome refers to the entrapment of the median nerve under the carpal tunnel either due to swelling or due to peripheral neuropathy. Examples include type 1 and 2 diabetes, hypothyroidism, rheumatoid arthritis, pregnancy and during menopause. 

The median nerve supplies the lateral two lumbricals(1st and 2nd) and thenar muscles which include abductor pollicis brevis, flexor pollicis brevis, and opponens pollicis.(Option D)Cutaneous nerve supply of the median nerve at hand is over the lateral 3 1/2  digits and their nail beds.Paralysis of the thenar muscles presents as ape or monkey-like thumb deformity.

Ulnar nerve supplies all other intrinsic muscles of the hand such as palmar interossei, dorsal interossei, 3rd and 4th lumbricals, all the hypothenar muscles- abductor digiti minimi muscle, the flexor digiti minimi brevis muscle, the opponens digiti minimi muscle, and the palmaris brevis muscle and ends its course in the hand by supplying the adductor pollicis. In fact, the adductor pollicis is known as the graveyard of the ulnar nerve. (Option A,B, and C).

questions.text: A patient with acoustic neuroma is being evaluated for the involvement of other cranial nerves. Which of the following regions of the external auditory canal will show hypoaesthesia due to facial nerve compression?
questions.solution:
Compression of the facial nerve due to acoustic neuroma will result in hypoesthesia of the posterior wall of the external auditory canal (region 2 in the given image). This is called the Hitzelberger sign.

The external auditory canal is supplied by 3 different nerves, as depicted in the image below :

  • Anterior wall and roof (regions 1 & 3): auriculotemporal nerve
  • Posterior wall & floor (region 4): auricular branch of the vagus
  • Posterior wall (region 2): facial nerve, auricular branch of the vagus


Acoustic neuroma is also called vestibular schwannoma or the eighth nerve tumor. It arises from the Schwann cells of the vestibular nerve. It is a cerebellopontine angle tumor and is associated with neurofibromatosis 2.

Clinically, patients typically present with progressive unilateral sensorineural hearing loss with tinnitus. Involvement of cranial nerves results in the following symptoms:

  • Trigeminal nerve: reduced corneal sensitivity, numbness, or paraesthesia of the face
  • Facial nerve: hypoaesthesia of the posterior meatal wall called Hitzelberger’s sign
  • Glossopharyngeal and vagus nerve: Dysphagia and hoarseness

questions.text: What is the finding shown in the given image, and in which race is this feature most commonly seen?
questions.solution:
The image shows small nodules on the lingual surface of maxillary molars. These are called Carabelli’s cusps. They are most commonly seen in people of the Caucasian race. The lateral incisors in the upper jaw are usually smaller than the central incisors. Caucasians also tend to have long, pointed canine roots. 

In bull-teeth or ‘taurodontism’, the pulp cavity of the molars is wide and deep, and the roots are fused and bent. A congenital lack of the third upper molar is most common in Mongoloids. In Mongoloid teeth, enamel pearls, small nodules of enamel on the tooth surface, are much more frequent. 

Other features of Mongoloid dentition:

  • Shovel-shaped upper central incisors - Posterior surfaces of these teeth have a depression centrally
  • Enamel pearls - Small nodules of enamel on the tooth surface
  • Wide and deep pulp cavity of the molars - bull-teeth or ‘taurodontism’
  • Congenital lack of the third upper molar - a common but nonspecific feature

Negroid races tend to have large teeth and often have more cusps on their molars, even up to eight, with two lingual cusps on the mandibular first premolars as an additional common finding.

Aboriginal races tend to have large teeth with wide crowns. They do not show taurodontism.

questions.text: A biochemist performed electrophoresis on lipoproteins during a study and has obtained results as shown below. The marked lipoprotein which has hardly moved from the origin is likely to be _______.
questions.solution:
The marked lipoprotein which has hardly moved towards the anode during electrophoresis is likely to be chylomicron.

Chylomicron particles have the lowest density and the largest size. They contain the highest percentage of lipids and the lowest percentage of protein.

questions.text: In a postoperative ward, 4 out of 10 patients developed wound discharge, which on culture and antibiotic susceptibility was found to be positive for coagulase-positive, gram-positive cocci, resistant to Methicillin. Which of the following is true regarding the causative agent?

choices.text: Major route of spread  is air borne
Alteration in its penicillin binding proteins is found
Sensitive to amoxicillin + clavulanic acid combination

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of infections occurring in the post-operative ward and the culture and antibiotic susceptibility report suggest methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) infection. Alteration in its penicillin-binding proteins is found in MRSA.

Staphylococci are gram-positive cocci arranged characteristically in grape-like clusters. They are uniformly resistant to lysozymes. 

They exhibit various types of resistance to antibiotics by beta-lactamase production and alteration in penicillin-binding protein PBP2a. 

Beta-lactamase or penicillinase-producing strains inactivate penicillin by splitting the beta-lactam ring. The beta-lactamase enzyme is plasmid-mediated. However, they are susceptible to penicillinase-resistant penicillins such as methicillin and cloxacillin. This can be transmitted by transduction or conjugation. 

Alteration of PBP2a leads to changes in surface binding of beta-lactam antibiotics on bacteria resulting in resistance to all beta-lactam antibiotics and is termed methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). The mechanism of resistance of MRSA is due to chromosomally mediated Mec A gene which codes for altered PBP2a (Penicillin Binding Protein or receptor 2a) which has less affinity for beta-lactam drugs.

Other options:

Option A: The major route of spread causing the outbreak is direct contact through the contaminated hands of hospital staff or direct contact with an infected wound.

Option B: The resistance to Methicillin is chromosomally mediated.

Option D: Since MRSA-coded altered PBP 2a (Penicillin Binding protein 2a) has less affinity for lactam drugs, MRSA strains are resistant to all beta-lactam drugs. Even a combination of β lactam and β lactamase inhibitor will not work.

Related Pearl: Methicillin-Resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA)

MRSA Definition: Methicillin MIC 8 μg/ml or more, Oxacillin MIC 4 μg/ml or more.

Resistance in MRSA is mediated by mecA gene which is chromosomally coded. It alters PBP (penicillin-binding protein) present on S.aureus cell wall to PBP-2a which has less affinity for beta-lactam antibiotics.

Penicillin Binding Protein:

  • Normal protein present in all bacterial cell wall.
  • Transpeptidase in nature.
  • Required for cross-linking of the peptidoglycan layer (essential for cell wall synthesis).
  • It is also the site of attachment for- beta-lactam drugs to bind & inhibit.

Types of MRSA:

  • Community-acquired - mediated by mec A subtype IV and Possess PV Toxin(Panton-Valentine Toxin), monodrug resistance,more virulent
  • Hospital-acquired - mediated by mec A subtype I, II, III, multidrug resistance,less virulent.

Detection of MRSA:

  • Antibiotic susceptibility test on Muller Hilton agar (Disk diffusion test) by using Methicillin or Oxacillin disc or cefoxitin disc.
  • PCR for detection of mecA gene.

Treatment:

  • Vancomycin is Drug Of Choice (should be used only if other drugs are resistant ).
  • Others- Teicoplanin, Linezolid, streptogramin, cipro/levofloxacin, cotrimoxazole, clindamycin, mupirocin, minocycline.
  • Newer Drugs – Daptomycin, ceftobiprole, tigecycline, oritavancin, dalbavancin, telavancin, delafloxacin.
  • Ceftobiprole and ceftaroline are 5th generation β lactams effective against MRSA.

questions.text: A mother brings her 10-year-old girl to the clinic with concerns regarding the girl's short height. On examination, the child has a short and wide neck, broad chest, and widely spaced nipples. A murmur is heard on auscultation. Which of the following is the most likely congenital heart defect seen in such patients?
questions.solution:
Physical findings of short stature, short and wide neck, broad chest, and widely spaced nipples are strongly suggestive of Turner’s syndrome. Among the given options, the congenital heart defect most likely to be found in patients with Turner’s syndrome is the bicuspid aortic valve.

Turner’s syndrome is characterized by complete or partial monosomy of the X chromosome (45, XO). It is associated with various phenotypic features including cubitus valgus, congenital hip dislocation, and low posterior hairline in addition to the features mentioned above.

Congenital heart defects and renal anomalies are common in such patients. It is also associated with primary amenorrhea and a lack of secondary sexual characteristics. The gonads are generally streaks of fibrous tissue (gonadal dysgenesis). Most patients tend to be of normal intelligence although intellectual disability is seen in a few cases.

Other options:

Option A: Atrial septal defects, ventricular septal defects, and complete atrioventricular canal defects are more common in Down’s syndrome.

Option B: Mitral valve prolapse is more common in connective tissue disorders such as Marfan’s and Ehler-Danlos syndromes.

Option C: Endocardial cushion defects are the most common congenital heart defects present in Down’s syndrome.

questions.text: A male patient was brought to the emergency room following a road traffic accident. He had sustained a pelvic fracture and injured his perineum and is unable to pass urine. On examination, blood was seen at the tip of the meatus and on digital rectal examination, there is a high-riding prostate. What is the likely site of injury?
questions.solution:
The site of injury, in this case, is the membranous urethra.

Membranous urethra rupture is most commonly caused by a pelvic fracture. Pelvic fracture is most commonly caused by road traffic accident. Clinical features include urinary retention, blood at the urethral meatus and on digital rectal examination, there will be a high riding prostate called as vermooten sign . Marked bruising of the penis, scrotum and pubic area is commonly associated.

Urethrogram with water-soluble contrast is used for confirmation of the diagnosis. 

Management is by inserting a suprapubic catheter. If there is an associated bladder rupture, the bladder will not be seen on the ultrasound, and management in such a case is by exploration, repair, and placement of a suprapubic catheter.

Other options:

Option A: Bulbar urethral injury is the most common type of urethral injury. It occurs when there is a blow to the perineum. It occurs commonly due to straddle injury (cycling accidents, loose manhole covers, and gymnasium accidents). Clinical features include perineal bruising, butterfly hematoma, bleeding from urethral meatus, and retention of urine is present.

Option C: Penile urethral injury is a type of distal urethral injury caused due to straddle injury. Clinical features are same as bulbar urethral injury. 

Option D: Urinary bladder rupture can be intraperitoneal or extraperitoneal. Extraperitoneal bladder rupture is the most common. Intraperitoneal bladder rupture is caused by a blow or a fall on the distended bladder. Intraperitoneal bladder rupture manifests as sudden severe pain in the hypogastrium and syncope. Extraperitoneal bladder rupture is caused by blunt trauma or surgical damage.

questions.text: An elderly diabetic lady comes to your OPD for her regular checkup. You notice the following lesion on her chest. Which of the following is most likely to be associated with her condition?
questions.solution:
The given images are of spider angiomas and are seen in liver cirrhosis.

Spider angiomas (also known as spider naevus or spider telangiectasias) consist of a central arteriole, about pin-headed in size from which steadily narrowing capillaries radiate like spider legs. Although the exact cause of spider angiomas is not known, many hypotheses have been put forward. Important among those are direct vasodilatory effects of alcohol, substance P, hyperestrogenism, and inadequate hepatic metabolism of steroid hormones.

Spider nevus is also seen in pregnancy and with the use of estrogen-containing pills, further associating it with a hyperestrogenic state.

Other options: 

Option A: A malar rash ("butterfly" rash) is a characteristic finding in systemic lupus erythematosus. It is photosensitive, raised, erythema on the cheeks and nose. It also can involve the ears, chin, V region of the neck and chest, upper back, and extensor surface of arms. 

Option C: Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) and is used as a chemotherapeutic agent in receptor-positive breast cancer. Cutaneous adverse effects are rarely reported with tamoxifen. Adverse effects of tamoxifen include hot flashes and an increased risk of deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism.

Option D: Cutaneous manifestations of gastric carcinoma include the following: 

Leser Trelet sign (Multiple seborrheic keratoses)

Tripe palms (Hyperkeratosis of the palms)

Acanthosis nigricans

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman complains of amenorrhea and hot flushes for 3 months following pelvic radiotherapy. She had regular menses before the procedure. A urine pregnancy test was negative. Investigations revealed normal prolactin and TSH. FSH was elevated on two occasions. Which of the following findings are consistent with the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of secondary amenorrhea with signs of estrogen deficiency (hot flushes) along with elevated FSH in a woman <40 years is suggestive of premature ovarian failure (POF). Among the given options, low estradiol is consistent with this diagnosis.

Premature ovarian failure or premature menopause is the development of menopause before the age of 40 years. It is diagnosed when at least 2 serum FSH levels are elevated (range of 30 to 40 mIU/l) when measured at least 1 month apart in a woman <40 years. Other findings consistent with POF are:

  • Low estradiol.
  • Elevated FSH/LH ratio 

Normal TSH and normal prolactin rules out other causes of secondary amenorrhea such as thyroid dysfunction and prolactinoma respectively. A urine pregnancy test must also be done on a woman of childbearing age with amenorrhea.

Causes of POF

  • Migration of germ cells from the yolk sac.
  • Germ cell apoptosis.
    • Chromosomal abnormalities
    • Autoimmune diseases - hypothyroidism, Addison's disease, etc
    • Genital TB
    • Smoking
    • Radiation and chemotherapy
    • Hysterectomy
    • Prolonged GnRH therapy
    • Induction of multiple ovulation.

Management:

  • Treatment of cause
  • If not interested in pregnancy:
    • Hormone replacement therapy.
  • If interested in pregnancy:
    • Ovulation induction (if an ovarian reserve is present) or
    • Offer donor eggs for in vitro fertilization.

Other options:

Option B - FSH/LH ratio is elevated in POF.

Option C - Anti-Mullerian hormone levels are decreased in POF.

Option D - DHEAS (dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate) is elevated when an adrenal tumor is a cause of secondary amenorrhea.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male came to OPD with complaints of difficulty in falling asleep.He was prescribed the drug ramelton. What is the mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
Ramelton is an MT1 and MT2 receptor agonist.

Ramelteon is a synthetic analogue of melatonin. There are two melatonin receptors, MT1 and MT2, in the suprachiasmatic nucleus where MT1 receptors promote the sleep onset and MT2 receptors change the timing of the circadian system. Ramelteon acts as an agonist to both MT1 and MT2 receptors and is used in the treatment of sleep-onset insomnia.

Ramelteon is metabolized by the CYP450 enzyme system and should not be taken along with drugs or substances inhibiting CYPA12 enzyme (ciprofloxacin, zileuton, and fluvoxamine) fluconazole (CYP2C9). It should be cautiously used with rifampin, an enzyme inducer. This can lead to decreased function.

Side effects include dizziness, fatigue, somnolence, and an increase in prolactin levels. Ramelteon undergoes extensive first-pass metabolism its bioavailability is less than 2%.

Other drugs used in the management of Insomnia:

  • Benzodiazepines: Facilitate the action of GABA by increasing the frequency of opening of the GABA-mediated chloride channel. Examples include alprazolam, clonazepam, lorazepam, midazolam, oxazepam,temazepam, estazolam.(option A)
  • Barbiturates: Facilitate the action of GABA by increasing the opening duration of GABA GABA-mediated chloride channel. Examples include amobarbital, phenobarbital, butabarbital, and pentobarbital.
  • Orexin antagonist: Blocks orexins, neuropeptides that promote wakefulness. Examples include suvorexant and daridorexant. (option B)
  • 5HT receptor agonist: Affinity for 5HT1A > D2 receptor. Examples include buspirone(option D).
  • Newer hypnotics:  These drugs act like benzodiazepines. Zaleplon, zolpidem, and eszopiclone are the examples.

A patient with ascites comes to your clinic for paracentesis and you decide to use a flank approach to drain the fluid. What is the sequence of layers that you will come across? 1-Transversus abdominis 2-Transversalis fascia 3- Oblique muscles 4- Campers and scarpa fascia

1- Transversus abdominis
2- Transversalis fascia

The correct sequence according to the question would be: Campers and Scarpa fascia - Oblique muscles - Transversus abdominis - Transversalis fascia (4-3-1-2).

questions.text: A 6-month-old baby was brought to the clinic with failure to thrive. On examination,  generalized hypotonia and hepatomegaly were present. A chest X-ray image shows massive cardiomegaly. Microscopy of a muscle biopsy shows vacuolations. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Type II (Pompe's disease) glycogen storage disease is the most probable diagnosis from the above-given clinical scenario.

The clinical symptoms are hypotonia (floppy infant), hepatomegaly, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, and chest X-ray image shows cardiomegaly, which is characteristically seen in Pompe's disease. The muscle biopsy showing vacuoles further aids the diagnosis. 

Pompe disease (glycogen storage disease type II) is due to the deficiency of the enzyme lysosomal acid alpha-glucosidase. The affected child usually dies around the age of 2 years due to heart failure.

The enzyme replacement therapy (ERT) for Pompe disease is the recombinant enzyme a-glucosidase alfa (Myozyme).

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man presenting with exertional chest pain is found to have coronary artery disease. Which of the following would indicate the need for coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG)?

LAD - Left anterior descending artery

choices.text: Two vessel disease with proximal LAD involvement
99% block in left anterior descending artery
Acute plaque rupture after orgin of left circumflex artery

questions.solution:
Two-vessel coronary artery disease with the involvement of the proximal left anterior descending artery (LAD) is an indication for coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG).

The proximal LAD is considered a high-risk location for coronary artery disease due to its critical role in supplying blood to a large portion of the myocardium. 

CABG involves anastomosis of one or both of the internal mammary arteries or a radial artery to the coronary artery distal to the site of obstruction. A venous segment, typically the saphenous vein, is used to create a venous bypass conduit between the aorta and the coronary artery distal to the obstruction in cases of additional obstructions that cannot be bypassed by an artery.

Other options:

Option B and C: Single vessel disease is not included in class I indications of CABG by the American Heart Association.

Option D: Ongoing ischemia (persistent ST elevation) and failure of medical therapy are other indication of CABG, not ongoing arrythmia. 

Related Pearl: Indications for Coronary Artery Bypass Grafting (CABG)

Class I indications for CABG from the American College of Cardiology(ACC) and American Heart Association(AHA).

  • Left main disease
  • Three-vessel disease with or without proximal LAD disease
  • Two vessel disease with proximal LAD disease
  • Survivors of sudden cardiac death with presumed ischemia-mediated VT  

Other indications for CABG include the following:

  • Disabling angina
  • Ongoing ischemia in the setting of a non–ST-segment elevation (MI) that is unresponsive to medical therapy
  • Poor LV function but with viable, nonfunctioning myocardium above the anatomic defect that can be revascularized

questions.text: What is the given instrument used for?

choices.text: To catch galea aponeurotica during craniotomy
To hold the ureter during nephrectomy

questions.solution:
The given instrument is Allis' tissue holding forceps, which is used to catch galea aponeurotica during craniotomy

Allis’ tissue holding forceps is identified by the toothed tips, which are apposing. There is a lock in the proximal part and the distal blades do not appose each other. It is used to hold skin flaps, fasciae, aponeurosis and bladder wall.

Option A - Artery forceps are used to catch bleeding points. The distal blades have transverse serrations which are well apposed, and there is a lock in the proximal part. They are also used to open the fascial planes, pass a ligature and hold fascia, peritoneum. Artery forceps can be straight or curved and come in small(mosquito), medium and large sizes.

Option B - Rampley’s sponge holding forceps are used to hold the gall bladder.It has got fenestrated, serrated, flat distal end. It is also used to clean the operative area, swab the cavities, mop the oozing area and hold the cervix.

Option D - Babcock’s forceps are used to hold the ureter. The distal part of the blades are curved with a triangular fenestra in it, which allows the soft tissues to bulge out.The tip is non traumatic with transverses serrations on it.There is a lock in the proximal part.It is also used to hold bowel loops, Fallopian tubes and the appendix.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs used in the treatment of alcohol abuse causes reduced craving by blocking the opioid receptor?
questions.solution:
Naltrexone causes reduced reward response to drinking and reduced craving by blocking the opioid receptor.

Before prescribing: Evaluate for possible current opioid use; consider a urine toxicology screen for opioids, including synthetic opioids. Obtain liver function tests and follow up periodically.

Acamprosate, naltrexone, and disulfiram are used in the treatment of alcohol dependence.

Other options:

Option A: Chlordiazepoxide is a benzodiazepine used in the treatment of alcohol withdrawal.

Option B: Acamprosate affects glutamate and GABA neurotransmitter systems, but its alcohol-related action is unclear.

Option D: Disulfiram inhibits the intermediate metabolism of alcohol which causes a build-up of acetaldehyde and a reaction of flushing, sweating, nausea, and tachycardia if a patient drinks alcohol.

questions.text: Choose the correct statement regarding the events occurring at the neuromuscular junction.

choices.text: The nicotinic receptors are concentrated at the pits of junctional fold
Ca2+ influx produces end plate potential
Action potential generated at the end plate travels bidirectionally
End plate receives signal from multiple nerve endings

questions.solution:
After depolarization at the neuromuscular junction, the action potential generated at the end plate travels bidirectionally, propagating in both directions away from the end plate.

At the neuromuscular junction,

  • Each motor endplate in a neuromuscular junction receives input from a single nerve fiber (Option D).
  • Impulse is received at the terminal of the motor neuron.
  • This in turn increases the permeability of calcium ions through voltage-gated calcium channels which causes exocytosis of acetylcholine-containing synaptic vesicles.
  • The nicotinic cholinergic receptors which are concentrated at the top of junctional folds (thickened portion of muscle membrane) receive acetylcholine (Option A).
  • Quantal release of acetylcholine refers to the magnitude of acetylcholine released in response to nerve impulse. The size of quanta of Ach released depends on the concentration of calcium ion and inversely with magnesium ion.
  • This increases the Na+ and K+ conductance and the fleeting influx of Na+ ion produces a depolarising endplate potential (Option B).
  • The end plate potential is a local graded potential caused by a sudden rise in the number of sodium ions in the muscle fiber when voltage-gated acetylcholine channels open causing a positive rise of potential up to 50 to 75 mV.
  • The action potential generated at the end plate travels on either side bidirectionally away from the end plate
  • This, the muscle action potential generates muscle contraction.
  • The acetylcholine released is then removed by acetylcholine esterase present in the cleft of junctional folds. 

The two diseases of neuromuscular junction include myasthenia gravis and Lambert-eaton myasthenic syndrome.

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant is brought to the emergency room with seizures. On examination, the child has thin extremities and  hepatomegaly. Investigations revealed hypoglycemia, elevated uric acid levels in the blood, and marked lactic acidosis. The blood sample has the following appearance. What is the most likely enzyme deficiency?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of hypoglycemia, hypertriglyceridemia (milky white plasma), hyperuricemia, and lactic acidosis are suggestive of von Gierke disease (type Ia). It is due to the deficiency of glucose 6-phosphatase.

Signs and symptoms of von Gierke disease are

  • Seizures 
  • Doll-like facies (fat cheeks and relatively thin extremities)
  • Milky white plasma - due to very high serum triglyceride levels and cholesterol levels
  • Hepatomegaly
  • Enlarged kidney
  • Growth retardation
  • Hypoglycemia (blood glucose <60 mg/dL)
  • Blood uric acid levels >5 mg/dL
  • Lactic acidosis
  • Neutropenia (specific to Ib)

Treatment of von Gierke includes

  • Maintenance of glucose levels by nasogastric infusion of glucose or the use of uncooked cornstarch.
  • Mild to moderate restriction of lactose, fructose, and sucrose.
  • Ensure adequate intake of vitamins and minerals.
  • Oral citrate and bicarbonate administration.
  • HMG-CoA reductase inhibitors and fibrates therapy should be started if triglyceride levels are >900 mg/dL, despite dietary therapy.
  • Allopurinol (10 mg/kg/day) should be started for hyperuricemia if uncontrolled on dietary therapy.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with sudden bilateral swelling of lower limbs associated with diarrhea, dyspnea, and signs of cardiac failure. Mustard oil adulteration is suspected to be the cause. What is the toxin involved?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of epidemic dropsy. It is caused by the toxic compound sanguinarine, which is present in argemone oil extracted from argemone seeds. It is commonly used as an adulterant in mustard oil.

Epidemic dropsy results in sudden onset of swelling of lower limbs, diarrhea, and breathlessness. Some patients may develop hypersecretory glaucoma. It can lead to death due to cardiac failure.

Adulteration with argemone oil can be detected by the following tests:

  • Paper chromatography - most sensitive test
  • Nitric acid test

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy has frequent episodes of facial edema around his lips. It usually occurs after an emotional stressor. He also has a family history of similar conditions. Which of the following is the main mediator of these symptoms?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of hereditary angioedema. The main inflammatory mediator responsible for these symptoms is bradykinin.

Bradykinin is an inflammatory mediator formed by the cleavage of kininogen, in the presence of the enzyme kallikrein. Bradykinin has the following effects:

  • Increases the vascular permeability
  • Causes contraction of smooth muscle
  • Dilates the blood vessel 
  • Mediates pain

Hereditary angioedema is an autosomal dominant condition characterized by a deficiency of C1 esterase inhibitors. C1 esterase inhibitors usually target proteases like C1r and C1s, factor XII and the kallikrein system. Therefore, its deficiency leads to unregulated activation of kallikrein, leading to increased bradykinin.

Features of the condition include swelling of the skin and mucosal surfaces, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. They may be aggravated after minor trauma or emotional stressor. The condition can be treated by giving C1 inhibitor concentrates from human plasma. 

Option D: histamine is implicated as a mediator of angioedema in anaphylaxis. However, the main mediator in Heriditory Angioedema is bradykinnin and therefore the correct answer.

Related Pearl: Various actions of Principal Mediators of Inflammation

Histamine Vasodilation, increased vascular permeability, endothelial activation
Prostaglandins Vasodilation, pain, fever
Leukotrienes Increased vascular permeability, chemotaxis, leukocyte adhesion, and activation
Cytokines (TNF, IL-1, IL-6)

Local: endothelial activation (expression of adhesion molecules).

Systemic: fever, metabolic abnormalities, hypotension (shock)
Chemokines Chemotaxis, leukocyte activation
Platelet-activating factor Vasoconstriction, Vasodilation (at low concentration), increased vascular permeability, leukocyte adhesion, chemotaxis, degranulation, oxidative burst
Complement Leukocyte chemotaxis and activation, direct target killing (membrane attack complex), vasodilation (mast cell stimulation)

Note: Thromboxane A2 (TXA2) is a prostaglandin, which is a potent vasoconstrictor

questions.text: An epidemiologist is studying the latent period of mesothelioma in a group of workers exposed to asbestos. Which of the following correctly describes the term?

choices.text: The period from disease initiation to disease detection
The period from disease detection to the start of treatment
The time required for 50% of cases to occur following exposure
Time between diagnosis by a screening test and confirmative test

questions.solution:
The latent period is defined as the period from disease initiation to disease detection.

It is a term used for non-infectious diseases such as heart disease, cancer, or mental illness. It is equivalent to the "incubation period" in infectious diseases.

The incubation period in infectious diseases is the time interval between the invasion of the infectious agent and the appearance of the first symptom or sign in the body. It is also assessed using the median incubation period which is the time required for 50% of cases to occur following exposure (Option C).

Lead time is the time gained by screening. It is the time between diagnosis by a screening test and diagnosis by other means. It helps in the early diagnosis and treatment of a disease (Option D).

questions.text: In which of the following condition would you use the tube given in the image below?
questions.solution:
The tube given in the image is the Ewald tube used for performing gastric lavage. It is used in carbolic acid poisoning.

The Ewald tube is also known as Boa's tube, stomach tube, or orogastric lavage tube. It has a funnel at the upper end and a suction bulb to suck out fluids.

Gastric lavage is done to empty the stomach followed by the instillation of one dose of activated charcoal. It is effective if performed within about 4 hours of ingestion. The tube is inserted with the patient in a prone or semi-prone on his left side with his head hanging over the edge of the bed and face down so that the mouth is at a lower level than the larynx to prevent aspiration (Trendelenburg and left lateral decubitus position).

In unconscious patients, the airway must be clear, and a mouth gag with a central hole is used. Before withdrawal, the tube should be pinched to prevent aspiration of material into the lungs.

Contraindications to lavage include corrosives (except carbolic acid), convulsants, foreign body ingestion, petroleum distillates, oesophageal varices, etc.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman came with complaints of recurrent easy bruising and mucosal bleeding with minor trauma that has been steroid-responsive for the past 9 months. Thrombocytopenia is present but the coagulation profile is normal. What is the pathogenesis involved in this condition?

choices.text: Deficiency of plasma enzyme vWF metalloproteinase
Quantitative defects in von willebrand factor

questions.solution:
The above given clinical scenario of easy bruising, mucosal bleeds even with minor trauma, thrombocytopenia, normal coagulation profile, and response to steroids is suggestive of chronic Immune Thrombocytopenic Purpura (ITP). Pathogenesis involved in chronic ITP is the production of antibodies against platelet membrane glycoproteins IIb-IIIa.

Immune thrombocytopenic purpura or idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP)  is an autoimmune disorder with an immune-mediated destruction of platelets. It can be acute or chronic.

Chronic ITP is due to autoantibodies against platelet membrane glycoproteins IIb-IIIa or Ib-IX occurring mostly in young women less than 40 years of age. It can either be primary (idiopathic) or secondary to autoimmune conditions like SLE or infections like HIV and hepatitis C. Pinpoint hemorrhages (petechiae) and ecchymoses are seen in the patient. There will be a history of easy bruising, nosebleeds, gingival bleeding, and hemorrhages into soft tissues from relatively minor trauma.

Investigation shows isolated very low platelet counts. These patients have abnormally large platelets (megathrombocytes) in the peripheral smear, a sign of accelerated thrombopoiesis. Coagulation studies will be normal. 

Almost all patients respond to glucocorticoids but many relapse following the withdrawal of steroids. Splenectomy is advised for patients who have severe thrombocytopenia (<30000/ml) and also for steroid-resistant patients. Immunomodulatory agents such as intravenous rituximab (Anti CD20 antibody) are effective in patients who relapse after splenectomy.

Other options:

Option B: Deficiency of plasma enzyme vWF metalloproteinase is seen in Thrombotic Thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP). It occurs due to deficiency or autoantibodies against the metalloprotease ADAMTS13. In this condition, the vWF molecules persist causing pathogenic platelet adhesion and aggregation. This causes localized platelet thrombi and fibrin deposits at various sites. TTP is classically manifested by the pentad of fever, neurologic symptoms, microangiopathy, renal involvement and thrombocytopenia

Option C: Deficiency of glycoprotein Ib - IX is seen in Bernard Soulier syndrome. It is an autosomal recessive disorder due to an inherited deficiency of platelet membrane glycoprotein complex Ib-IX. This glycoprotein is a receptor of the von Willebrand factor, which is needed for normal platelet adhesion to the subendothelial extracellular matrix. The platelet count will be normal but there will be abnormal platelet function.

Option D: Quantitative defects in von Willebrand factor lead to von Willebrand disease. Von Willebrand disease occurs due to a deficiency of the von Willebrand factor (vWF) which serves as a carrier for factor VIII and is essential for platelet adhesion. It presents with mucocutaneous bleeding. Lab investigations will show an increase in bleeding time and APTT.

Related Pearl: Causes of Thrombocytopenia

I. Decreased Production of Platelets

  1. Selective impairment of platelet production
    • Drug-induced: alcohol, thiazides, cytotoxic drugs
    • Infections: measles, human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)
  2. Nutritional deficiencies - B12, folate deficiency
  3. Bone marrow failure - aplastic anemia
  4. Bone marrow replacement - leukemia, disseminated cancer, granulomatous disease
  5. Ineffective hematopoiesis - myelodysplastic syndromes 

II. Decreased Platelet Survival

  1. Immunologic destruction
    • Primary autoimmune - chronic immune thrombocytopenic purpura, acute immune thrombocytopenic purpura
    • Secondary autoimmune - systemic lupus erythematosus, B-cell lymphoid neoplasms
    • Alloimmune - posttransfusion and neonatal
    • Drug-associated - quinidine, heparin, sulfa compounds
    • Infections - HIV, infectious mononucleosis (transient, mild), dengue fever
  2. Nonimmunologic destruction
    • Disseminated intravascular coagulation
    • Thrombotic microangiopathies
    • Giant hemangiomas

III. Sequestration - The spleen normally sequesters 30% to 35% of platelets. This can rise to 80% to 90% when the spleen is enlarged, producing moderate degrees of thrombocytopenia.

IV. Dilution - Transfusions

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman, with psoriasis, was found to have manic depression. She was started on a medication that resulted in severe exacerbation of the psoriatic rash as shown in the image below. Which of the following medications is likely to have caused it?
questions.solution:
The patient has developed a severe exacerbation of psoriasis, secondary to lithium administration for her manic depression.

Various factors contribute to the exacerbation of psoriasis. Drugs inducing/exacerbating psoriasis:

  1. Beta-blockers
  2. Synthetic antimalarials
  3. NSAIDS
  4. Lithium
  5. ACE inhibitors & angiotensin receptor blockers
  6. Interferon alpha
  7. Tetracycline
  8. Terbinafine
  9. Gemfibrozil

Other environmental and immunological factors that may trigger psoriasis are:

  • Infections- beta-hemolytic streptococci can trigger guttate psoriasis, viral infections like HIV
  • Alcohol misuse and smoking
  • Emotional stress
  • Trauma - Koebner phenomenon
  • Winter 
  • Sunlight

questions.text: Some people underwent general health checkups at your hospital. This included a health questionnaire, clinical examination, and a range of biochemical tests on blood and urine specimens. This type of screening is an example of:
questions.solution:
The given scenario of annual health check-ups would be an example of multiphasic screening.

Multiphasic screening is the application of two or more screening tests in combination at one time to a large number of people instead of screening separately for individual diseases.

This procedure includes a health questionnaire, clinical examination, and investigations that can be performed rapidly with the appropriate staffing organization and equipment. 

Other options 

Options A and C-  High-risk or selective screening is done on high-risk groups. For example, MRI screening of breast is done annually in 25-year old women with BRCA 1, BRCA 2 mutations in the first-degree relative.

Option D- Mass screening is a screening of a whole or large population like using chest X-rays for TB screening in large populations. It is done for diseases with high prevalence.

questions.text: As a researcher, which of the following studies would be necessary for therapeutic confirmation?
questions.solution:
Randomized, 3000 patients can be used to conduct a phase 3 clinical trial. 

Phase 3  involves a large number of patients (about 500-3000) being assigned randomly to either the treatment under investigation (e.g., drug X in the question) or to the present standard of care. Option C: Phase 2 (first in patients) checks the efficacy and dose range of the drug. 50-500 patient subjects receive the experimental drug. It lasts for 2-3 years.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient was recently diagnosed with non-Hodgkin lymphoma and was started on an anticancer drug. After a few days, the patient started passing blood in the urine for which mesna was used as a treatment. Which of the following is responsible for the side effect?
questions.solution:
In this case, the patient is suffering from hemorrhagic cystitis as an adverse effect, due to the toxic metabolite of cyclophosphamide called acrolein. This can be decreased by vigorous hydration and by the use of mercaptoethanesulfonate (mesna).

Cyclophosphamide is an alkylating agent that interferes with DNA integrity and function. It induces cell death in rapidly proliferating tissues. It is metabolised by hepatic cytochrome enzyme to form 4-Hydroxycyclophosphamide. The tautomer of 4-Hydroxycyclophosphamide called aldophosphamide cleaves non-enzymatically in the tumor cell to form phosphoramide mustard and acrolein.

Antitumor effects are due to phosphoramide mustard, while acrolein causes hemorrhagic cystitis. Vigorous intravenous hydration should be done in patients with high-dose treatment. Brisk hematuria in a patient receiving daily oral therapy should lead to immediate drug discontinuation.

Cyclophosphamide is an essential component of many effective drug combinations for non-Hodgkin lymphomas, other lymphoid malignancies, breast and ovarian cancers, and solid tumors in children.

questions.text: Given below is a special type of airway device. In which of the following situations would it be used?
questions.solution:
The given image is that of a double lumen bronchial tube, which is used in pneumonectomy.

Double lumen tubes are used to provide one-lung ventilation. Intentional collapse of the lung on the operative side facilitates most of the thoracic procedures . They are identified by:

  • A longer endobronchial lumen that enters either the right or left main bronchus and another shorter endotracheal lumen that terminates in the lower trachea
  • A preformed curve that, when properly aimed, allows preferential entry into a bronchus
  • An endobronchial cuff
  • An endotracheal cuff 

Some of the indications for double lumen tubes are:

  • To confine infection or bleeding to one lung  
  • Bronchopleural fistula
  • Tracheobronchial disruption  
  • Severe hypoxemia due to unilateral lung disease 
  • Repair of thoracic aortic aneurysm
  • Pneumonectomy, Lobectomy or Segmental resection of the lung
  • Thoracoscopy
  • Esophageal surgery
  • Single-lung transplantation
  • Bronchoalveolar lavage 

Option A - Ophthalmic surgeries are performed with an oral RAE (Ring Adair Elwyn) tube, which has a preformed right-angle bend at the level of the teeth so that it does not disrupt the surgical field.     

Option B - Wire reinforced (armored) tubes are used for surgeries performed in prone position , to resist kinking.

Option C - Nasal RAE tube is preferred in dental and oral surgeries. The endotracheal tube can be directed cephalad over the patient’s forehead so as not to disrupt the surgical field.

questions.text:
A young female patient with SLE visits the doctor for a follow-up. Her urine analysis shows the presence of proteinuria and microscopic hematuria. The patient undergoes renal biopsy, and it shows focal glomerulonephritis involving less than 50% of all glomeruli. What is the class of lupus nephritis?

SLE - systemic lupus erythematosus
questions.solution:
Focal glomerulonephritis involving less than 50% of all glomeruli belongs to class III lupus nephritis (focal lupus nephritis).

Nephritis is a serious and life-threatening manifestation of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). In the initial stages, the patients are usually asymptomatic. Therefore, evaluating patients for renal function is important to prevent the progression of the disease. 

Symptoms of nephritis are proteinuria, hematuria, nephrotic syndrome, and hypertension. If the patient has clinical or laboratory evidence of nephritis, they have to undergo renal biopsy. Depending on the histopathological features, lupus nephritis is divided into six classes.

Class III or focal lupus nephritis shows focal, segmental, or global glomerulonephritis involving ≤ 50% of all glomeruli. Focal subendothelial deposits might also be present.

Immunofluorescence of the renal biopsy in lupus nephritis will show positive staining for all immune reactants (IgG, IgA, IgM, C1q, C3, kappa and lambda light chain). This is called a full house pattern.

Below image shows the deposition of all the immune reactants in the glomeruli:

questions.text: A patient underwent reconstruction surgery with a flap known as the Abbe-Estlander flap, shown below. This flap is used for the reconstruction of which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the Abbe-Estlander flap, which is used for lip reconstruction.

The Abbe-Estlander flap is a full-thickness lip-switch flap. Here, a part of the uninvolved lip is rotated across the mouth and into the defect of the involved lip.

The Estlander and Abbé flaps are based on the labial artery used for the reconstruction of the lip. The Estlander flap involves resection of the commissure, while the Abbé flap preserves the commissure.

Related Pearl: Lip reconstruction flaps

  • Up to half of the lip can be removed and closed primarily.
  • Defects encompassing between one half and two-thirds of the lip require augmentation.
  • Karapandzic flap consists of circumoral incisions with the circular rotation of the skin flaps while maintaining innervation.
  • When the defect involves the commissure, the Estlander flap is used, and the Abbé flap is used for more midline defects.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with a history of falling off his bicycle. He complains of severe pain around his ankle. Which of the following findings is seen in this CT scan?
questions.solution:
The finding seen in the CT scan is Thurston Holland sign or fragment. The given CT of the ankle lateral shows a Salter-Harris type 2 epiphyseal fracture, in which there is involvement of the growth plate (physis) and a triangle of metaphyseal bone, with sparing of the epiphysis. This triangle of metaphyseal bone is known as Thurston Holland sign. 


Salter-Harris classified epiphyseal injuries into 5 types. Type 2 epiphyseal fractures are the most common type of epiphyseal injury in patients over 10 years of age.

Other options:

Option A: Trethowan's sign is seen in slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE). It is when Klein's line does not intersect the lateral part of the superior femoral epiphysis on an AP radiograph of the pelvis but passes superior to it.


Option B: Terry Thomas sign is seen in patients with scapholunate instability which denotes the increased gap between the scaphoid and the lunate.


Option D: The teardrop sign is seen in orbital floor fractures and is also known as a blow-out fracture due to the herniation of orbital contents into the maxillary antrum.

Related Pearl: Types of Salter–Harris fractures- Mnemonic

There are nine types of Salter-Harris fractures. Among these, types I to V are more common.

The mnemonic "SALTER" can be used to help remember the first five types.

TYPE  MNEMONIC DESCRIPTION
Type I S = Slip/straight across Transverse fracture through the growth plate
Type II A = Away The fracture lies away from the joint. A fracture through the growth plate and the metaphysis, sparing the epiphysis
Type III L = Lower The fracture is below the physis in the epiphysis.
Type IV TE = Through Everything  A fracture through all three elements of the bone, the growth plate, metaphysis, and epiphysis
Type V R = Rammed (crushed)  A compression fracture of the growth plate

Rarer types VI to IX have been added subsequently.

  • Type VI - Injury to the perichondral structures
  • Type VII - Isolated injury to the epiphyseal plate
  • Type VIII - Isolated injury to the metaphysis, with a potential injury related to endochondral ossification
  • Type IX - Injury to the periosteum that may interfere with membranous growth

questions.text: A resident doctor suspects a deformity in the hip while doing a routine clinical examination of a 3 day old baby. He performs the following test that is found to be positive. Which of the following investigations is best suited for the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with Ortlani's test positive is suggestive of developmental dysplasia of the hip. Ultrasound of the hip is most useful for the diagnosis of this condition in children less than 6 months old. X-ray is more useful in children more than 6 months since ossification occurs.

Developmental Dysplasia of the hip (DDH): It is characterized by spontaneous dislocation of the hip joint before, during, or shortly after birth. This condition is more common in females. Children with this condition have a waddling gait and on examination abduction and lateral rotation of the hip is decreased. The Barlow and Ortolani tests are used for the diagnosis of DDH

The image given below shows the vertical Perkin's line and the horizontal Hilgenreiner’s line. Normally the femoral head lies in the inner and lower quadrants formed by these lines. But in DDH the femoral head is in the upper and outer quadrant.

*Note: The investigation of choice before 6 months of age is ultrasonography. The investigation of choice after 6 months is X-ray. Overall, MRI is the investigation of choice preoperatively since it aids in the evaluation of soft tissue structures of the labrum, and helps plan the treatment for DDH. 

Related Pearl: Age wise management of DDH

6-18 months Closed or open reduction followed by hip spica after reduction
18-36 months Open reduction with femoral shortening and pelvic osteotomy (Salter's osteotomy, Pemberton osteotomy, Steel osteotomy)
3-8 year Open reduction with femoral shortening and pelvic osteotomy 
8-18 year

questions.text: A 69-year-old diabetic patient has come to you with excruciating right ear pain and right-sided facial palsy. An otoscopic examination of the ear shows granulations on the floor of the external auditory canal. Choose the correct statement regarding this condition.

choices.text: Technicium 99 is useful in monitoring disease
Antibiotic therapy is the treatment of choice

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of malignant otitis externa and antibiotic therapy is the treatment of choice.

Malignant otitis externa/ Necrotizing otitis externa is an inflammatory condition caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa in elderly diabetics and immunocompromised patients. It is characterised by excruciating ear pain, profuse discharge and granulations on the floor of the external ear canal. Necrosis of bone aids in the spread of infection. Infection may spread to the skull base and jugular foramen causing multiple cranial nerve palsies. Facial paralysis is the most common nerve palsy seen.

Gallium-67 scan is useful in the diagnosis and follow-up of the patient. It can be repeated every 3 weeks to monitor the disease and response to treatment. Technetium 99 bone scan reveals bone infection, but the test remains positive for a year or so and cannot be used to monitor the disease.

Treatment includes control of diabetes, toilet of the ear canal, removal of discharge, debris and granulations of dead tissue or bone.

Antibiotic treatment against P. aeruginosa for 6-8 weeks or more. If the patient is not responsive, treatment should be based on culture and sensitivity of ear discharge. Antibiotics that are usually effective against pseudomonas aeruginosa are gentamicin combined with ticarcillin (IV), third-generation cephalosporins (IV) e.g. ceftriaxone, ceftazidime along with an aminoglycoside, fluoroquinolones (ciprofloxacin, ofloxacin and levofloxacin) combined with rifampin (Oral).

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman had undergone breast implantation one year back. She now presents to you with pain in the left breast. MRI imaging shows the following finding. It is indicative of:

choices.text: Stepladder sign indicating Intra-capsular implant rupture
Stepladder sign indicating extra-capsular implant rupture
Linguine sign indicating Intra-capsular implant rupture
Linguine sign indicating Extra-capsular implant rupture

questions.solution:
The given breast MRI shows linguine sign which is seen in intra-capsular rupture of a breast implant. It is due to the free-floating shell within the implant.

After implantation of a silicone or saline breast implant, a fibrous capsule (scar) forms around the implant shell. In an intracapsular rupture, the contents of the implant are contained by the fibrous scar, while the shell appears as a group of wavy lines. This has been termed the "linguine sign". It is seen in intra-capsular rupture of a breast implant. It is best seen on MRI.


Note:

  • Stepladder sign is analogous to the "linguine sign," which is seen on the USG of the breast. It is identified as multiple, discontinuous, parallel, linear echoes in the lumen.
  • Snowstorm sign on USG is seen in extracapsular rupture due to silicone granuloma.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presented with frequently changing bowel habits. He noticed blood in the stools which were not associated with pain. There was no history of weight loss. Barium enema was done and the image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is colonic diverticulosis.

The above clinical scenario with the barium enema image is suggestive of colonic diverticulosis. The barium enema given shows multiple outpouchings in the ascending, transverse, and descending colon resembling a saw-tooth.  

Diverticulosis refers to the condition where multiple outpouchings occur along the gastrointestinal tract without any inflammation. Colonic diverticulosis is more common among the age group of more than 50 years. Colonic diverticulosis is primarily false diverticula as only the mucosa and muscularis mucosa have herniated. Due to the high intraluminal pressure, they are referred to as the pulsion type of diverticula. A low fibre diet results in smaller stool volume that increases intraluminal pressure for propulsion. The higher pressures get directed to the colonic wall resulting in pulsion diverticula. The sigmoid colon is the most common location.

The majority of the patients with diverticulosis are usually asymptomatic. However, some patients may present with abdominal cramps, altered bowel habits, and painless rectal bleeding. Diverticulosis can present with complications like:

  • Diverticulitis
  • Abscess
  • Peritonitis
  • Intestinal obstruction
  • Hemorrhage 
  • Fistula formation

Diagnosis:

The diagnosis is confirmed by a colonoscopy or an X-ray barium enema. Barium enema radiograph shows multiple barium-coated outpouchings from the colonic wall and gives the appearance of a saw-tooth. In cases of severe abdominal pain, a CT scan is preferred to avoid the risk of intestinal perforation.

Treatment:

A high fibre diet reduces the incidence of diverticulosis. Antispasmodics can be prescribed to reduce intestinal spasms. Most cases of bleeding are self-limiting. If persistent bleeding is present, surgical, endoscopic or radiological interventions can be done to reduce the bleeding.

Other options:

Option B- Carcinoma colon shows apple-core sign on barium enema as shown below. 

 

Option C- Crohn's disease is an inflammatory bowel disease that shows the string sign of Kantor on barium enema as shown below.

 

Option D- Intussusception shows the coiled-spring appearance on barium enema as shown below.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old pregnant woman presented to the OPD after 5 weeks of delivery with a loss of interest in day-to-day activities, inability to sleep, and low mood. She does not want to feed her baby and has lost weight. Which of the following SSRIs can be safely used in this patient to improve her condition?

SSRI - Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of postpartum women with loss of interest, insomnia, low mood, and loss of weight after 4 weeks of delivery is suggestive of postpartum depression. Sertraline has the least passage into breast milk and can be safely used in this condition.

Postpartum depression is marked by a depressed mood, excessive anxiety, insomnia, and weight changes usually within the 4-6 weeks of delivery. The preferred treatment is cognitive behavioral therapy and the usage of SSRIs like sertraline and paroxetine. The levels of antidepressants in breast milk are usually very low. Sertraline and paroxetine are considered the safest and first-line drugs.

Antidepressants like citalopram (option A), fluoxetine (option C) and bupropion (option D) are mostly avoided in postpartum depression as these drugs may cross into the infant by breastfeeding. These drugs are secreted in larger amounts in the breast milk.

10-15%

Note: Zuranolone is the first-ever oral drug to be FDA-approved specifically for the treatment of postpartum depression. It is a neuroactive steroid that enhances the action of GABA in the brain and regulates mood.

questions.text: A 53-year-old man complains of fatigue, constipation, and weakness in the dorsiflexion of his foot. Laboratory examination reveals anemia, and the peripheral blood smear is shown below. What is the likely cause of his findings?
questions.solution:
The slide shows basophilic stippling (punctate basophilia), seen in chronic lead poisoning (also called plumbism or saturnism). 

The hematological findings that are associated with lead poisoning are anemia, ringed sideroblasts, and basophilic stippling of the RBCs.

Clinical features include:

  • A - Anemia with basophilic stippling
  • B - Burtonian line (blue stippled line on gums)
  • C - Constipation and colic (abdominal pain)
  • D - Drop (wrist and foot drop) due to neuropathy
  • E - Encephalopathy (seen in infants- ataxia, vomiting, stupor, convulsions, and even coma)
  • F - Facial pallor (earliest sign)

Other options-

Option A: Minamata disease resulted from the consumption of fish contaminated with methylmercury. Chronic mercury poisoning would not present with anemia with ringed sideroblasts and basophilic stippling.

Option C: Chronic iron toxicity can be seen in conditions like hemochromatosis, thalassemia (increased absorption due to defective hemoglobin synthesis), or because of excessive oral consumption. Iron overload in various organs can present as liver cirrhosis, hypogonadism, skin pigmentation, diabetes, etc. These patients would have increased serum iron, ferritin, and transferrin saturation. Sideroblastic anemia may present with iron toxicity and how certain similarities to this peripheral smear, but the patient would not present with foot drop.

Option D: Arsenic Poisoning is seen in people working in smelting and ore refineries. Toxicity can present with normocytic normochromic anemia, leukopenia, and thrombocytopenia. Patients would not have basophilic stippling on peripheral smear. Foot drop is also not a feature of arsenic toxicity. Peripheral neuropathy in a glove and stocking pattern may be seen.

questions.text: A person was walking on the road on a hot sunny day. The body tries to maintain optimum body temperature through sweating. Which of the following nuclei is involved in mediating this temperature regulatory response?
questions.solution:
The above scenario, in which the body is trying to maintain optimum body temperature through sweating (i.e. cooling) is mediated by the anterior nucleus of the hypothalamus.

questions.text: What is the earliest morphological feature in reversible cell injury and the underlying mechanism behind this change?
questions.solution:
Cellular swelling is the earliest morphological feature resulting from ATP depletion leading to sodium-potassium pump failure.

The following changes occur in reversible cell injury:

  • Cellular swelling or hydropic change
    • ATP depletion leads to sodium-potassium pump failure
    • Na and water accumulate within the cell causing cellular swelling
  • Fatty change
    • Seen in cells involved in or dependent on fat metabolism (liver hepatocytes and myocardial cells)
  • Light microscopy - no noticeable changes

Ultrastructural findings:

  • Mitochondrial swelling and small amorphous densities
  • Plasma membrane blebs
  • Swelling of the endoplasmic reticulum (ER)
  • Detachment of ribosomes from granular ER
  • Nuclear changes like disaggregation of granular and fibrillar filaments

questions.text: An anxious mother is worried about feeding her baby. The baby was born at 30 weeks of gestation with a birth weight of 1.6 kgs. What will you advise as a routine primary feeding method for this baby?
questions.solution:
The nasogastric tube feeding can be advised as a routine primary feeding method for this baby.

The feeding of neonates depends on their gestational age and it depends on the level of maturity of the neonate. In this scenario, as the baby is 1.6 kg (low birth weight) and was born at 30 weeks of gestation, nasogastric tube feeding is preferred. Babies born before 32 weeks will not have the coordination between swallowing and breathing. So, paladai feeding can only be used occasionally. Babies born after 34 weeks will have a completely mature sucking pattern and breastfeeding is more preferred.

Based on birth weight, babies can be classified into

  • Low birth weight (LBW) - Birth weight < 2.5kg
  • Very low birth weight (VLBW)- Birth weight <1.5kg
  • Extremely low birth weight (ELBW)- Birth weight <1kg

All LBW infants, irrespective of their initial feeding method should receive only breast milk. This can be given as expressed breast milk (mothers' milk) to those infants fed by paladai or gastric tube. An alternative is human donor milk. When there is a contraindication to breastfeeding or if the mother is sick, formula feeds can be given. Term formula feed in babies with birth weight >1500 g and preterm formula feed in VLBW babies can be given. All hemodynamically stable LBW babies should receive Kangaroo Mother Care (KMC).

LBW can result from preterm birth (born before 37 completed weeks) or IUGR (intrauterine growth restriction) or both. Prematurity and low birth weight are the leading causes of neonatal mortality.

questions.text:
Which of the following pairs of exotoxins do not show a similar mechanism of action?

ETEC - Enterotoxigenic E.coli
questions.solution:
Among the given pairs of exotoxins , verocytotoxin - shigella enterotoxin do not show a similar mechanism of action instead verocytotoxin and shiga toxin show a similar mechanism of action - by inhibiting protein synthesis by inhibiting 60S ribosome.

Shigella enterotoxin (ShET) is structurally similar to cholera toxin and is found in Shigella flexneri 2a whereas shiga toxin is produced by S. dysenteriae type 1 and is structurally and functionally similar to verocytotoxin of EHEC (Enterohemorrhagic E.coli). It enhances local vascular damage of the intestine,kidney and brain.

Other options - 

Option A - Both Pseudomonas Exotoxin A and diphtheria toxin acts by inhibiting protein synthesis by inhibiting elongation factor-2.    

Option B - Both ETEC (Enterotoxigenic E.coli) labile toxin and cholera toxin acts by activation of adenylate cyclase, increasing cAMP in target cells leading to secretory diarrhea.

Option D - Both streptococcal pyrogenic exotoxin and staphylococcal enterotoxin are super-antigens that bind to T-cell receptors (TCR) outside the antibody binding groove directly to the lateral aspect of TCR beta-chain stimulating T cells non-specifically to release large amounts of cytokines.

questions.text: A 20-year-old patient with tubercular cervical lymphadenitis came to the OPD with the following painful red nodular lesion predominant on the posterior aspect of the legs. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and image point to the diagnosis of Erythema induratum of Bazin which is a delayed hypersensitivity reaction in patients suffering from tuberculosis.

The erythema induratum of Bazin is a tuberculosis-associated panniculitis and it is the most common form of tuberculid. It usually presents as crops of small, painful deep-seated, dusky or erythematous plaques on the posterior aspect of calves. 

it is caused by PPD-specific T-cells which produce IFN-gamma in response to mycobacterial antigens at the site of skin lesion. The vascular component may be caused due to immune complex deposition. It can be caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis, Mycobacterium bovis, and Mycobacterium chelonae. 

Most patients respond to a complete course of anti-tubercular therapy and heal with hyperpigmented scars.

Other Options:

Option A) Papulonecrotic tuberculid is a type of hypersensitivity reaction to tuberculosis that presents as an asymptomatic cluster of small, erythematous papules that may ulcerate. it usually presents on the lower abdomen, trunk, buttocks and scalp.

Option B) Erythema Nodosum is the most common panniculitis that presents on the anterior shin and is a self-limiting plaque-producing non-ulcerating nodule. The most common triggers are bacterial infections, sarcoidosis and inflammatory bowel disease.

Option D) Prurigo nodularis are symmetric hyperkeratotic and eroded nodules, that occur in response to chronic pruritis in the extremities, due to underlying atopic predisposition.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy is brought to the emergency room with excruciating burning pain over the palms and soles, diarrhea, abdominal pain, and ringing sensation in the ears. On examination, he has thickening of lips, frontal bossing, corneal opacities, and skin lesions as shown in the image below. This X-linked disorder is caused due to which enzyme deficiency?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Fabry's disease and it is caused due to the deficiency of α-Galactosidase. 

Fabry disease is an X-linked, multisystem, lysosomal storage disorder caused due to mutations in the gene that codes for α-Galactosidase, resulting in decreased activity of the enzyme. This leads to accumulation of globotriaosylceramide. It is seen in both men and women (less severe).

It usually manifests in childhood or adolescence, with symptoms of severe agonizing pain in the palms of hands, soles of feet, and proximal extremities called acroparesthesia, aggravated by changes in temperature, exercise, fatigue, or fever and may last anywhere from a few minutes to many days.

There is a characteristic facial appearance of frontal bossing, thickening of the lips, and prominent supraorbital ridges. Angiokeratomas, as seen in the image above are present, which are lesions that are dark-red to blue-black, flat or slightly raised, punctate, and usually seen between the umbilicus and the knees (called the 'bathing suit area') and the trunk.

Patients also have diarrhea, abdominal distension, heat intolerance, and tinnitus. Late presentations include renal failure, and cardiovascular or cerebrovascular disease, which are the leading causes of death in these patients.

Urinalysis shows proteinuria. An enzyme assay, genetic testing, or a skin or kidney biopsy showing glycolipid deposits helps establish the diagnosis.

Treatment is with enzyme replacement therapy (recombinant alpha-Gal A or migalastat).

Other options:

Option B: β-Glucosidase deficiency manifests as Gaucher disease, which gives rise to symptoms of hepatosplenomegaly, erosion of long bones and mental retardation in infants.

Option C: Sphingomyelinase deficiency manifests as Niemann-Pick disease, with patients presenting with symptoms of hepatosplenomegaly and mental retardation. It is usually fatal in early life.

Option D: Ceramidase deficiency manifests as Farber disease, characterised by dermatitis, hoarseness, skeletal deformities and mental retardation. It is fatal in early life.
