questions.text: A 36-year-old pregnant lady presents in her first trimester for a check-up. She mentions that she has a family history of the condition shown in the images below. Which of the following  can be used to screen for the condition during this visit?
questions.solution:
The images showing a child with oblique palpebral fissures, a depressed nasal bridge, and a single palmar crease are suggestive of Down's syndrome (Trisomy 21). Nuchal translucency (NT) is used to screen for it during the first trimester. 

Nuchal translucency is the maximum thickness of the translucent area between the skin and soft tissue over the fetal spine at the back of the neck. When the NT measurement is increased, it is a marker for fetal aneuploidy and struc­tural anomalies.

Combined first-trimester screening consists of serum human chorionic gonad­otropin (hCG), pregnancy-associated plasma protein-A (PAPP-A), and the measurement of the nuchal translucency (NT) on ultrasound. It is performed between 11 and 14 weeks of gestation.

In fetal Down syndrome, the first-trimester hCG level is increased, PAPP-A level is decreased, and nuchal translucency thickness is increased.

The ultrasound image below shows increased NT thickness and absent nasal bone of a fetus with Trisomy 21 at 11 weeks gestation:


Maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (MSAFP) and unconjugated estriol are measured in the second trimester as part of the triple screening test. Inhibin A is measured as part of the quadruple screening test.

The screening test results associated with trisomy 21 are summarized in the table below:

PAPP-A decreased Unconjugated estriol decreased Unconjugated estriol decreased
NT increased MSAFP decreased MSAFP decreased

questions.text: Absence of the Nitabuch layer in the uterine decidua will lead to which of the following placental abnormalities?
questions.solution:
The absence of the Nitabuch layer in the uterine decidua leads to the placenta accreta spectrum.

The Nitabuch layer (also known as the fibrinoid layer) is a layer of fibrinoid degeneration where the invading trophoblasts meet the decidua basalis.


This Nitabuch layer is absent in the placenta accreta spectrum (PAS), which is characterized by abnormally implanted, invasive, or adhered placenta.

Risk factors for PAS include associated placenta previa and previous cesarean delivery.

Types of the morbidly adherent placenta:

  • Placenta accreta: Villi are attached to the myometrium.
  • Placenta increta: Villi invade the myometrium.
  • Placenta percreta: Villi penetrate through the myometrium and to or through the serosa.

Other options: 

Option A: Placenta previa is a condition in which the placenta is implanted at the lower uterine segment. Patients present with painless, apparently causeless vaginal bleeding after the 28th week. Some of the risk factors include prior cesarean section, suction and curettage, advanced maternal age, and smoking.

Option B: Attachment of the umbilical cord to the membranes is known as velamentous insertion of placenta. The cord vessels traverse between the membranes for some distance before reaching the placenta. If the leash of blood vessels traverses through the membranes overlying the internal os, in front of the presenting part, the condition is called vasa previa.

Option C: Placenta succenturiata is the presence of one or more unequally sized smaller placental lobes at distant sites from the bulk of the placenta. Vessels are present in the intervening membranes that connect the two lobes. It is associated with complications like vasa previa, postpartum uterine atony, postpartum hemorrhage, and endometritis.

questions.text: A known cardiac patient was advised not to take omeprazole while he is on clopidogrel medication. What is the liver enzyme common to the metabolism of these drugs?
questions.solution:
CYP2C19 is the liver enzyme common to the metabolism of Clopidogrel and Omeprazole.

Clopidogrel is a prodrug that is activated to its active metabolite by the liver enzyme CYP2C19. Apart from CYP2C19, CYP3A4, and CYP2C9 are also involved to a certain extent.

Omeprazole serves as both substrate and inhibitor for CYP2C19. Thus, omeprazole may inhibit the activation of clopidogrel and decrease its antiplatelet action.

questions.text: A patient with aplastic anemia undergoes bone marrow transplantation. Within 2 weeks, he presents with complaints of bloody diarrhea. Upon further examination, he was found to have jaundice and blistering rashes on the skin. What is the possible mechanism behind the patient's current clinical picture?

choices.text: Immune cells of the host attacking transplanted tissue
Preformed antibodies of the host attacking transplanted tissue

questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of graft-versus-host disease (GVHD). The possible mechanism behind the patient's current clinical picture is transplanted cells attacking host tissues.

Transfusion of irradiated RBCs prevents the incidence of GVHD associated with the transfusion.

GVHD occurs when immunologically competent cells or their precursors are transplanted into immunologically compromised recipients. The transferred cells recognize the alloantigens in the host and attack host tissues. It is seen most commonly during hematopoietic stem cell transplantation but may also occur following the transplantation of solid organs. 

GVHD may be of two types: acute and chronic.

Acute GVHD occurs within days to weeks after allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation. It mainly involves the immune system and the epithelia of the skin (in the form of generalized rash), liver (in the form of jaundice), and intestines (in the form of bloody diarrhea). But the affected tissues are not heavily infiltrated by lymphocytes.

Chronic GVHD may follow acute GVHD or may occur insidiously. These patients have extensive skin damage, with the destruction of skin appendages and fibrosis of the dermis, resembling systemic sclerosis. Cholestatic jaundice and esophageal strictures are also common. There will be involution of the thymus and depletion of lymphocytes in the lymph nodes. There will also be recurrent bouts of life-threatening infections. Some may even develop autoimmunity, owing to the grafted CD4+ helper T cells reacting with host B cells and stimulating them, which may result in autoantibody production.

Depletion of donor T cells by irradiation before transfusion can eliminate the occurrence of GVHD. But irradiation also has its adverse effects such as tumor recurrence in leukemic patients, increased incidence of graft failures, and EBV-related B-cell lymphoma.

questions.text:
A hospitalized patient develops catheter-associated UTI. The urine culture grows a certain bacteria. The patient is started on nitrofurantoin. What is the likely uropathogen that the drug will target?

UTI - urinary tract infection
questions.solution:
Nitrofurantoin can target Enterococci and E. coli, the most common causes of nosocomial catheter-associated UTIs. So the likely target of this drug is enterococci. 

Nitrofurantoin is a urinary antiseptic agent that is activated by bacterial reductase. It produces free radicals that block the synthesis of bacterial proteins and nucleic acids, causing DNA damage. It has better antibacterial activity in acidic urine.

Nitrofurantoin is active against the most common uropathogens causing UTIs such as Escherichia coli and Enterococci. However, it does not act against Pseudomonas aeruginosa (option B), Proteus spp. (option C), Enterobacter (option D) and Klebsiella.

The drug is generally well-tolerated. Reported adverse effects include flu-like symptoms, hemolysis in G6PD deficient individuals, peripheral neuropathy, pneumonitis or interstitial pulmonary fibrosis, and liver damage. It colors the urine brown.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient complained of excessive daytime sleepiness and tiredness throughout the day. He also had episodes where he felt losing his strength in his muscles and falling to the ground, especially when he is stressed or laughing. What is this finding called?
questions.solution:
The above clinical vignette is suggestive of narcolepsy. The finding mentioned here is called cataplexy. It is a sudden, brief loss of voluntary muscle tone, with partial or no loss of consciousness. It is triggered by strong emotions such as laughter or stress, commonly associated with narcolepsy. 

Narcolepsy is a type of hypersomnolence disorder. Symptoms commonly appear in the second decade of life. A characterized by a tetrad of symptoms is seen:

  1. Excessive daytime sleepiness where there are recurrent episodes of irrepressible sleepiness occurring in a day for more than 3 months. 
  2. Cataplexy- It is associated with deficiency of the neurotransmitter hypocretin. Sudden loss of muscle tone may lead to jaw drop, head drop, weakness of the knees, paralysis of skeletal muscles, or collapse. 
  3. Sleep paralysis is where patients report being unable to move their muscles while waking up in the morning, even though they are conscious and awake. 
  4. Hypnagogic/hypnopompic hallucinations where auditory or visual hallucinations are vivid, dream-like, occurring at the onset of sleep or while waking up and cause frightening for a brief period of time. 

Occurrence of REM sleep within 10 minutes of sleep onset (sleep-onset REM periods) is also seen in these patients. 

Modafinil, an a1-adrenergic receptor agonist, is used to reduce the number of sleep attacks and improve psychomotor performance. Besides this, tricyclic antidepressants or SSRIs are found effective in eliminating cataplexy. Psychosocial therapy like sched­uled naps, lifestyle adjustment, counseling, etc can also be employed. 

Other options:

Option A- Catalepsy, also known as waxy flexibility is a condition in which a person maintains abnormal body posi­tions for very long durations. This is seen in severe cases of catatonic schizophrenia.

Option C- Gegenhalten or paratonic rigidity is seen in frontal lobe lesions. It leads to an involuntary increase in resistance to passive movements.  

Option D- Negativism is when a person opposes or resists any effort to be moved or does the opposite of what is asked. They are seen in catatonic schizophrenia.

questions.text: In patients with obstructive sleep apnea, what is the reason for the increased risk of hypertension?

choices.text: Increased partial pressure of carbon dioxide

questions.solution:
In patients with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), the hypoxemic respiratory events cause overactivation of the sympathetic nervous system, leading to an increased risk of development of hypertension.

OSA is characterized by recurrent episodes of upper airway obstruction during sleep, leading to intermittent hypoxia and sleep fragmentation. These episodes trigger sympathetic nervous system activation. This heightened sympathetic tone contributes to hypertension by increasing systemic vascular resistance and stimulating renin release from the kidneys.

OSA is also characterized by a non-dipping pattern on overnight blood pressure monitoring, which is the absence of a normal 10% drop in blood pressure during sleep when compared to the awake state.

Other complications of OSA include exacerbation of insulin resistance and an increased risk of coronary artery disease, heart failure, arrhythmias, and cardiovascular disease.

Other options: 

Options A and D: Although factors such as increased partial pressure of carbon dioxide and elevated erythropoietin levels may be observed in OSA, they are not the primary mechanisms driving hypertension.

Option C: Hypoxemic episodes result in the release of reactive oxygen species which contributes to insulin resistance and prothrombotic state in OSA, but is not a primary mechanism for the development of hypertension.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with fatigue, joint pain, features of diabetes with bronze pigmentation of the skin. Lab tests reveal abnormal liver function tests and raised ferritin. Supplementation of which of the following vitamins should be avoided in this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
This is a clinical vignette of hemochromatosis, characterized by fatigue, joint pain (arthropathy), skin pigmentation, new-onset diabetes, abnormal liver function tests, and elevated ferritin levels. Vitamin C supplementation should be avoided in these patients as it increases iron absorption.

Hemochromatosis is an inherited or acquired metabolic disorder characterized by excess iron absorption and deposition in various organs such as the liver, pancreas, heart, and joints, leading to tissue damage and dysfunction. It consists of a triad of micronodular cirrhosis, bronzing of the skin, and diabetes mellitus.

This occurs due to a mutation causing reduced levels of hepcidin leading to increased absorption of dietary iron. Iron transport is regulated by hepcidin, synthesized in the liver, which is produced in response to high intrahepatic iron levels. Hepcidin binds to ferroportin, causing it to be degraded and thereby reducing plasma iron absorption, as shown below.


Dietary vitamin C supplementation should be avoided as it enhances iron absorption in the gut by reducing it from a ferric (Fe3+) to a ferrous (Fe2+) state, exacerbating iron overload. Alcohol consumption should also be avoided as it increases the risk of cirrhosis. Apart from avoiding supplementation of iron and vitamin C, other dietary adjustments are not necessary (Options A, B, and D). 

Diagnosis is by elevated levels of serum ferritin, serum iron, transferrin saturation, and confirmation by a gene assay. Treatment involves phlebotomy and iron chelators such as deferasirox and deferoxamine.

questions.text:
Match the following :
Disease Defect
1. Leukocyte adhesion defect a. Defect in tyrosine kinase 
2. Bruton's agammaglobulinemia b. Deficiency of CD40L
3. Hyper IgM syndrome c. Adenosine deaminase deficiency
4. Severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) d. Absence of CD18
questions.solution:
The correct answer is -

Disease Defect
1. Leukocyte adhesion defect d. Absence of CD18
2. Bruton's agammaglobulinemia a. Defect in tyrosine kinase 
3. Hyper IgM syndrome b. Deficiency of CD40L
4. Severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) c. Adenosine deaminase deficiency

 

Leukocyte adhesion defect is due to the absence of CD18 (an integrin), which is necessary for the adhesion of leukocytes to the endothelium. Thus leukocytes can't migrate out of the blood vessels to the sites of inflammation.

Bruton's X-linked agammaglobulinemia is due to a defect in Bruton tyrosine kinase (BTK), which is required for the maturation of pre-B cells. Thus the defect leads to the arrest of maturation of pre-B cells and a decrease in the number of mature B cells.

Hyper IgM syndrome is due to deficient CD40L on T-cells. B-cells have CD40 on their surface which interacts with CD40L on T-cells to undergo class switching from IgM to various other classes (IgG, IgA, IgE) depending on the type of antigen. Thus, failure of this class switching leads to an increase in IgM and a decrease in other classes of antibodies.

SCID is due to many defects but the most common cause of an autosomal recessive form of SCID is the deficiency of adenosine deaminase enzyme. Deficiency of this enzyme leads to accumulation of adenosine derivatives inside the cell, which is toxic to them. Since lymphocytes are rapidly diving cells they are most affected by them leading to immunodeficiency.

questions.text: The larval stage of a mosquito is given below. Which of the following is false regarding this species of mosquitoes?

questions.text: During periods of prolonged fasting, one of the following tissues preferentially uses fatty acids as energy-providing substrates. It is because this tissue has the highest concentration of lipoprotein lipase. Identify this tissue.
questions.solution:
The highest concentration of lipoprotein lipase is found in the cardiac muscle. This leads to preferential usage of fatty acids to provide most of the energy needed for cardiac function.

Lipoprotein lipase is an extracellular enzyme which is present in the capillary walls of most tissues. It is chiefly synthesised by the adipose tissue, cardiac and skeletal muscles.

According to the nutritional and hormonal level the expression of tissue specific iso-enzyme takes place :

  • Fed state (elevated insulin ) : LPL is predominant in adipose tissue but decreased in muscle tissue
  • Fasting (decreased insulin ) LPL is more in muscle tissue rather than adipose tissue 

A deficiency of lipoprotein lipase or apo C-II leads to type 1 hyperlipoproteinemia or familial chylomicronemia which leads to increased risk of acute pancreatitis.

Other options :

Lipoprotein lipase is not active in the adult liver. This prevents the degradation of chylomicrons and VLDL in the liver. Instead, the liver has hepatic lipase that is involved in the degradation of chylomicron remnants and HDL.

Lipoprotein lipase is found in the heart, lung, adipose tissue, renal medulla, aorta, diaphragm, lactating mammary gland and spleen.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents to the emergency department at 34 weeks gestation with regular contractions and lower abdominal cramping. Her cervix is found to be 2 cm dilated with 80% effacement. Membranes are intact. She received 1 course of betamethasone for a similar presentation at 33 weeks. What is the appropriate management at this gestational age?

choices.text: Administer tocolytics, corticosteroids and magnesium sulfate

questions.solution:
This is a clinical vignette of preterm labor occurring at 34 weeks of gestation, characterized by regular contractions, lower abdominal cramping, and cervical dilation ≥2 cm with ≥80% effacement. As this mother has received one course of betamethasone, she can be managed by admission and monitoring.

Labor occurring before the 37th completed week is considered preterm labor. It is diagnosed based on the presence of the following signs and symptoms: 

  • Regular contractions (at least one in every 10 minutes)
  • Cervical dilatation (≥2 cm) with effacement (≥ 80%)
  • Cervical length ≤ 2.5 cm and funneling of internal os
  • Pelvic pressure, backache, vaginal discharge or bleeding

Management of preterm labor depends on gestational age:

Single course of corticosteroids for those with:

  • Risk of imminent birth within 7 days (and)
  • Have not received a previous course of antenatal corticosteroids

≥ 37 weeks

Deliver the baby

GBS screening

 

Patients with intact membranes are put to bed to prevent early rupture of membranes, given adequate oxygen, and monitored. Patients with preterm premature rupture of membranes are managed similarly. 

Other options: 

Option A: Magnesium sulfate is indicated in pregnancies < 32 weeks. It is used for fetal neuroprotection and lowers the risk of cerebral palsy.

Option B: Tocolytics are preferably avoided in management, but can be considered to delay pregnancy by 48 hours to administer antenatal corticosteroids < 34 weeks.

Option C: Antenatal corticosteroids are typically indicated in preterm labor < 34 weeks. Intramuscular injections of either 2 doses of 12 mg betamethasone are given 24 hourly or 4 doses of 6 mg dexamethasone are given 12 hourly. A single course of betamethasone is also recommended for mothers between 34 weeks and 36 weeks + 6 days who are at risk for imminent preterm labor within 7 days and have not received a previous course of antenatal corticosteroids. They are however contraindicated in frank chorioamnionitis.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presented with complaints of fever and fatigue for the past few weeks. Examination revealed hepatomegaly and splenomegaly. The peripheral blood smear is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The peripheral blood smear shows numerous Auer rods in the cytoplasm of progranulocytes, characteristic of acute myeloid leukemia (AML).

Acute myeloid leukemia is a spectrum of hematological malignancies where poorly differentiated cells of the hematopoietic stem cells infiltrate the blood and bone marrow. They are the most common acute leukemias in elderly people. Histopathology from bone marrow aspirate reveals Auer rods (needle-like azurophilic granules) in the cytoplasm of the progranulocytes. There is also presence of bilobed nuclei and multiple coarse azurophilic granules. 

Auer rods are predominantly seen in acute promyelocytic leukemia which is a subtype of acute myeloid leukemia. Acute promyelocytic leukemia is associated with t(15;17)(q22;11-12), which results in the formation of the fusion gene called PML-RARa. The condition is associated with a high incidence of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). Treatment includes administration of all-trans retinoic acid.

Other options:

Option A: Acute lymphocytic leukemia present with a hypercellular marrow that is packed with lymphoblasts. These lymphoblasts, when compared to myeloblasts, have more condensed chromatin with less prominent nucleoli. Histochemichal staining show that lymphoblasts are myeloperoxidase-negative and often contain a periodic acid–Schiff–positive cytoplasm.

Option B: Chronic myeloid leukemia is characterised by scattered macrophages with green-blue colored cytoplasm called sea blue histiocytes. 

Option D: Chronic lymphocytic leukemia usually contain proliferation centers that are pathognomonic for chronic lymphocytic leukemia. Smudge cells can also be seen. They are small round lymphocytes with scant cytoplasm that gets disrupted during the process of smearing.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a history of poorly controlled diabetes presents with proteinuria and elevated serum creatinine levels. A renal biopsy reveals a pathognomic finding as shown below. Which of the following stains is used to identify this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and histopathology image showing Kimmelstiel–Wilson nodules suggestive of diabetic glomerulosclerosis. Kimmelstiel-Wilson disease is identified by the presence of acellular periodic acid Schiff (PAS)-positive nodules.


Periodic acid-Schiff detects intracellular glycogen and neutral mucopolysaccharides. 

The following renal lesions are encountered in diabetic nephropathy:

  • Glomerular lesions - Capillary basement membrane thickening, diffuse mesangial sclerosis, nodular glomerulosclerosis/Kimmelstiel–Wilson disease- intercapillary glomerulosclerosis
  • Renal vascular lesions - hyaline arteriolosclerosis
  • Pyelonephritis - necrotizing papillitis

questions.text: A pregnant woman who has a history of preeclampsia delivered a boy at 37 weeks. On the first month postpartum, she complained of dyspnoea and easy fatiguability and on the echocardiogram, she had an ejection fraction of 40%. Which of the following can be expected in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of pregnant women with a history of preeclampsia and showing signs of heart failure with reduced ejection fraction in the postpartum period is suggestive of Peripartum cardiomyopathy which is a type of dilated cardiomyopathy(DCM).

Peripartum cardiomyopathy is defined as newly diagnosed systolic cardiomyopathy (LVEF < 45% or fractional shortening < 30%) without a reversible cause, presenting between the last month of gestation and 5 months postpartum (most commonly in the first month postpartum) in a woman without known CVD. Risk factors include Multiparity, Multiple gestations, Diabetes, Hypertension, preeclampsia, Family history, Race/ethnicity (eg, African American), Smoking and Cocaine use.

Peripartum cardiomyopathy is one of the forms of Dilated cardiomyopathy. DCM is the most common cardiomyopathy and is predominantly characterised by systolic dysfunction. The familial form is due to mutations in the TTN gene which encodes the sarcomeric protein titin. Other etiological agents include alcohol, infective myocarditis, doxorubicin, hemochromatosis and sarcoidosis. 

Other options:

Option A: Restrictive cardiomyopathy (RCM) is characterized by increased ventricular stiffness causing impaired diastolic filling of the ventricles. The stiffness is secondary to an underlying disease causing accumulation of intra and intercellular substances in the myocardium. Causes of RCM include infiltration disorders like amyloidosis (most common) and sarcoidosis, storage disorders like Fabry’s disease and glycogen storage disease type II, fibrotic disorders like scleroderma, endomyocardial fibrosis and Loeffler's endo myocarditis.

Option B: Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) is the most common genetic cardiovascular disorder and is a prominent cause of sudden death before the age of 35 years. Sudden death can be due to polymorphic ventricular tachycardia/fibrillation. 

Option D: Arrhythmogenic ventricular cardiomyopathy is an autosomal dominant disorder that classically manifests with right-sided heart failure and rhythm disturbances, which can cause sudden cardiac death. Many of the causal mutations involve genes encoding desmosomal junctional proteins at the intercalated disk as well as proteins that interact with the desmosome (e.g., the intermediate filament desmin).

questions.text: A patient comes with complaints of bloody vomitus and black coloured stools. His hemoglobin is 7mg/dl. He has a past history of an aortic aneurysm repair 2 weeks ago. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In this patient with hematemesis and malena with a past history of an aortic aneurysm repair, the likely diagnosis is an aortoenteric fistula formation.  

An aortoenteric fistula is a rare complication that occurs after an anomalous fistula is formed between the site of repair after the surgery and the third part of the duodenum. This leads to the patient presenting with initial hematemesis and malena and if untreated, can lead to rapid exsanguination. 

Abdominal aortic aneurysms(AAA) are mostly asymptomatic and are detected as incidental findings on investigations for other complaints. However, as the aneurysm expands, patients may present with lower back or abdominal pain and an associated pulsatile abdominal mass (like seen in this patient). 

These aneurysms present more frequently in males than females and their incidence increases with age. An important underlying cause for the development of this condition is atherosclerosis. Smoking is considered one of the strongest risk factors for the development of this condition. 

Abdominal ultrasound is a useful initial test for screening. CT abdomen with contrast is the preferred investigation of choice to determine the location and size of the aneurysm, which helps guide further management. 

Rupture of the aneurysm is a dreaded complication and usually presents with shock and hypotension. It usually occurs when the size of the aneurysm is more than 5.5 cm. 

Other options: 

Option A: Gastric antral vascular ectasia (GAVE) is also known as watermelon stomach because of the collection of dilated venules that appear as linear red streaks converging on the antrum. It causes chronic occult blood loss. Endoscopy reveals longitudinal stripes of edematous erythematous mucosa that alternate with less severely injured, paler mucosa giving the appearance of watermelon.

Option B: Failure of aneursym repair would lead to exsanguination of blood into the retroperitoneal space and it is unlikely to lead to upper GI bleeding. 

Option D: The sigmoid flexure of the colon is a watershed area and is prone to ischemia after major surgery. However, bleeding from this condition leads to bright red blood in the stools as it is a source of lower GI bleeding.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman came with complaints of milky white discharge with a fishy odour from the vagina and minimum itching. What is the treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 50-year-old woman with a milky white discharge with a fishy odor from the vagina and minimum itching is suggestive of bacterial vaginosis. It is treated with metronidazole 400 mg bd for 7 days.

 Metronidazole, an antibiotic with activity against anaerobes but poor activity against lactobacilli, is the drug of choice for the treatment of BV. A dose of 400 mg administered orally twice a day for 7 days should be used or the same can be given as gel, if available.

Other antibiotics that are used include ampicillin 500 mg or cephalosporin 500 mg b.i.d. for 7 days or tetracycline 500 mg four times a day, doxycycline I00 mg twice a day for 10-14 days.  

Bacterial vaginosis is a polymicrobial infection caused by Mobiluncus curtisii, Gardnerella vaginalis, Mycoplasma hominis, and Haemophilus vaginalis. It has a malodorous (fishy smell) vaginal discharge with minimal vulval irritation.

Amsel's Criteria helps diagnose bacterial vaginosis when 3 of the following 4 are present

  • Thin, white homogenous vaginal discharge
  • A pH of vaginal fluid >4.5
  • Fishy odour of discharge accentuated by adding 10% KOH-Whiff test
  • Presence of Clue cells on microscopy.

Candidiasis is caused by infection with Candida albicans and presents with pruritus, burning, and dysuria with vulvar erythema, edema, and excoriations. A curdy white discharge will be present.

questions.text: A 48-year old man presented with the following skin lesion. It was noted that the lesions got aggravated after he was started on a beta-blocker. What could be the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of psoriasis with the image showing a psoriatic plaque, with a silvery center surrounded by a reddish border.

Plaque/ discoid psoriasis, also known as psoriasis vulgaris accounts for almost 90% of all psoriasis cases. It presents as a papulosquamous rash, with reddish edematous plaques covered with silvery-white scales, which are well-demarcated from unaffected skin with sharply delineated edges. Plaques may be encircled by a clear peripheral zone called the halo or ring of Woronoff. The scalp is one of the most common and first affected areas in plaque psoriasis, while other affected areas include elbows, knees, and back.

It can also be classified based on the site involved:

Plaque psoriasis (most common): sharply demarcated erythematous plaques with silvery scales, commonly present on extensor surfaces (elbows, knees, etc.).


Guttate psoriasis: small scattered erythematous papules with silvery scales; often triggered by infections.


Erythrodermic psoriasis: confluent plaques affecting nearly all of the skin but often sparing the central face, with electrolyte and thermoregulation abnormalities.

Pustular psoriasis: presence of superficial pustules; generalized, annular, palmar-plantar, localized, and exanthemic variants are described.

Scalp psoriasis: well-demarcated plaques on the retro auricular areas and posterior upper neck.

Flexural/ inverse psoriasis: plaques affecting intertriginous folds, scaling may be less prominent.

Napkin psoriasis: may be seen in napkin (diaper) area in newborns.

Nail psoriasis: pits, splinter hemorrhages, oil drop sign (translucent yellow discoloration of the nail caused by parakeratosis of the nail bed), salmon patches, and leukonychia are common on the nail plate.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic was brought to casualty with a history of agitation and hallucinations since the previous day. He had his last drink three days ago. On examination, the patient has generalized tremulousness and tachycardia, and the liver markers are deranged. Which of the following drugs can be safely used in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a chronic alcoholic with agitation and hallucinatory behaviours along with tremors is suggestive of alcohol withdrawal syndrome. Lorazepam is the drug that this patient can use as it can be safely used for liver dysfunction.

Benzodiazepines are the mainstay of treatment of alcohol withdrawal syndrome.

Alcohol withdrawal symptoms include autonomic hyperactivity such as increased pulse rate, blood pressure, and body temperature, restlessness, disturbed sleep, anxiety, nausea, tremors and severe withdrawal involving auditory, visual, or tactile hallucinations, delirium, seizures, and coma.

These are commonly treated with benzodiazepines such as oxazepam, diazepam, chlordiazepoxide, and lorazepam. Diazepam (Option C) and chlordiazepoxide(Option B) require less frequent dosing but are not useful in the elderly or patients with hepatic dysfunction. Due to its short half-life and metabolism through glucuronidation only, lorazepam is best for the treatment of alcohol withdrawal in older adults. Lorazepam and oxazepam can also be used in patients with hepatic dysfunction.

Other options:

Option D:  Mirtazapine is an atypical antidepressant that is a serotonin-norephedrine reuptake inhibitor used in major depressive disorder. It increases appetite and causes significant weight gain.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with longstanding bloody diarrhea and abdominal pain. Colonoscopy reveals pseudopolyps and continuous inflammation involving the rectum which extends proximally in a symmetric, continuous pattern. Biopsy shows crypt distortion and ulceration. The inflammation in this condition commonly extends until which layer?
questions.solution:
This patient has ulcerative colitis (UC) which is characterized by continuous inflammation of the colon, pseudopolyps, biopsy findings of crypt distortion, ulceration, and infiltration of inflammatory cells until the submucosal layer of the intestinal wall.

UC is a type of inflammatory bowel disease that primarily affects the rectum and extends proximally to involve the colon. Patients typically present with diarrhea, rectal bleeding, tenesmus, crampy abdominal pain, and mucus discharge. They may also present with anorexia, nausea, vomiting, fever, and weight loss.

Barium enema in UC shows complete loss of haustral markings in the diseased section of the colon, and the organ appears smooth-walled and cylindrical, giving it the appearance of a lead pipe. Diagnosis can be made by colonoscopy followed by a biopsy. Salazopyrine/Sulfasalazine and Mesalamine (5 ASA) are used in first-line therapy of UC. Steroids are used in refractory cases.

The presentation of UC differs from that of Crohn's disease, which is characterized by transmural inflammation (Option D) of the intestine.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman is scheduled to undergo 4 cycles of chemotherapy. After her first cycle, she developed thrombocytopenia with a platelet count of 19,000/mm3. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis for this patient is chemotherapy-induced thrombocytopenia. Oprelvekin is an IL-11 analog used in the prophylaxis and treatment of chemotherapy-induced thrombocytopenia. IL-11 stimulates the megakaryocytes to mature into platelets.

Other options:

2) Filgrastim is a G-CSF (Granulocyte- Colony Stimulating Factor), which is used for neutropenia.

3) Darbepoetin alfa is a modified form of erythropoietin, which stimulates erythroid proliferation. It is used to treat anemia in patients with chronic renal failure, HIV-infected patients treated with zidovudine and in cancer patients treated with myelosuppressive cancer chemotherapy 

4)Intravenous immunoglobulins are prepared from pools of thousands of healthy donors and used in the treatment of a number of conditions like primary immunodeiciency disorders, Kawasaki disease, immune thrombocytopenic purpura, Guillain Barre syndrome and chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy, . They have no role in the treatment of chemotherapy-induced thrombocytopenia.

questions.text: A few natives residing on the slopes of the Himalayas have been recruited as subjects for a project aiming to study the pathophysiological changes in people living at high altitudes. Which of the following would you not expect to find in their test results?

choices.text: Greater than normal pulmonary arterial blood pressure
Increase in the quantity of myoglobin

questions.solution:
Decreased bicarbonate levels are seen in people acclimatized to low partial pressures of oxygen.

People living at high altitudes for prolonged periods become acclimatized to the low partial pressures of oxygen and their body undergoes certain pathophysiological changes as compensatory mechanisms.

Initially, there is an increase in pulmonary ventilation in response to hypoxia, which drives out large amounts of carbon dioxide. The resulting respiratory alkalosis causes the kidneys to reduce hydrogen ion secretion and increase bicarbonate excretion over a few days, thereby aiming to bring the pH toward the normal range. Hence, there is lower than-normal levels of plasma bicarbonate.

Other options:

Option A - Raised hematocrit is a compensatory mechanism that occurs in people chronically exposed to low levels of oxygen. This occurs due to the activation of erythropoietin genes and helps in meeting the tissue oxygen demands in a hypoxic environment.

Option C- In the context of chronic hypoxia, the pulmonary arterial pressure rises, which forces blood into a greater number of alveolar capillaries, especially in the upper parts of the lungs which are poorly perfused under usual conditions. Chronic hypoxic stimuli of high altitude living can result in permanent pulmonary vascular remodeling due to increased pulmonary vascular resistance and lead to pulmonary hypertension. 

Option D - An increase in myoglobin is another compensatory mechanism, which helps facilitate greater movement of oxygen in the muscle tissue.

Related Pearl: Acclimatization to high altitude

questions.text: The recent Air Quality Index (AQI) in Delhi was reported to be 250. Which of the following parameters is included in the calculation of AQI?
questions.solution:
Lead is likely to be elevated as it is the only parameter considered out of the given options while calculating the AQI.

Air Quality Index (AQI) is a tool used for effective communication of air quality status on a scale that is easily comprehensible. Complex air quality data of various pollutants are compiled to give a single score (index value), nomenclature and colour that determines the air pollution of that particular location.

Eight pollutants are taken into consideration to calculate the AQI - 

  • PM10 (Airborne particulate matter with a diameter of 10 microns or less)

questions.text: A patient who was on selegiline as an adjunct  treatment for parkinsonism develops stupor, rigidity, agitation, and hyperthermia when administered with meperidine which is an analgesic medication. What’s the likely cause of the patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of stupor, rigidity, agitation, and hyperthermia in a patient who was on selegiline will develop serotonin syndrome when administered with meperidine. 

Selegiline is a selective and irreversible MAO-B inhibitor that increases the levels of serotonin and dopamine (MAO-A preferentially metabolizes serotonin, norepinephrine, and dopamine; MAO-B is effective against serotonin and dopamine). 

It is contraindicated with SSRI, SNRI, TCA, meperidine, dextromethorphan, St. John's wort, pseudoephedrine, and linezolid (to avoid seratonin syndrome).

Serotonin syndrome is characterized by a triad of:

  • Autonomic instability - hyperthermia, hypertension, tachycardia, diaphoresis, vomiting, diarrhea
  • Altered mental status - agitation, confusion, delirium
  • Neuromuscular hyperactivity - tremor, hyperreflexia, myoclonus

It is treated with cyproheptadine (5-HT2 receptor antagonist). 

Other options:

Option A: Neuroleptic malignant syndrome presents with extreme rigidity, fever, unstable blood pressure, and myoglobinemia. It occurs after weeks and months of starting antipsychotics due to dopamine antagonism. In the case of neuroleptic malignant syndrome - Stop the antipsychotic immediately and give supportive care along with dantrolene. 

Option B: Akathisia is a sense of restlessness. Propranolol is used for the management of akathisia.

Option D: Peri oral tremor is also known as rabbit syndrome as seen after months of treatment with antipsychotic due to dopamine antagonism.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient was referred from the infertility clinic with abnormal semen analysis reports. On local examination, there is a ‘bag of worms’ like feel on the left side of the scrotum. All are true regarding the following condition except?

choices.text: It is associated with Nutcracker syndrome
Infertility is due to lack of blood flow to the testis
Similar isolated finding on the right side should be evaluated for a retroperitoneal mass
Percutaneous embolization is the usual first line management

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests a left-sided varicocele and the incorrect statement regarding varicocele is infertility is due to lack of blood flow to the testis. (Option B)

The pathogenesis behind varicocele is due to increased blood flow to the testis leading to higher intratesticular temperatures, which inhibits spermatogenesis and results in low sperm count, motility and morphology. Large varicoceles may eventually cause testicular failure,ultimately resulting in low testosterone production.

A varicocele is characterized by abnormal dilation and enlargement of the scrotal venous pampiniform plexus, which drains blood from each testicle. Majority of them present as left sided boggy or ‘bag of worms’ like scrotal swelling, since the left testicular vein drains into the relatively high-pressure left renal vein while the right testicular vein drains into the low-pressure inferior vena cava below the right renal vein.

They typically develop during late childhood and adolescence and presents as infertility in adulthood.Other symptoms include dragging sensation to the left side that is worse on standing at the end of the day. When examined in the erect position, the scrotum on the affected side often hangs lower than normal and on palpation, with the patient standing, the varicose plexus feels like a ‘bag of worms’ and cough impulse may be present. Testicular atrophy maybe seen in long standing cases.

While most varicoceles are idiopathic, obstruction of the testicular vein by a renal tumor or nephrectomy is a cause of varicocele in later life; characteristically, in such cases, the varicocele does not decompress in the supine position. The presence of an isolated right-sided varicocele is rare. Hence, imaging should be considered to exclude a retroperitoneal mass in such cases.

Treatment includes percutaneous embolisation of the gonadal veins as first line management or surgical ligation of the testicular veins. Both procedures are associated with upto 20% recurrence rates. Newer procedures such as microsurgical varicocelectomy have been proved to be more effective than existing treatment modalities.

Nutcracker syndrome - It is the left renal vein entrapment syndrome, characterized by extrinsic compression of the left renal vein, most commonly between the abdominal aorta and superior mesenteric artery and is one of the postulated reasons for left sided varicoceles being more common than the right side.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman presented to the OPD with fever, dysuria, and frequent micturition. Urine analysis showed pus cells. Gram staining shows gram-negative rods and culture on MacConkey agar shows non-lactose fermenting colonies. The test for the presence of phenylalanine deaminase gives the result shown in the image. Which of the following organisms is likely to be involved?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of urinary tract infection, with a gram-negative rod forming non-lactose fermenting colonies on MacConkey's agar, and the image of a positive phenyl pyruvic acid (PPA) reaction are suggestive of Proteus infection.

The phenyl pyruvic acid (PPA) reaction is a characteristic feature that distinguishes Proteus from other enterobacteria. All members of the Proteus tribe have the enzyme phenylalanine deaminase which converts phenylalanine to phenyl pyruvic acid. Phenyl pyruvic acid imparts a green color. The test is given below:


Proteus is a gram-negative bacillus seen as a normal gastrointestinal flora. The two most common species causing infection in humans are P. mirabilis and P. vulgaris, which can be differentiated by spot indole test. P. mirabilis is indole negative while P. vulgaris is indole positive. Production of urease enzyme by Proteus, which hydrolyses urea to ammonia causes alkalinization of urine. Alkalinization of urine leads to the precipitation of organic and inorganic compounds which contributes to the formation of Struvite stones.

P. mirabilis is associated with urinary tract infections while P. vulgaris is usually associated with wound and soft tissue infections. 

On solid culture media such as blood agar, Proteus shows swarming motility due to the presence of peritrichous flagella. It is characterized by expanding rings (waves) of organisms over the surface of the agar (shown in the image below). However, swarming is inhibited on MacConkey agar due to the presence of bile.


Enterobacteriaceae family is classified based on their action on lactose present in MacConkey's medium as:

Lactose fermenters

Escherichia, Klebsiella,Enterobacter 

Late lactose fermenters

Shigella sonnei, Serratia, Citrobacter, Erwinia

Non-lactose fermenters

Salmonella, Shigella, Proteus

Mnemonic to remember Non-lactose fermenters: SPY PSM

  • Salmonella
  • Proteus
  • Yersinia
  • Providencia - late fermenter
  • Shigella (Except S Sonnie which is a late lactose fermenter)
  • Morganella

Other options:

Klebsiella (Option A) and Enterobacter (Option D) are lactose-fermenters on MacConkey's medium. Serratia (Option C) is a late lactose fermenter.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented with Parkinsonian features which is unresponsive to levodopa. MRI image is given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
An elderly male with a history of features of Parkinsonism nonresponsive to levodopa should raise suspicion for Parkinson plus syndrome or Atypical parkinsonism. The given MRI showing the hummingbird sign is suggestive of progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP).

Progressive supranuclear palsy is a type of atypical Parkinson's disease that is characterised by an aggressive clinical course and early involvement of speech and gait, absence of rest tremors, decreased cognition, abnormal eye movements (supranuclear vertical gaze palsy), postural instability and falls, as well as Parkinsonian features and speech disturbances. 

Progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP), also known as the Steele-Richardson-Olszewski syndrome, is a tauopathy and is considered a neurodegenerative disease with no current efficacious treatment. 

The atrophy of the midbrain results in hummingbird sign of the brainstem (in the sagittal plane). The preserved pons form the body of the bird, and the atrophic midbrain, the head, with beak extending anteriorly towards the optic chiasm. Midbrain atrophy is best confirmed with the reduction in the midbrain to pons ratio.

Mickey mouse appearance, which is the reduction of anteroposterior midline midbrain diameter, at the level of the superior colliculi is seen on axial imaging.

questions.text: Which one of the following is NOT a feature of re-feeding syndrome?
questions.solution:
Refeeding syndrome is associated with hypophosphatemia, hypocalcemia, and hypomagnesemia.

Refeeding syndrome is a potentially lethal condition that can occur with rapid and excessive feeding of patients with severe underlying malnutrition due to starvation, alcoholism, delayed nutritional support, anorexia nervosa, or massive weight loss in obese patients.

It can occur with both enteral and parenteral nutrition but is more common with the latter. Electrolyte abnormalities can result in cardiac failure and dysrhythmias, respiratory failure, neu­rologic disturbances, and renal and hepatic dysfunction.


Prevention: Caloric replenishment should be instituted slowly and increased gradually over the first week. Vital signs, fluid balance, and electrolytes should be closely monitored and any deficits should be corrected as they evolve.

Thiamine should be administered before the initiation of feeding. Since thiamine is an important cofactor for the metabolism of glucose and the conversion of lactate to pyruvate. When the body is replenished following starvation as in refeeding syndrome, thiamine requirements increase, and lactate levels can accumulate.

Thiamine deficiency leads to neurological manifestations(dry beri-beri) such as Wernicke's encephalopathy(memory impairment, ophthalmoplegia, ataxia) and Korsakoff syndrome (anterograde/retrograde amnesia, confabulation). Thiamine deficiency has also been implicated in cardiac tissue dysfunction due to insufficient ATP production(wet beri-beri).

questions.text: A 75-year-old woman with the complaints of mass per vagina, as shown in the below image was posted for operative repair. During a pre-anesthetic check-up, she was found to be unfit for major surgery. Which of the following procedures is recommended in her?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and the image is suggestive of severe uterine prolapse in elderly women. Le Fort’s repair is recommended in this case.

This repair is done in patients who satisfy the following criteria:

  • Very elderly menopausal patient with an advanced prolapse
  • Do not wish to retain sexual function
  • Medically unfit for major surgeries

This procedure can be performed under sedation and local anesthesia, or epidural anesthesia. The vaginal flaps from the anterior and posterior vaginal walls are excised, the raw areas are apposed in the midline with catgut sutures. This prevents the uterus from prolapsing.

This operation limits marital functions; hence, it should not be advised in women who wish to retain sexual function.

Other options

Abdominal sling operations are designed for women with type II or III degree prolapse and who are desirous of retaining childbearing function and menstrual function.

Sling operations are best suited to nulliparous prolapse. It includes,

  • Abdominal wall cervicopexy (Option A) 
  • Shirodkar’s abdominal sling operation (Option B) 
  • Khanna’s abdominal sling operation (Option D)

questions.text: A healthy 22-year-old lady presents to the casualty with sudden onset loss of vision and pain in her right eye for the past 2 days.  Fundal examination is normal, but when light is shone on the pupils, there is an ill-sustained constriction to light. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient's history of sudden onset loss of vision with a normal fundus and Marcus Gunn pupil suggests the diagnosis of retrobulbar neuritis.

Retrobulbar neuritis is a type of optic neuritis which involves the optic nerve behind the eyeball. The fundus appears normal in majority of the cases. Marcus Gunn pupil (ill-sustained constriction to light) can be seen and it is elicited using the swinging flashlight test. Color vision is also impaired.

Investigations include MRI brain and orbit to rule out multiple sclerosis as retrobulbar neuritis is often one of its earliest symptoms. Multifocal VEP is also useful for diagnosis. The condition is managed by treating causes and corticosterid therapy (intravenous methylprednisolone in case of multiple sclerosis).

Other types of pupillary defects have been compared below.

 

Marcus Gunn pupil

 Adie’s tonic pupil Argyll Robertson pupil
Etiology

Incomplete optic nerve lesions

Severe retinal diseases

 Unknown etiology Caused by neurosyphilis
Pupil size Equal in size Dilated pupil compared to counterpart Slightly smaller pupil compared to counterpart (spinal miosis)

Reaction to near reflex

Present 

(Accommodation Reflex Present/ARP )

Reaction to 

light reflex

 Relative afferent pupillary defect Sluggish slight constriction 

No light reflex

(light near dissociation)

 

Option B: Argyll Robertson pupil occurs due to neurosyphilis and requires syphilis serology testing. Serology testing is the mainstay of investigation. Neurosyphilis is ruled out by a lumbar puncture. 

Option C: Amblyopia is the partial and reversible loss of vision for which no cause is found on ocular physical examination. It can occur due to strabismus, stimulus deprivation, anisometropia, etc. 

Option D: Papillitis is a type of optic neuritis where the optic disc is involved. Marcus Gunn pupil is also present in this case, however, on fundus examination, there would be characteristic disc hyperemia and blurring of the margins. The retinal veins are congested and splinter hemorrhages as well as fine exudates can be seen on the optic disc.

Attached below is the image showing the swinging flashlight test as well as the explanation:

 

It is elicited as explained below:

A flashlight is shone at the normal eye. When the normal eye is stimulated, both pupils constrict. The flashlight is then swung to the diseased eye. This causes both the pupils to dilate.

Normally, when the input from both optic nerves to the Edinger-Westphal nucleus is the same, the pupil to which light is being transferred remains constricted due to consensual light reflex.

However, with a diseased optic nerve, the input from the diseased side is reduced. Hence, when light is transferred to the diseased eye, both the pupils will dilate. And on swinging the light back to the normal eye, both pupils will constrict again.  This 'escape dilatation' is known as a relative afferent pupillary defect/Marcus Gunn pupil.

questions.text: A patient who is a known case of peptic ulcer disease came with features suggestive of peritonitis and underwent emergency laparotomy. The wound is closed by the following technique. What is true regarding the technique shown?

choices.text: It provides positive pressure to the wound
Continuous pressure leads to faster wound healing
Reduces the need of skin grafting procedures
Air gaps should be present for wound culture sampling

questions.solution:
The technique used to close the wound is negative pressure dressing/therapy otherwise also called vacuum assisted closure. The true statement regarding the technique is that they reduce the need of skin grafting procedures.(Option C)

Vacuum-assisted closure (VAC) is a method of wound management, which uses negative pressure(Option A) for spontaneous healing or by lesser reconstructive options. Negative pressure therapy stabilizes the wound environment by reducing wound edema and bacterial load,as well as improves tissue perfusion by angiogenesis and thereby stimulating granulation tissue formation. All this improves the possibility of primary closure of wounds and reduces the need for plastic procedures.

Method of VAC application includes thorough debridement, adequate haemostasis and application of sterile foams dressing. A fenestrated tube is embedded in the foam and the wound is sealed with adhesive tape to make it airtight. The fenestrated tube is connected to a vacuum pump with a fluid collection container. The ideal pressure applied is 125 mm Hg. 

VAC therapy is simpler and more effective than conventional dressings for the management of difficult wounds in terms of reduction in wound volume, depth, treatment duration and cost effective.

Indications of VAC therapy includes diabetic foot ulcers, bed sores,burn injuries,crush injuries, sternal/abdominal wound dehiscence, fasciotomy wounds and animal bites/frostbite wounds.

VAC therapy is contraindicated in patients with malignant wounds such as Marjolin’s ulcer,untreated osteomyelitis, presence of fistulae or necrotic tissue underneath the dressing.

Other options - 

Option B - Intermittent pressure application is more effective than continuous pressure for faster wound healing as it generates more blood flow during vacuum “off” phase as well as increases granulation tissue formation almost twice faster than continuous pressure.

Option D - Air leak in the dressing should be avoided as it leads to continual flow of air over the wound surface leading to desiccation of tissue and eschar formation. This eschar seals the wound with retained exudate and leads to worsening of the wound.The pressure in VAC dressing gradually reduces over 48 hours therefore, dressings should be changed on the 3rd day. Wound culture samples can be taken when changing VAC dressings.

questions.text: Which of the following disorders is related to the triangle shown below?
questions.solution:
The image depicts Passaro’s triangle, which is related to gastrinomas. Around 90% of gastrinomas are found within this triangle. 

The three points forming this triangle are the junction of the cystic duct and the common bile duct, the junction of the second and third portion of the duodenum, and the junction of the neck and body of the pancreas.

Zollinger-Ellison syndrome (ZES)/Gastrinoma is a neuroendocrinal tumor characterized by hypersecretion of gastrin resulting in gastrointestinal tract ulcers. It occurs more commonly in a sporadic pattern but can be associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia-1 (MEN-1) syndromes in the familial pattern.

Other options:

Option (A): Insulinomas are insulin-secreting tumors of the pancreas that cause hypoglycemia. They are found either in the pancreas or attached directly to it. They are not found specifically within this kind of anatomical triangle. 

Option (B): Glucagonoma should be suspected when a patient has diabetes associated with dermatitis. Necrolytic migratory erythema is one of the classical skin manifestations seen in these patients. These tumors are found in the body and tail of the pancreas.

Option (D): Vasoactive intestinal peptide tumor (VIPoma) is also called watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, and achlorhydria (WDHA) syndrome. It is a tumor that is most commonly found in the distal pancreas.

Related Pearl: Passaro’s Triangle

Around 90% of gastrinomas are found in this triangle.

Its boundaries are as follows:

  • Junction of the cystic duct and common bile duct
  • Junction of the 2nd and 3rd parts of the duodenum
  • Junction of the body and neck of the pancreas

Related Pearl: Clinical features of gastrinoma (Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome)

Most common symptom: Abdominal pain.

Gastrin hypersecretion stimulates gastric acid secretion, leading to peptic ulcers that occur at atypical sites like the duodenum and jejunum and are refractory and multiple.

Diarrhea is due to

  • Acid-induced injury to the small intestine mucosa
  • Inability of the intestinal tract to absorb large volumes of fluids secreted by the stomach
  • Inactivation of pancreatic lipase by low pH
  • Precipitation of bile salts.

The unique characteristic of acid-induced diarrhea is that it is controlled by nasogastric aspiration of gastric secretions.

Related Pearl: Pancreatic Endocrine Neoplasms

Present as mass lesions as even high plasma levels of this hormone fail to cause symptoms

Islet hyperplasia (previously known as nesidioblastosis) is seen in maternal diabetes, Beckwith–Wiedemann syndrome , and rare mutations in the β-cell K+-channel protein or sulfonylurea receptor.

In maternal diabetes, the fetal islets respond to hyperglycemia by increasing their size and number. In the postnatal period, these hyperactive islets may be responsible for serious episodes of hypoglycemia.

questions.text: While evaluating a child with glomerulonephritis, you notice the renal biopsy specimens show ANCA-positive glomerulonephritis with the absence of granulomatous inflammation. Which of the following small vessel vasculitis is this child likely to be suffering from?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of microscopic polyangiitis. The absence of granulomatous inflammation differentiates microscopic polyangiitis from other forms of ANCA-associated vasculitis. 

Anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA)-associated vasculitis is categorized into 3 distinct forms: 

  • Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA; formerly Wegener granulomatosis)
  • Microscopic polyangiitis (MPA)
  • Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis, formerly called Churg–Strauss syndrome (CSS) 

Necrotizing vasculitis is the cardinal histologic feature in both GPA and MPA. Kidney biopsies typically demonstrate crescentic glomerulonephritis with little or no immune complex deposition. hence the name “pauci-immune vasculitis.”

Granulomatous inflammation is typically absent in MPA but is common in both GPA and CSS.

ANCA-associated vasculitis (AAV) comprises a group of multi-systemic diseases affecting small-to-medium-sized vessels. It is characterized by the presence of ANCA with specificity for either proteinase-3 (PR3) or myeloperoxidase (MPO).

Other options:

Wegener granulomatosis: It is now known as Granulomatosis with polyangiitis(GPA). It is a necrotizing granulomatous vasculitis affecting the small and medium-sized vessels. It usually targets the respiratory tracts(both upper and lower) and the kidneys.

Churg-Strauss syndrome: It is necrotizing granulomatous small vessel vasculitis with a history of bronchial asthma and peripheral eosinophilia.

Henoch–Schonlein purpura: It is the most common vasculitis of childhood. It is characterized by leukocytoclastic vasculitis and IgA deposition in the skin, kidney, joints, and GIT. The clinical manifestations include palpable purpura, joint involvement in the form of arthritis or arthralgias, diarrhea, vomiting, renal involvement in the form of microscopic hematuria, proteinuria, etc.

Related Pearl: Microscopic polyangiitis v/s granulomatosis with polyangiitis

questions.text: A body was found in a forest. The image is given below. What is the reason for this discolouration seen on the dependant portion?
questions.solution:
The postmortem change given in the image is suggestive of postmortem hypostasis. The reason for this discolouration seen is due to the formation of deoxyhemoglobin.

Postmortem hypostasis/Postmortem staining/Postmortem lividity/Livor mortis/Suggilation refers to bluish-purple or reddish-purple discolouration of the superficial layers of the skin due to the collection of blood in toneless capillaries. 

It is an early postmortem change that occurs due to engorged vessels showing through the skin seen on the dependent parts due to the pooling of blood under the effect of gravity. 

This staining starts as mottled patches 1-3 hours following death and develops to a uniform area of staining in 3-6 hours. Full development and fixation of hypostasis occur within 6-12 hours. This finding usually develops within 4 hours and persists until putrefaction. Fixation of hypostasis occurs earlier in summer. It is delayed in asphyxial deaths and intracranial lesions.  

Any pressure prevents the capillaries from filling, such as the collar band, wrist band, belts, wrinkles in the clothes, etc. and such areas remain free from colour and are seen as strips or bands called vibices.
