questions.text: Which of the following processes is unlikely to be seen in the water purification system depicted below?
questions.solution:
The blueprint depicts a slow sand filter which is identified by the presence of the supernatant water and sand bed layer. The purification processes involved are oxidation, mechanical straining, and adsorption.

Coagulation is the first step involved in rapid sand filters where raw water is treated with a chemical coagulant like alum, the dose of which varies from 5 to 40 mg or more per litre depending upon colour, turbidity, temperature, and pH value of the water.

Comparison between rapid and slow sand filters: 

Property Rapid sand filter Slow sand filter
Space Less space Large area
Rate of filtration 200 m.g.a.d 2–3 m.g.a.d
Effective size of sand 0.4–0.7 mm 0.2–0.3 mm
Preliminary treatment Chemical coagulation and sedimentation Plain sedimentation 
Washing Backwashing Scraping the sand bed
Operation Highly skilled Less skilled
Loss of head 2–2.5 m/6–8 feet 1.5 m/4 feet
Removal of turbidity Good Good
Removal of color Good Fair 
Removal of bacteria 98–99% 99.9–99.99% 

 

Related Pearl: Slow Sand Filters

  • These are also called biological filters.
  • They are accepted as the standard method of large scale water purification.
  • Essentially, elements of a slow sand filter include
    • Supernatant (raw) water
    • Bed of graded sand
    • Under-drainage system
    • System of filter control valves
  • Supernatant water:
    • It lies above the sand bed and its depth varies from 1 – 1.5 metres.
    • The level of supernatant or raw water is always kept constant and this helps in overcoming the resistance of filter bed, promoting the downward flow of water through the sand bed.
    • It also provides for a waiting period during which the water undergoes partial purification by sedimentation, oxidation and particle agglomeration.
  • Sand bed:
    • This is the most important part of a slow sand filter.
    • Its thickness is generally around 1 metre.
    • The sand grains must be rounded and have an effective diameter of 0.2 – 0.3 mm. They must be clean and free from organic matter.
    • A layer of supporting, graded gravel, 30 – 40 cm deep, prevents the grains from being carried into drainage pipes.
    • The sand bed filters the water as it percolates slowly through it through processes like mechanical straining, oxidation, sedimentation and adsorption.
    • Vital layer: In a new filter, the bed merely acts as a mechanical strainer. But over time the sand bed get covered with a Schmutzdecke/vital layer/zoogleal layer/biological layer. This is a slimy and gelatinous layer that contains algae, diatoms and plankton. The formation of such a layer is the ripening of the filter and this layer is the heart of a slow sand filter. It removes organic matter, prevents bacteria from flowing through and oxidizes ammoniacal nitrogen into nitrates, thus rendering the water bacteria-free.
  • Under-drainage system:
    • A system of porous and perforated pipes, at the bottom of the filter bed, is part of the under-drainage system.
    • They provide an outlet for the filtered water and a support to the filter medium above.
    • The under-drainage system along with the supernatant water and sand bed is kept in a filter box, which is usually 2.5 to 4 metres.
  • Filter control:
    • The outlet-pipe system is provided with valves and other devices which maintain a constant rate of filtration.
    • The Venturi meter measures the bed resistance or the loss of head.
    • When the resistance builds up, the operator opens the regulatory valve to maintain a steady-state of filtration.
    • When the loss of head exceeds 1.5 metres (4 feet), it is uneconomical to run the filter.
    • If the regulatory valve has to be kept fully open as the bed resistance is very high, the filter needs to be cleaned.
    • This is done by scraping the sand bed, which doesn’t need to be done by skilled labor. After several years of operation (say 20 to 30 scrappings) the sand bed can be changed as it would have diminished in size.
  • Advantages of slow sand filters:
    • Simple to construct and operate.
    • Cost of construction is cheap compared to rapid sand filters.
    • Physical, chemical and bacteriological quality of the water is very high which is partially owed to the long duration taken for filtration.
    • Bacteria are cleared more effectively than rapid filters.

Related Pearl: Rapid Sand Filters

  • They are also called mechanical filters and are another method of large scale purification of water.
  • The two types of rapid sand filters are gravity type (e.g. Paterson’s filter) and pressure type (e.g. Candy’s filter).
  • Steps in the purification of water by rapid sand filters are:
    • Coagulation – Raw water is first treated with a chemical coagulant like alum.
    • Rapid mixing – The treated water then undergoes violent agitation in a mixing chamber which allows complete dissemination of alum throughout the bulk of the water.
    • Flocculation – Slow and gentle mixing of water in a flocculation chamber is done for 30 minutes. This results in a thick, copious flocculate of aluminium hydroxide.
    • Sedimentation – The coagulated water is moved into sedimentation tanks where detaining it for 2 – 6 hours will result in the settling down of the flocculent along with impurities and bacteria. This is to be removed before the filtration takes place.
    • Filtration – The partly purified water is then subjected to rapid sand filtration.
      • Filter beds: The effective size of the sand particles/grains is about 0.4 to 0.7 mm. The depth of the sand bed is about 1 metre and has graded gravel below it.
      • As the filtration is done, the alum-floc which has not precipitated is held back by the sand bed. This forms a layer which adsorbs bacteria and other impurities. When the loss of head in a rapid sand filter approaches 7 – 8 feet, the filter needs to be cleaned by a process known as backwashing.
      • Backwashing is done by reversing the flow of water through the sand bed. It dislodges the impurities and cleans the bed. Skilled labor is needed for this purpose.
    • Advantages of rapid sand filter:
      • Rapid sand filter does not need storage of water before it is treated.
      • It occupies less space when compared to slow sand filters.
      • Filtration is much more rapid than slow sand filters.
      • It is easy to wash and clean.
      • There is more flexibility in its operation.

Related Pearl: Purification of Water

Purification of water can be done on a large scale or small scale.

I) Purification of water on a large scale is done by one or more of the following measures:

  • Storage
  • Filtration:
    • Slow sand filters
    • Rapid sand filters
  • Disinfection:
    • Chlorination
    • Ozonation
    • UV radiation
    • Membrane processes like reverse osmosis, nanofiltration, ultrafiltration and microfiltration.

II) Purification of water on a small scale:

  • Household purification of water:
    • Boiling
    • Chemical disinfection using bleaching powder, chlorine solution, high test hypochlorite, chlorine tablets, iodine and potassium permanganate.
    • Filtration using Pasteur Chamberland filter, Berkefeld filters or Katadyn filters.
    • UV radiation
    • Multi-stage reverse osmosis
  • Disinfection of wells with bleaching powder

questions.text: Which of the following salivary gland neoplasm is responsible for the given appearance in the Tc-99m radionuclide scan?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, Warthin's tumor is the salivary gland tumor that appears as a hot spot on the technetium-99m scan as shown in the image.

Because of the high mitochondrial content within oncocytes, the oncocyte-rich Warthin's tumor and oncocytomas incorporate technetium-99m and appear as hot spots on radionuclide scans.

Warthins tumor or papillary cystadenoma lymphomatosum is the second most common benign tumor of the parotid gland. It is seen in elderly male smokers. It is a slow-growing, benign, well-encapsulated cystic tumor and involves the lower pole of the parotid gland. It usually occurs unilaterally.

Treatment is superficial parotidectomy.

Grossly, they appear as round to oval encapsulated masses, 2-5 cm in diameter, easily palpable in the superficial parotid. Transection reveals a pale grey surface punctuated by cleft-like spaces filled with mucinous or serous secretions.

The image below shows the gross appearance of Warthin's tumor. Note the well-encapsulated mass.

Histologically, Warthin's tumor shows epithelial and lymphoid elements. The epithelium typically consists of a double layer of oncocytic epithelial cells, with a columnar luminal layer and a cuboidal layer. 


Other options:

Only a minority of salivary gland tumors show uptake on 99Tc scintigraphy. They include:

  • Warthins tumor
  • Oncocytoma of salivary glands

Tc-99m radionuclide scan is not done for pleomorphic adenoma, mucoepidermoid carcinoma, and adenoid cystic carcinoma as they show variable uptake. 

Option A: Pleomorphic adenomas are the most common salivary gland neoplasms and it most commonly involves the parotid gland (in about 60% of the cases). These are benign and mixed tumors that consist of a mixture of ductal (epithelial), myoepithelial, and mesenchymal cells. They present in the buccal cavity, parotid, or submandibular area as a painless, slow-growing, mobile mass.

Histopathology:

Grossly, the tumor is rounded and well-demarcated, measuring <6 cm in the greatest dimension. They are usually encapsulated, except in some areas such as the palate. The cut surface is gray-white with myxoid and blue translucent areas of the chondroid (cartilage-like) stroma (image given below).

Microscopic features include the epithelial elements which resemble ductal cells or myoepithelial cells and these are arranged as ducts, acini, irregular tubules, strands, or sheets of cells. They are dispersed within a background of loose myxoid and hyaline tissue containing islands of cartilage and, rarely, foci of bone.

The image below shows pleomorphic adenoma of the salivary gland consisting of mixed epithelial (left) and mesenchymal cell components (right).

Option C: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma is the most common primary malignant tumor of the salivary gland, commonly affecting the parotid gland. Mucinous, intermediate, and squamous elements, with small to large mucus-filled vacuoles are seen in histopathology. The image is shown below.

Option D: Adenoid cystic carcinoma is a malignant tumor that involves minor salivary glands, commonly the palatine glands. Histology shows tumor cells resemble swiss cheese due to an organized cribriform growth pattern. The image is shown below.

Related Pearl: Important points regarding salivary gland tumors

  • Most common neoplasm of the salivary gland: Pleomorphic adenoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common benign tumor of the salivary gland in children: Hemangioma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland in children: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the minor salivary glands: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Most common gland affected by pleomorphic adenomas: Parotid gland
  • Tumor of the salivary gland with perineural invasion: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Tumor that shows a hot spot in 99mTc scan: Warthin’s tumor

questions.text: A middle-aged man was diagnosed with malaria. His body temperature measured 39°C. Which curve in the graph below and its description depict the compensatory mechanism adapted by his body at this phase?

choices.text: Red curve-Increased evaporative heat loss by shivering
Red curve-Increased heat production by shivering
Blue curve-Increased heat production by sweating
Blue curve-Increased evaporative heat loss by sweating

questions.solution:
The correct answer is blue curve-increased evaporative heat loss by sweating. 

The graph here depicts the effect of hypothalamic temperature control centers on changing core body temperature below or above the critical level of 37.1°C (98.8°F).

The blue curve depicts a sharp increase in the rate of evaporative heat loss, resulting from sweating when core body temperature rises above 37.1°C. As in the given clinical scenario, the body temperature is 39oC , the compensatory mechanism is by sweating resulting in heat loss and thereby reducing the body temperature to the normal core temperature(critical temperature).

The red curve depicts a sharp increase in heat production from shivering when core body temperature falls below 37.1°C. Even though option B is correct factually, it is not the compensatory mechanism expected in the given clinical scenario.

questions.text: A pathologist is studying a unique form of programmed cell death which is triggered by microbial infection and is accompanied by the release of interleukin-1. Which of the following is involved in triggering this process?
questions.solution:
The type of programmed cell death triggered by microbial infection and accompanied by interleukin-1 release is called pyroptosis, a variant of apoptosis. Activation of the inflammasome is primarily involved in triggering downstream effects of pyroptosis.

Inflammasomes are involved in pyroptosis, a process of programmed cell death distinct from apoptosis and necrosis. The phenomenon of pyroptosis is an inflammatory form of cell death involving the upregulation of the proinflammatory enzyme caspase-1 and the release of the proinflammatory cytokine IL-1 β. This process is dependent on caspases 1, 4, and 5 and is responsible for killing infected cells. 

It occurs in the following sequence:

  • Activation of inflammasome complex by infected cells. Inflammasomes are involved in the recognition and clearance of necrotic cells.
  • This causes activation of caspase-1.
  • This results in the generation of IL-1, which is responsible for fever, inflammation, and leukocyte recruitment.

questions.text: Which of the following tumors will exhibit the least amount of apoptosis in response to radiation?
questions.solution:
Apoptosis in response to radiation occurs in all of the following except Glioblastoma.

Apoptosis is the most common form of programmed cell death, also known as interphase death, to differentiate it from mitotic death. During this process cell dies in an orderly and controlled fashion. 

Apoptosis in response to radiation occurs in some but not all cells. Very radiosensitive cells like normal lymphocytes, lymphoma and neuroblastoma cells undergo a lot of apoptosis whereas very radioresistant tumor cells like melanoma and glioblastoma have no meaningful apoptosis. 

Tissue Effects After Irradiation: 
1. Apoptosis : It begins  usually within 6–24 h after irradiation. In some cases delayed apoptosis (several days) has also been observed.
 Apoptotic bodies are rapidly degraded and hence they quickly disappear. 

2. Mitotic catastrophe: It usually occurs in one to two cell cycles. (15 h to 2 weeks in actively cycling cells). 

3. Necrosis : It is observed after days to a small number of weeks after irradiation. At very high doses it may occur within hours of irradiation. 

4. Late responses: Some changes may take months to years after radiation. These changes can be fibrosis, microvascular changes, chronic inflammation, decreased wound healing and not directly cell death.

Related Pearl: Radiosensitive and Radioresistant Tumors

Highly radiosensitive tumors :

  • Lymphoma
  • Seminoma
  • Myeloma
  • Ewing’s sarcoma
  • Wilms tumor

 Highly radioresistant tumors :

  • Melanoma
  • Osteosarcoma
  • Pancreatic carcinoma
  • Hepatic carcinoma
  • Renal cell carcinoma
  • glioblastoma

questions.text: Which of the following factors is responsible for the plasmid-mediated transfer of drug resistance?
questions.solution:
The R-factor called as resistance factor is responsible for the plasmid-mediated transfer of drug resistance.

Bacteria can acquire drug resistance by mutation or by one of the methods of genetic transfer. Mutational drug resistance is of two types, step-wise mutation as seen in penicillin where the resistance is acquired through many steps and one-step mutation as in streptomycin resistance in tuberculosis where the mutants can show either high resistance or low acquired through a single mutation.

Plasmid-mediated transfer of drug resistance mediated by the R factor is the most important method of drug resistance. Resistance is due to the production of degrading enzymes and the bacteria becomes highly drug resistant. The presence of the R factor can provide resistance to multiple drugs so the usage of a combination of drugs is not effective. Transferable drug resistance is universal in distribution and mainly involves all the antibiotics that are indiscriminately used for diarrhoea and other mild self-limiting conditions.

Other options:

Option A: Col factor is the plasmid called as colicinogenic factor responsible for the production of colicins. Colicins are antibiotic-like substances produced by the bacteria that are selectively and specifically lethal to other Enterobacteriaceae.

Option C: The f prime factor is the F factor that carries some chromosomal genes near its site as it is transferred from an integrated state to a free state.

Option D: F factor also called as Fertility factor or sex factor is responsible for the formation of conjugation tubes between the bacteria. It is a transfer factor that contains the genetic information necessary for the synthesis of sex pilus and self-transfer.

questions.text: You perform a bithermal caloric test for a patient in both ears. Which of the following will produce a left-sided nystagmus?

choices.text: 44°C water in right and 30° water in left
44° water in right and 44° water in left
30° water in right and 44° water in left
30° water in right and 30° water in left

questions.solution:
Normally, nystagmus towards a particular side is produced by cold water (30°C) into the opposite ear or warm water (44°C) into the same ear, which can be remembered by the mnemonic COWS (Cold - Opposite ; Warm - Same). Thus, a left sided nystagmus will be produced by cold water into the right ear and warm water into the left ear.

This test where the inner ear is tested based on the pattern of nystagmus produced by irrigating cold and warm water alternatively is called bithermal caloric test / Fitzgerald-Hallpike test.  Time taken between the start of irrigation to the end of nystagmus is noted and plotted on a chart called calorigram. Normally each ear is irrigated for 40 seconds and nystagmus will last for around 120 seconds. A gap of 5 minutes should be allowed between two ears. Based on the calorigram, 4 different patterns can be derived :

  • Normal
  • Canal paresis / dead labyrinth (minimal or no nystagmus)
  • Directional preponderance (direction of nystagmus more towards either right or left)
  • Both canal paresis and directional preponderance

If no nystagmus is elicited from any ear, test is repeated with water at 20°C for 4 min before labelling the labyrinth dead.

The following image shows a left sided canal paresis / dead labyrinth (note the reduced period of nystagmus in left side for both cold and warm water)

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman dislikes her parents but finds these thoughts unacceptable. She acts extra nice and caring towards them. What is this defense mechanism called?
questions.solution:
Reaction formation is the defense mechanism in which the woman hides her unacceptable thoughts and acts oppositely by being extra nice to her parents. 

Reaction formation is a neurotic defense mechanism in which unacceptable impulses are transformed into extreme opposite feelings or behaviors. When the impulse is persistent, reaction formation can become a character trait. In this question, the woman finds her dislike towards parents unacceptable and acts oppositely by being extra nice and caring towards them.

Other options: 

Option A: Sublimation is a mature defense mechanism in which people channel their socially unacceptable impulses into socially acceptable behaviors. For example, a teenager with aggressive feelings channels them into sports by becoming a boxer. 

Option B: Projection is an immature defense mechanism in which one attributes one’s feelings to others. For example, a person who cheats on his wife says that the wife is probably cheating on him.

Option D: Acting out is an immature defense mechanism that involves expressing unacceptable emotions or impulses through actions. For example, a teenager starts throwing things and yelling when he doesn’t win a game. 

Related Pearl: Defense mechanisms

Narcissistic-psychotic defenses

Denial: Used to avoid becoming aware of some painful aspects of reality.

  • Eg: I know I do not have cancer.

Distortion: Grossly reshaping the experience of external reality to suit inner needs.

  • Eg: I possess special powers and abilities and am superior to others.

Projection (psychotic): Attributing your own wishes, thoughts, or feelings onto someone else.

  • Eg: I’m sure my wife is cheating on me.

Splitting: External objects are divided into all good or all bad.

  • Eg: The morning staff is perfect, the evening staff is terrible.

 

Immature defenses

Acting out: Behavioral or emotional outburst.

  • Eg: My 10-year-old started getting into trouble right after his mother and I got divorced.

Blocking: Temporary block in thinking.

  • Eg: I have known him for years but can never seem to remember his name.

Hypochondriasis: A defense style in which people say that no one understands their pain.

  • Eg: No one understands the depth of my pain.

Introjection: Features of the external world are taken and made part of the self.

  • Eg: The resident physician dresses like the attending whom he admires.

Passive-aggressive behavior: Aggressive intent is cloaked by a passive method.

  • Eg: Procrastinating at work for not getting the promotion.

Projection (non-psychotic): Unwanted feelings are displaced onto another person.

  • Eg: A man who has been unfaithful to his wife but accuses his wife of cheating on him.

Regression: Return to an earlier stage of development, most immature.

  • Eg: Ever since my divorce, my 5-year-old has begun to wet the bed.

Schizoid fantasy: Tendency to retreat into fantasy in order to resolve inner and outer conflicts.

  • Eg: Adolescents day dreaming on pornographic materials.

Somatization: Psychic derivatives are converted into bodily symptoms.

  • Eg: Just thinking of the exam I get butterflies in my stomach.

 

Neurotic defenses

Externalization: Perceiving one’s personality, impulses, moods and attitudes in the external world.

  • Eg: An argumentative person perceives the doctor as argumentative whilst believing himself to be blameless.

Displacement: Shifting emotions about one object/ individual onto another object/ individual.

  • Eg: Getting angry at your parents because you had a bad day at work.

Inhibition: conscious or unconscious constraint of a process or behavior.

  • Eg: A desire to eat dessert versus the desire to lose weight.

Intellectualization: Excessive use of intellectual processes to avoid affective expression or experience.

  • Eg: It is interesting to note the specific skin lesions which seem to arise as a consequence of my end-stage disease.

Isolation: Separation of an idea from the affect that accompanies it.

  • Eg: As she arrived at the station to identify the body, she appeared to show no emotion.

Rationalization: Rational explanations are used to justify unacceptable attitudes, beliefs, or behaviors.

  • Eg: I did not pass the test because it was harder this year than ever before.

Reaction formation: An unacceptable impulse is transformed into its opposite; results in the formation of character traits.

  • Eg: Listen to him tell his family he was not afraid when I saw him crying.

Repression: An idea or feeling is withheld from consciousness; unconscious forgetting.

  • Eg: I do not remember having had a dog.

Sexualization: Endowing an object or function with sexual significance.

Undoing: Acting out the reverse of unacceptable behavior; consists of an act.

  • Eg: I need to wash my hands whenever I have these thoughts.

Retroflexion: Self-destruction due to rage.

  • Eg: A person cutting his wrist because he is angry with himself.

 

Mature defenses

Altruism: Getting pleasure from giving to others what the individual would have liked to receive.

  • Eg:  A former alcoholic funding a rehabilitation center.

Anticipation: Realistically planning or anticipating future inner discomfort.

  • Eg: Moderate amount of anxiety before surgery.

Asceticism: Gratification derived from renunciation.

Humor: Permits the expression of feelings and thoughts without personal discomfort.

  • Eg: Before execution, firing squad leader offers the man a cigarette. He replies "no thanks I'm trying to quit".

Sublimation: Impulse gratification has been achieved, but the aim or object has been changed from unacceptable to acceptable; allows instincts to be channeled. Most mature of the defenses.

  • Eg: Jack the Ripper becomes a surgeon.

Suppression: Conscious forgetting. The only conscious defense mechanism.

  • Eg: I would rather talk about my operation after the party is over.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presented with progressive dysphagia, weight loss, and regurgitation for the past 3 months. On upper GI endoscopy, a tissue growth was seen in the esophagus, and a biopsy of the lesion showed keratin pearls. All of the following are risk factors for this condition, except:
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and the presence of keratin pearls on biopsy suggest a diagnosis of squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus. All the above-mentioned conditions are risk factors for squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus except for gastro-oesophageal reflux disease, which is a risk factor for adenocarcinoma of the esophagus. 

Risk factors for squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus include - 

  • Alcohol and smoking
  • Betal nut chewing
  • Plummer-Vinson syndrome
  • Achalasia cardia
  • Radiation exposure to mediastinum
  • Corrosive injury
  • Low dietary intake of fruits and vegetables and vitamin deficiencies

Risk factors for adenocarcinoma of the oesophagus include -

  • Obesity
  • GERD
  • Barrett’s esophagus
  • Smoking
  • Radiation exposure to mediastinum

Note - Risk factors of squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus can be remembered as associated with a poor socio-economic status man and adenocarcinoma of the esophagus as an obese busy businessman.

The image below shows a keratin pearl in squamous cell carcinoma:


Plummer-Vinson syndrome/ Patterson-Kelly syndrome is also called sideropenic dysphagia and it commonly affects middle-aged women with long-standing anemia. The triad of features seen in this syndrome include:

  • iron deficiency anemia
  • oesophageal webs in the post-cricoid area
  • dysphagia

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman at term is admitted to the labor room for normal vaginal delivery. Her vitals are stable, and her uterus is term-sized, but on per vaginal examination, the cord was found to be prolapsed outside the vulva. What is the immediate step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette suggests cord prolapse, and the immediate step in the management is to assess fetal viability.

The definitive treatment for cord prolapse is delivery by cesarean section when the baby is alive and mature. Reconfirming if the baby is alive before the incision is important to prevent unnecessary trauma from surgery.

The contraindications of immediate delivery are fetal death, lethal fetal anomalies, and a pre-viable gestation.

If immediate safe vaginal delivery is possible:

  • When the fetal head is engaged - delivery by forceps. Ventouse is not ideal in such circumstances as it takes a longer time 
  • Breech presentation - the delivery is to be completed by breech extraction
  • Transverse lie - the internal podalic version, followed by breech extraction

When immediate safe vaginal delivery is not possible:

  • Oxytocin infusion is stopped
  • IV fluids, oxygen by face mask, and continuous fetal monitoring
  • Relieve pressure on the cord by:
    • Manual elevation of the fetal presenting part using two fingers or the whole hand through the vagina.
    • Vagos method: Foley catheter is placed and the bladder is filled with 500-750 mL of saline, and then clamped. The patient’s enlarging bladder provides upward pressure on the fetus and alleviates the compression on the cord.
    • Positioning of the patient in a steep Trendelenburg position, exaggerated Sim’s position, or knee-chest position, as shown below.

The given image represents oesophageal speech (option B).

Vocal rehabilitation after total laryngectomy is broadly divided into:

  • Esophageal speech
  • Artificial larynx
  • Tracheo-oesophageal speech         

Oesophageal Speech-  the patient is taught to swallow air and hold it in the upper oesophagus and then slowly eject it from the oesophagus into the pharynx. The patient can speak 6-10 words before re-swallowing air. The voice is rough but loud and understandable.

 

Electrolarynx and transoral pneumatic devices are methods of artificial larynx (options C and D).

 

Tracheo-Oesophageal Speech- Here the air is diverted from the trachea to the oesophagus or hypopharynx by the creation of a skin-lined fistula or by the placement of a prosthesis. The vibrating column of air entering the pharynx is then modulated into speech. The prostheses used are Blom-Singer and Panje devices. They have inbuilt valves which work only in one direction thus preventing problems of aspiration. (option A)

questions.text: An 8-year-old child scheduled for a tonsillectomy is given a neuromuscular blocking agent 'A' prior to endotracheal intubation. The effect of this blockage is monitored by the train-of-four stimulation, which shows the following pattern. Identify the drug A.
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the fade in the train-of-four (TOF) monitoring graph suggests that drug 'A' is a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent. In the given options, rocuronium is the only non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent while the others are depolarizing agents.

TOF is a pattern of nerve stimulation used to monitor neuromuscular blockade. It consists of four successive 200-μs stimuli in 2 seconds (2 Hz).

It is calculated by dividing the amplitude of the fourth response by the amplitude of the first response and requires an objective measure of the response to stimulation. The TOF count denotes the number of detectable evoked responses, and it correlates to the degree of neuromuscular block

This effect can be reversed by Sugammadex, a modified gamma-cyclodextrin, that forms a tight complex with rocuronium and decreases the concentration of free plasma levels. 

Rocuronium is commonly used to provide muscle relaxation during routine intubation in pediatric patients because it has a rapid onset and can be administered intramuscularly.

Depolarising agents such as succinylcholine (also called suxamethonium) and decamethonium (Options A, B & D) will show a decrease in amplitude in all four twitches simultaneously in phase 1, but no progressive decline in amplitude. If repeated doses or a prolonged infusion is given, phase 2 blockade with a progressive decline in amplitude will be seen.

The illustration below shows variations of train-of-four fade patterns of various muscle relaxants.

questions.text:
What are the two major mechanisms that can trigger disseminated intravascular coagulation?

vWF - von Willebrand Factor

choices.text: Injury of platelets and release of tissue factor
Deposition of antigen-antibody complexes and activation of thrombin
Accumulation of vWF multimers and activation of thrombin
Release of tissue factor and injury of endothelial cells

questions.solution:
The two major mechanisms that trigger disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) are the release of tissue factors or other procoagulants and the widespread injury of endothelial cells.

DIC is a thrombo-hemorrhagic disorder in which there is widespread clotting in the body. The most common causes are obstetric complications like amniotic fluid embolisms and retained products of conception. Major trauma, sepsis, and certain malignancies are also common causes.

TNF (tissue necrosis factor) is an important mediator of endothelial injury. It can promote the expression of tissue factors on endothelial cells and also stimulate the adhesion of leukocytes to the endothelium, causing further damage and clotting. 

These factors result in the occlusion of the microvasculature by thrombi. Large-scale clotting leads to the consumption of platelets and clotting factors. Hence, it is also called consumptive coagulopathy. 


The clinical diagnosis is supported by the following laboratory findings:

  • low platelet count
  • prolonged bleeding time
  • prolonged PT/aPTT
  • elevated fibrin degradation products
  • elevated D-dimer

Two common named syndromes associated with DIC:

  • Waterhouse-Friderichson syndrome caused by meningococcal septicemia. It can result in microthrombi that block the adrenal vasculature and ultimately result in adrenal hemorrhage due to DIC.
  • Kasabach-Merritt syndrome is a type of DIC that is seen with giant hemangiomas. Recurrent bleeding and clotting in these fragile vessels results in DIC.

Related Pearl: Causes of Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC)

Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) is an acute, subacute, or chronic thrombohemorrhagic disorder occurring as a secondary complication in a variety of diseases. It is characterized by the activation of the coagulation sequence that leads to the formation of microthrombi throughout the microcirculation of the body. As a consequence of the thrombotic diathesis, there is a consumption of platelets, fibrin, and coagulation factors and, secondarily, activation of fibrinolytic mechanisms.

questions.text: Which of the following immunodiffusion tests represents single diffusion in one dimension?
questions.solution:
Single diffusion in one dimension is called the Oudin procedure. Immunodiffusion employs antigen-antibody precipitation in gel medium rather than liquid and has several advantages. 

  • Distint line of precipitation which is stable and can be stained seperately
  • Able to detect the number of different antigens, as individual antigens produce a distinct line of precipitation
  • Analyse the identity and non-identity between different antigens

Different types of immunodiffusion:

  • Single diffusion in one dimension - Oudin procedure
  • Double diffusion in one dimension - Oakley-Fulthorpe procedure
  • Single diffusion in two dimensions - Radial immunodiffusion/Mancini procedure : This method has been used for the estimation of the immunoglobulin classes in sera and for screening sera for antibodies to influenza viruses
  • Double diffusion in two dimensions - Ouchterlony procedure : A special variety of double diffusion in two dimensions is the Elek test for toxigenicity in diphtheria bacilli. When diphtheria bacilli are streaked at right angles to a filter paper strip carrying the antitoxin implanted on a plate of suitable medium, arrowhead-shaped lines of precipitation appear on incubation, if the bacillus is toxigenic.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with blistering skin lesions on sun-exposed areas of his body, including the face and dorsa of the hands. He reports increased skin fragility and recurrent episodes of blistering with minimal trauma. Laboratory tests reveal elevated levels of urinary porphyrins. What is the management for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
This is a clinical vignette of porphyria cutanea tarda (PCT), characterized by cutaneous photosensitivity, blistering skin lesions, and elevated levels of urinary porphyrins. Phlebotomy is indicated in the management of this condition to reduce excess iron.

PCT is the most common subtype of porphyria. It is caused by a defect in uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase. It is associated with hemochromatosis. The management of PCT primarily involves reducing the levels of excess iron, which contributes to the overproduction of porphyrins in the liver. Phlebotomy, or the removal of blood, reduces iron stores and subsequently decreases hepatic porphyrin synthesis. This approach helps alleviate cutaneous symptoms and prevents disease progression.

Hydroxychloroquine is an alternative to phlebotomy when it is contraindicated.

Other options: 

Option A: Replacement of the defective enzyme is not a treatment modality in PCT.

Options B and D: Intravenous hemin is the 1st line treatment in an acute attack of acute intermittent porphyria. It represses ALAS1 activity and stops the production of harmful heme precursors. Carbohydrate loading via intravenous glucose is done, if hemin is not available and for less severe attacks of porphyria. Glucose also inhibits ALAS1 activity.

Related Pearl: Types of porphyria

Clinically porphyrias can be classified into:

  • Hepatic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in the liver.
  • Erythropoietic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in bone marrow erythroid cells.

questions.text: Which of the following is an advantage of ropivacaine compared to bupivacaine?
questions.solution:
The advantage of ropivacaine is that it is less cardiotoxic than bupivacaine. 

Ropivacaine is an S(-) enantiomer of bupivacaine. It was developed as a modification of bupivacaine to decrease cardiotoxicity. Ropivacaine is less cardiotoxic and has a higher safety profile than bupivacaine. It has a shorter duration of action and produces less motor block (Option D) than bupivacaine (i.e. more motor sparing than bupivacaine). Ropivacaine is less potent (Option A) than bupivacaine. 

Both ropivacaine and bupivacaine have similar profiles in terms of renal toxicity (Option B). They do not produce adverse renal effects. Dose adjustments in renal failure is also not required. Bupivacaine may even have a renal protective effect.

Ropivacaine can be used for infiltration anesthesia and central neuraxial blocks (both spinal and epidural).

Bupivacaine is a long-acting local anesthetic that is the most cardiotoxic among the local anesthetics. It blocks the sodium channels of the heart during systole. However, compared to lidocaine, it dissociates very slowly. Therefore, the heart remains blocked for a longer duration in diastole. This makes bupivacaine cardiotoxic.

Accidental intravascular injection of local anesthetic like bupivacaine results in bupivacaine-induced cardiotoxicity. If this occurs, basic life support followed by intralipid therapy is initiated. A rapid bolus of intralipid 20% IV (1.5 mL/kg) is administered without delay, followed by an infusion of 0.25 mL/kg/min. Intralipid decreases cardiac bupivacaine concentration, and cerebral bupivacaine concentration

Note:

Local anesthesia systemic toxicity (LAST) can also affect the central nervous system (CNS), which is more susceptible to local anesthetic action as compared to the cardiovascular system. Dizziness, tinnitus, and disorientation are the initial symptoms. Shivering, muscular twitching, and tremors follow. Finally, respiratory depression can lead to respiratory arrest.

questions.text: An ultrasound scan done at 32 weeks for a woman with oligohydramnios revealed fetal ureteropelvic junction obstruction. What is the surgery of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
Anderson Hyens surgery is the surgery of choice in a case of ureteropelvic junction obstruction(UPJO) and it is done after birth.

The most common cause of an unilateral hydronephrosis after birth is due to congenital ureteropelvic junction obstruction (UPJO). UPJO is more common in males and occurs more frequently on the left side. 

Most cases of PUJO with associated hydronephrosis are now detected before birth with antenatal ultrasound. If undetected, it presents in infancy as a palpable renal mass. Associated presentations include abdominal or flank pain, febrile UTI, or hematuria after minimal trauma.

The causes of UPJ obstruction are:

  • Intrinsic (due to an adynamic or stenotic segment of the proximal ureter) or 
  • Extrinsic (e.g. compression by accessory renal arteries). This needs to be corrected primarily.

The renal anatomy and function can be assessed using radio scintigraphy studies. The investigation of choice for UPJ obstruction is a 99mTc-MercaptoAcetyl-triGlycine (MAG3) scan. Micturating cystourethrogram is the investigation of choice in vesicoureteric reflux. 99mTc-dimercaptosuccinic acid (DMSA) scan is used for assessing renal scarring. Ultrasound abdomen is useful to grade the severity and persistence of hydronephrosis which in turn guides management. Mild cases with grade 1 or 2 hydronephrosis and normal renal parenchyma are managed with observation and subsequent renal ultrasound studies to monitor the severity.

Treatment of intrinsic UPJ obstruction is done surgically if renal function is compromised or if there is bilateral involvement of the kidneys. In other cases, serial follow-up with ultrasonography is done to assess the spontaneous resolution of hydronephrosis.

Its indications include persistent pain, hypertension, haematuria, secondary renal calculi and recurrent UTIs due to the UPJO. The age group for which it is done depends on the severity of hydronephrosis hence can be from 1 month to 18-19 years of age.

Surgical options include Anderson Hynes pyeloplasty which entails the surgical division of the obstruction and the creation of a funnel-shaped anastomosis. Additionally, a temporary stent and a drain may be inserted. It is necessary to do further serial ultrasounds and MAG-3 imaging in order to ensure proper monitoring and evaluation. This procedure is now commonly being performed via laparoscopy and also with robotic assistance. 

Other options:

Option A: Stephan Fowler technique is used in the management of cryptorchidism.

Option B: Nesbitt’s procedure is used in the management of Peyronie's disease.

Option D:  Grey hack shunt surgery is used in the management of priapism.

questions.text: A young man presents to the casualty after a stab injury to the back and the muscles marked below are injured. What is the prime action of these muscles?
questions.solution:
The muscles marked in the above image are rhomboids minor and major. These muscles cause retraction of the scapula.

Rhomboids minor and major are innervated by the dorsal scapular nerve. They are supplied by the dorsal scapular artery or the deep branch of the transverse cervical artery.

Muscles involved in movements of the scapula are:

  • Protraction (forward movement): Serratus anterior and pectoralis minor are prime movers. Rhomboid muscles control the rate and range of movements. The upper part of the latissimus dorsi acts like a strap across the inferior scapular angle in protraction.
  • Retraction (backward movement): Middle trapezius and rhomboids.
  • Elevation: Trapezius, Levator scapulae.
  • Depression: Usually gravity alone is sufficient for the depression of the scapula. When required, a part of the serratus anterior, pectoralis minor, and trapezius are used.

questions.text: Which colour vision test cannot  detect blue colour vision deficit?
questions.solution:
The Ishihara test is used to screen for red-green colour vision deficit. It cannot detect blue colour vision deficit. 

Ishihara's pseudoisochromatic chart is a type of pseudoisochromatic chart in which there are patterns of coloured and grey dots.  It will show one pattern to normal individuals and another to a person with defective colour vision. This is the most commonly used test for colour vision.

Colour blindness is the inability to appreciate one or more of the 3 primary colours, i.e. red, green, and blue. It can be congenital or acquired. Hereditary conditions can be classified into dyschromatopsia (colour confusion) and achromatopsia (rod monochromatism).  

Tests for colour vision:

  • Ishihara pseudo-isochromatic chart
  • Hardy–Rand–Rittler test
  • City University test
  • Holmgren's wool-matching test
  • Naegels anamoloscope
  • Farnsworth Munsell 100 hue test

The image given below shows Ishihara's pseudo-isochromatic chart.

Other options:

Option A: The image below shows the Hardy–Rand–Rittler test which is similar to Ishihara test but is used to detect all three colour vision defects.

Option B: Farnsworth–Munsell 100-hue test is a spectroscopic test (the patient arranges colour chips in ascending order) and consists of 85 caps of different hues in four racks. The colour vision is judged according to the error score, such that a greater error score means poorer colour vision. It is the most sensitive test for both congenital and acquired colour vision defects.

Option D: City University colour vision is a spectroscopic test where a central coloured plate should be matched with the closest hue from the four surrounding colours present in 10 plates.

questions.text: In the 1980s, David Philip Vetter was a prominent case of Severe Combined Immunodeficiency (SCID), who later died at the age of 12.  In such children, the defective DNA repair mechanism is:
questions.solution:
SCID is associated with a defective Non-Homologous End Joining (NHEJ).

Non-homologous end-joining (NHEJ) is a mechanism by which a group of proteins mediates the recognition, processing, and direct ligation of the ends of two DNA fragments where a double-strand break in DNA has occurred. This is in contrast to homologous repair (HR), another mechanism, where an undamaged homologous DNA template is required to replace an adjacent damaged one.

The type of repair depends on the phase of cell cycles:

The phase of the cell cycle     Repair mechanism
 G0 /G1 Phase   Nonhomologous End Joining Repair
S, G2, M Phase   Homologous Repair

NHEJ deficiency confers combined immunodeficiency due to a failure to carry out recombination efficiently. NHEJ also functions in class switch recombination, another step enhancing T and B cell diversity.

Severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) occurs due to defects in both humoral and cell-mediated immune responses. Patients with SCID are extremely susceptible to recurrent, severe infections by a wide range of pathogens, including Candida albicans, Pneumocystis jirovecii, Pseudomonas species, cytomegalovirus, varicella, etc. The most common form is X-linked SCID, and hence, SCID is more common in boys than in girls. The genetic defect in the X-linked form is a mutation in the common γ-chain (γc) subunit of cytokine receptors and the most common cause of autosomal-recessive SCID is a deficiency of adenosine deaminase (ADA) enzyme.

questions.text: All of the following are type IV hypersensitivity reactions except:
questions.solution:
Polyarteritis nodosa is a type III hypersensitivity reaction, not type IV.

Type IV hypersensitivity reactions (delayed hypersensitivity reactions): These reactions are induced by sensitized T cells which on contact with the specific antigen, release cytokines that produce biological effects on leucocytes, macrophages, and tissue cells.

Examples of type IV hypersensitivity reactions include sarcoidosis, leprosy, type I lepra reaction, tuberculosis, psoriasis, inflammatory bowel disease, multiple sclerosis, and type 1 diabetes mellitus, contact dermatitis.

Type III hypersensitivity reactions: These reactions are induced by immune complexes which deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating the complement system. The inflammatory reaction causes tissue injury.

Other examples of type III hypersensitivity reactions include systemic lupus erythematosus, serum sickness, arthus reaction, post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis, rheumatoid arthritis, and type II lepra reaction.

questions.text:
A 6-day-old girl is brought by her parents with complaints of increased irritability, poor feeding, and three episodes of seizures. A lumbar puncture is performed and the findings are listed below. Which of the following is a suitable empirical treatment option?

Appearance: Turbid
Opening pressure: 30 cm H2O
WBC count: 1000 cells/µL (90% PMNL)
Glucose level: 35 mg/dL
Protein level:  80 mg/dL
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of neonatal meningitis. E. coli > Streptococcus agalactiae are the most likely causative organism of neonatal meningitis. Ampicillin + 3rd-generation cephalosporin is a suitable empirical treatment option as the age of the baby is less than a month.

Neonatal meningitis is classified as either early or late-onset. Early-onset meningitis within the first 72 hours of life. Late-onset meningitis is seen in premature infants and is generally caused by Escherichia coli, coagulase-negative staphylococci, Staphylococcus aureus, and Klebsiella. 

Neonates have immature cellular and humoral immunity. This makes them prone to meningitis and sepsis. Thus, an infant with a fever who is 28 days or younger, should be evaluated for sepsis. This is done by obtaining a complete blood count (CBC), differential blood count, blood culture, urine culture, chest radiograph, and lumbar puncture. 

Meningococcal infections are usually asymptomatic. If invasive disease occurs, then the clinical spectrum varies widely from meningococcal meningitis (highest proportion) to bacteremia without sepsis, meningococcal septicemia with or without meningitis, pneumonia, chronic meningococcemia, and occult bacteremia.

Meningitis caused by Listeria monocytogenes is relatively rare but clinically significant. Infants acquire infection in utero or by inoculation through an infected birth canal. Neonatal listeriosis can be,

  • Early-onset neonatal disease, which occurs in infants less than 5 days old, usually within 1-2 days of birth. It is predominantly septicemic form.
  • Late-onset neonatal disease, which occurs in infants >5 days old. It is predominantly meningitic form.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man presented with lethargy, constipation, and weight gain, with a poor appetite for a few months. The thyroid profile revealed a high thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) level and low free T4 levels. Which of the following features will most likely be seen in this condition?

choices.text: Increase in blood flow to skin

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with elevated TSH level and low level of free T4 is suggestive of hypothyroidism. Among the given options, a reduction in stroke volume is the feature most likely to be seen in hypothyroidism. Hypothyroidism leads to a decrease in myocardial contractility and pulse rate, resulting in reduced stroke volume and bradycardia.

Enzymes involved in regulating calcium fluxes in the heart are controlled by thyroid hormones, including the calcium-dependent adenosine triphosphate and phospholamban.

In hypothyroidism, the expression and activity of these enzymes decrease so that it could potentially impair systolic performance and diastolic relaxation.

Expression of the beta-adrenergic receptor is also decreased in hypothyroidism, resulting in a reduced response to a catecholamines-mediated increase in inotropy. 

The thyroid hormone relaxes the vascular smooth muscle and reduces peripheral vascular resistance. Conversely in hypothyroidism, the release of endothelial-derived relaxing factors is decreased causing a contraction of smooth muscle and, thereby, an increase in peripheral vascular resistance (option A) leading to hypertension. 

This change causes a reduction in stroke volume and tissue perfusion. This leads to an inflow of blood away from the skin (option C) and results in cold extremities.  

Pericardial effusion occurs almost in 30% of cases with hypothyroidism (Option B). In hypothyroidism, the permeability of the epicardial vessels will increase and lymphatic drainage of albumin will decrease. This results in the accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space.

Patients with hypothyroidism often present with tiredness, weakness, dry skin, hair loss, difficulty concentrating, poor memory, constipation, and weight gain with poor appetite. On examination, they may have cool peripheral extremities, puffy faces, bradycardia, and peripheral edema.

In primary hypothyroidism, TSH will be elevated and free T4 is low.

Patients with hypothyroidism who have no evidence of heart disease are managed with levothyroxine 50 to 100 mcg daily. The goal of the treatment is to maintain TSH in the lower half of the reference range.

questions.text: A patient presents with fever and productive cough. Subsequent sputum culture shows draughtsman appearance on blood agar and positive bile solubility. Which of the following is responsible for these properties of the organism ?
questions.solution:
The history of fever with productive cough points towards pneumonia and subsequent culture showing draughtsman appearance on blood agar with positive bile solubility is suggestive of pneumococcal infection. Autolysin which is present in the organism is responsible for these properties.

Autolysin is an amidase enzyme which plays a major role in self-destruction of the bacteria's cells. Culture on blood agar initially shows dome-shaped colonies but later this enzyme causes autolysis in the centre of the dome, producing the chacarteristic draughtsman / carrom coin appearance of the colonies. This enzyme enhances the autolytic activity in the presence of bile, thus contributing to its solubility in bile. These properties differentiates pneumococcus from Streptococcus viridans.

Carrom-coin (draughtsman) appearance of the colonies is shown below :


Capsular polysaccharide protects the bacteria from phagocytosis and its a major virulence factor. Typing of the pneumococcus is done based on the capsular polysaccharide.

C-antigen (carbohydrate antigen) acts by precipiating with C-reactive protein (CRP). CRP is initially thought to be an antibody against pneumococcal c-antigen but later found to be an acute phase reactant.

Pneumolysin is a membrane damaging toxin which inhibits neutrophil chemotaxis and phagocytosis similar to streptolysin-O

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with type 2 neurofibromatosis was referred to the Department of Otorhinolaryngology for hearing rehabilitation after excision of bilateral acoustic neuromas. The surgery notes mentioned that the 8th nerve was severed during the surgery. After further evaluation, a decision to insert an implant to aid hearing was made. Where will the implant be placed?
questions.solution:
The implant of choice, in this case, would be an auditory brainstem implant (ABI), which is placed in the lateral recess of the 4th ventricle. It is designed to directly stimulate the cochlear nuclear complex in the brainstem.

This type of implant is required when cranial nerve VIII has been severed in surgery for vestibular schwannomas. In unilateral acoustic neuromas, ABI is not necessary as hearing is possible from the contralateral side. The receiver or stimulator has a removable magnet so that MRI can be safely performed if required.

ABIs help in communication, awareness, and recognition of environmental sounds, but are not as efficient as multichannel cochlear implants. 

Cochlear implants are electronic devices for severe to profound SNHL and those who cannot benefit from a hearing aid. The electrode array is placed within the scala tympani of the cochlea. A prerequisite for this is that cranial nerve VIII and the higher auditory pathway should be intact.

 

Related Pearl: Cochlear implant

A cochlear implant replaces the organ of Corti i.e. when hair cells of the organ of Corti are severely damaged these implants bypass it and directly stimulate the auditory nerve.

Indication: Bilateral severe sensorineural hearing loss i.e. > 70 dB.

Components:

Preoperative investigation: Complete audiological evaluation and HRCT and MRI (to detect the structure of cochlea, cochlear nerve and CNS abnormalities).

Surgical approach: Two surgical techniques to approach the cochlea for implantation are the facial recess approach (via facial recess) and the pericanal technique (via EAC).

Postoperatively: Activation of the device after 3-4 weeks and evaluation is by HRCT (MRI is contraindicated).

Contraindications:

  • Absence of cochlea (Michel aplasia)
  • Deafness due to absent cochlear nerve, lesions of cochlear nerve or lesions of the central auditory pathway

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient with advanced cancer is experiencing chronic pain and is scheduled to start opioid therapy as part of end-of-life care. What medication can be prescribed prophylactically to prevent constipation from developing?
questions.solution:
Senna is a stimulant laxative that is prophylactically prescribed in patients who are started on opioids to prevent opioid-induced constipation. 

Opioid-induced constipation is a common side effect of opioid therapy, especially in patients with chronic pain, such as those in palliative or end-of-life care. Nearly all patients started on opioids can experience constipation, which can be debilitating. Hence, the preferred management is the prevention of constipation.

Senna, a stimulant laxative, is often used prophylactically to prevent constipation in patients starting opioid therapy. Stimulant laxatives stimulate intestinal motility and secretion by irritating the mucosa and acting directly on myenteric neurons. Chronic use of anthraquinone laxatives like senna can cause melanosis coli.

Other agents that are considered as first-line for preventing opioid-induced constipation include:

  • bisacodyl (stimulant laxative)
  • docusate (stool softener)
  • lactulose.

Other options: 

Option A: Prucalopride is a 5-HT4 agonist and acts as a stimulant laxative.

Options B and C: Lubiprostone and methylnaltrexone are recommended for refractory opioid-induced constipation.

questions.text: Two neighbours brawling, hit each other and one person dislocated the tooth of the other person. Which of the below BNS (IPC) can the person be punished for this kind of injury?
questions.solution:
The given scenario shows the dislocation of the tooth of a person which is a grievous hurt and is punishable by BNS Sec 117(2) (325 IPC).

Grievous hurt or injury are injuries inflicted voluntarily on another person and defined by BNS Sec 116, previously IPC 320(Option B). It comprises of any of the following eight clauses given below:

Clause 1 — Emasculation-  Examples are castration, cutting away of the penis, etc.
Clause 2 — Permanent loss of sight of either eye.
Clause 3 — Permanent loss of hearing of either ear.
Clause 4 — Privation of any member or joint.
Clause 5 — Destruction or permanent impairment of powers of any member or joint.
Clause 6 — Permanent disfigurement of head or face.
Clause 7 — Fracture or dislocation of bone or tooth
Clause 8 — Any hurt that endangers life or which causes the sufferer to be, during 15 days, in severe bodily pain or unable to follow his or her ordinary pursuits.

Sections under which hurt and grievous hurt are punishable as follows:

questions.text: Which of the following process increases the internal validity of a test?
questions.solution:
Randomization increases the Internal validity of the test.

A test's validity (accuracy) refers to the closeness with which measured values agree with "true" values. Two kinds of validity are involved in research/test results.

Internal validity: Here the results of the study are valid for the sample of patients who were studied. If a test is properly performed, so that there are no confounding factors, the results would be internally valid for this sample. Randomization removes confounders and thus increases the internal validity of the study.

External validity: If the study sample is truly representative of the population from which it was drawn, then the study is said to have external validity. Its findings can also be applied to the entire population and therefore it is said to be generalizable. Random sampling and preventing selection bias increase the external validity of a study (options A and B).

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a classical autopsy finding seen in cases of amniotic fluid embolism in the maternal pulmonary circulation?

choices.text: Mucin derived from the fetal respiratory tract
Laminated swirls of fetal squamous cells

questions.solution:
Marked fibrinoid necrosis is not seen in amniotic fluid embolism (AFE). The classical findings in autopsy includes presence of laminated swirls of squamous cells shed from the fetal skin, lanugo hair, fat from vernix caseosa, and mucin derived from the fetal respiratory or gastrointestinal tract in the maternal pulmonary circulation. 

Amniotic fluid embolism refers to the entry of amniotic fluid containing fetal cells and debris into the maternal circulation through open uterine and cervical veins. The patients present with sudden onset of severe dyspnea, cyanosis, and shock, followed by neurologic impairment ranging from headache to seizures and coma.

AFE is a life-threatening obstetric emergency characterized by sudden cardiorespiratory collapse and disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). The underlying cause is the infusion of amniotic fluid or fetal tissue into the maternal circulation via a tear in the placental membranes or rupture of uterine veins.

Fibrinoid necrosis is commonly seen in Malignant hypertension, Rheumatic carditis and Vasculitis - Polyarteritis nodosa, Kawasaki disease. 

The given image shows the presence of laminated swirls of squamous cells in the pulmonary arteriole which is characteristically seen in AFE.

questions.text:
A patient with Crohn's disease who underwent gut resection has been on TPN for the past 2 weeks. He has now developed jaundice and investigations reveal elevated GGT. Which of the following is the underlying cause of his symptoms?

TPN- Total parenteral nutrition
GGT- Gamma-glutamyl transferase

choices.text: Ascending infection of the gall bladder

questions.solution:
In this patient status post extensive gut resection on TPN for 2 weeks with elevated GGT(Gamma glutamyl transferase) and jaundice has most likely developed cholestasis secondary to reduced motility of the gut and gall bladder. 

The lack of gut stimulation leads to reduced flow of bile and can increase the risk of gall stones and cholelithiasis. This can lead to calculous and acalculous cholelithiasis. This condition can be prevented by early refeeding in patients who can tolerate it.

Total parenteral nutrition (TPN) is defined as the provision of all nutritional requirements by means of the intravenous route and without the use of the gastrointestinal tract. Parenteral nutrition is indicated when energy and protein needs cannot be met by the enteral administration of these substrates. The most frequent clinical indications relate to those patients who have undergone massive resection of the small intestine, who have an intestinal fistula or who have prolonged intestinal failure for other reasons.

TPN can be administered either by a catheter inserted in the central vein or via a peripheral line. PICC lines have a mean duration of survival of 7 days. The disadvantage is that when thrombophlebitis occurs, the vein is irrevocably destroyed. When the central venous route is chosen, the catheter can be inserted via the subclavian or internal or external jugular vein. 

Whichever technique is employed, a postinsertion chest X-ray is essential before feeding is commenced to confirm the absence of pneumothorax and that the catheter tip lies in the distal superior vena cava, to minimise the risk of central venous or cardiac thrombosis.

Other options:

Option A: Fatty infiltration of the liver can cause jaundice but this pathology takes a long time to develop, it is unlikely to cause these symptoms in 2 weeks.

Option B: Infection of the gall bladder can cause cholangitis which presents with fever and right upper quadrant pain. But cholestasis related jaundice is more likely in a patient on TPN.

Option D: Bile duct injury is not common in bowel resection surgeries. It is associated with cholecystectomy surgeries following which they can present as bile leak or minor injuries can cause biliary stricture formation and present as obstructive jaundice later.

Related Pearl: Complications of total parenteral nutrition

A. Related to nutrient deficiency

  • Hypocalcaemia/hypophosphatemia/hypomagnesaemia/hypoglycemia (refeeding syndrome)
  • Chronic deficiency syndromes (essential fatty acids, zinc, mineral and trace elements)

B. Related to overfeeding

  • Excess glucose: Hyperglycemia, hyperosmolar dehydration, hepatic steatosis, hypercapnia, increased sympathetic activity, fluid retention, electrolyte abnormalities
  • Excess fat: Hypercholesterolemia and formation of lipoprotein X, hypertriglyceridemia, hypersensitivity reactions
  • Excess amino acids: Hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis, hypercalcemia, aminoacidemia, uremia

C. Related to sepsis

  • Catheter-related sepsis
  • Possible increased predisposition to systemic sepsis

D. Related to IV line

  • On insertion: Pneumothorax, damage to adjacent artery, air embolism, thoracic duct damage, cardiac perforation or tamponade, pleural effusion, hydro mediastinum
  • Long-term use: Occlusion, venous thrombosis

E. Related to motility

  • Cholestasis
  • Gallstones

questions.text: While working as a resident in a hospital, you are asked by the consultant to prescribe a certain proton-pump inhibitor (PPI). It should be given only orally once daily before breakfast, even though it has a half-life of no more than 3 hours. What is the rationale behind this once-daily dosing?

choices.text: The drug can inhibit all gastric pumps.
The drug irreversibly inactivates the pump molecule.
The drug is gradually released irrespective of its formulation.
The drug suppresses basal but not stimulated acid production.

questions.solution:
The rationale behind the once-daily dosing is that the drug irreversibly inactivates the pump molecule.

Proton-pump inhibitors (PPIs) are prodrugs that are activated only after undergoing an acid-catalyzed cleavage in the canaliculi of the parietal cells of the stomach.

On administration, they are absorbed in the proximal small bowel and eventually, block the H+/K+ ATPase enzyme, the "proton pump" in the parietal cells of the stomach. The secretion of protons by an activated H+/K+- ATPase (proton pump) in the parietal cells into the gastric lumen is the final step involved in the production of gastric acid and inhibition of this enzyme prevents acid secretion into the stomach.

Once PPIs irreversibly inactivate the H+K+-ATPase pump, acid secretion resumes only after new pump molecules are synthesized and inserted into the luminal membrane. This leads to prolonged suppression of acid secretion for up to 24-48 hours, despite having a shorter plasma half-life of only 30 minutes to 3 hours.

In most individuals, once-daily dosing is enough to achieve effective acid inhibition. If necessary, a second dose can be given before an evening meal.

The number of H+K+-ATPase pump molecules increases after fasting and food decreases the oral bioavailability of the drug. Hence, PPIs are given around 30 minutes before the first meal of the day.

PPIs cannot inhibit all gastric acid pumps with oral dosing because not all pumps are active during the short half-life of the PPI in the blood. 

PPIs cause maximum suppression of gastric acid. They reduce the daily production of both basal and stimulated acid secretion by 85–90%. 

There are available in the form of delayed-release tablets, capsules, and oral suspension packets and for immediate acid suppression, there are intravenous formulations for PPIs like lansoprazole, pantoprazole, and esomeprazole. Therefore, the release of the drug depends upon the drug formulation.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient, who is a known case of chronic hypertension, delivers a male baby by vaginal delivery. Following the delivery, she starts to bleed profusely. All of the following medications can be used to control hemorrhage in this patient, except:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario indicates postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) in this patient following vaginal delivery. All of the listed medications can be used for management, except methylergonovine. Methergine (methylergonovine) is contraindicated in a patient with a history of chronic hypertension.  

Ergot alkaloids (ergonovine and methylergonovine) are commonly used second-line agents to treat uterine atony if atony persists despite oxytocin and other preventive measures. Given oral or parenterally, these drugs act rapidly and cause strong uterine contraction. However, ergot agents may cause dangerous hypertension, which is more likely in women with preeclampsia or chronic hypertension. Other contraindications include organic heart disease, multifetal pregnancy after delivery of the first twin, and sepsis. 

Oxytocin is used as the first-line agent in preventing postpartum hemorrhage. If bleeding and atony are refractory, a second-line agent can be added. These include:

  • Ergot alkaloids, namely methylergonovine and ergonovine
  • Carboprost tromethamine, the 15-methyl derivative of prostaglandin F2α. However, it is contraindicated in asthmatics and patients with pulmonary hypertension. It can also cause systemic hypertension as a side effect and should be used with caution in hypertensive patients.
  • Misoprostol, a synthetic prostaglandin E1 analogue. It is contraindicated in patients with previous cesarean section. 
  • Inj. tranexamic acid, an antifibrinolytic agent

questions.text: A student plots the following graph while studying the concentration of cyclins in various stages of the cell cycle. Which cyclin does the pink curve represent?
questions.solution:
The pink curve represents cyclin D, the first cyclin to appear in the cell cycle. The correct sequence of cyclins in the cell cycle is Cyclin D → Cyclin E → Cyclin A → Cyclin B.

The sequence of events that results in cell proliferation is called the cell cycle. It consists of G1 (gap 1), S (DNA synthesis), G2 (gap 2), and M (mitotic) phases. Quiescent cells that are not actively cycling are in the G0 (gap 0) state

Cell cycle progression is chaperoned by proteins called cyclins and cyclin-associated enzymes called cyclin-dependent kinases (CDKs). More than 15 cyclins have been identified; cyclins D, E, A, and B appear sequentially during the cell cycle and bind to one or more CDKs.
