questions.text:
A 35-year-old primigravida at 34 weeks of gestation is brought to the emergency room in an unresponsive condition. The resident finds that she has no pulse and begins chest compressions. ECG shows ventricular fibrillation. Which of the following is true regarding her subsequent management if ROSC is not achieved?

ROSC- Return of spontanous circulation

choices.text: No role of lateral uterine displacement
Peri mortem C-section performed within 5 minutes

questions.solution:
Peri mortem Cesarean section should be performed within 5 minutes (ideally) if return of spontaneous circulation (ROSC) is not achieved.

The purpose of timely perimortem delivery is 2-fold. If cardiac output has not yet been effectively established, relieving aortocaval compression by emptying the uterus significantly improves resuscitative efforts. Second, and of critical importance, early delivery of the baby is accomplished with a decreased risk of permanent neurological damage from anoxia. 

Cardiac arrest in pregnancy is a special situation which involves two patients - the mother and the fetus. Therefore resuscitation algorithm is similar to the routine ACLS, with some additional interventions. 

Option 1) It is advised not to utilize fetal monitoring during such emergencies and if these monitors are present they should be removed during resuscitation procedures.

During active CPR, the focus should remain on maternal resuscitation and restoration of maternal pulse and blood pressure with adequate oxygenation. During this time, evaluation of the fetal heart will not be helpful and carries the risk of inhibiting or delaying maternal resuscitation and monitoring. Should the mother achieve ROSC and her condition be stabilized, then fetal heart surveillance may be instituted when deemed appropriate.

Option 2) Continuous lateral uterine displacement is recommended to relieve the aortocaval compression. The reduced venous return caused by gravid uterus puts the mother at hemodynamic disadvantage, reducing the cardiac output produced by chest compressions.

Option 4) Pregnancy is not a contraindication for defibrillation. Prompt application of defibrillation in the setting of ventricular fibrillation or pulseless ventricular tachycardia is critical to maximize the likelihood of survival. Application of defibrillation and cardioversion shocks to the maternal chest would be expected to pass minimal energy to the fetus and is considered safe in all stages of pregnancy.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man presents to the emergency room with abdominal pain and severe non-bilious vomiting. He was treated for severe upper abdominal pain 5 weeks ago.  CT scan shows a 7cm lesion near the pancreas. The diagnosis of a pancreatic pseudocyst in close proximity to the stomach with secondary pressure effects is made.  What is the best treatment option for this patient?
questions.solution:
The best treatment option for this patient would be to perform a cystogastrostomy since the size of the tumor is greater than 6 cm and in close proximity to the stomach.

Interventions in pseudocyst are required when:

  • Complicated by infection
  • Presence of a mass effect 
  • Diameter increasing in size or greater than 6 cm
  • Recurrence following the previous resection

Pancreatic pseudocysts are fluid-filled oval or round collections encapsulated in a relatively thick wall. They develop 4 weeks after acute pancreatitis and are frequently found on imaging during follow-up. The capsule of a pseudocyst is composed of collagen and granulation tissue, and it is not lined by epithelium. Hence, it is called a pseudocyst.

They may be asymptomatic or become large enough to cause mass effects such as gastric outlet obstruction, bowel obstruction, hydronephrosis, and biliary obstruction. They can present with an epigastric mass, pain abdomen, early satiety, nausea, and vomiting. Abdominal pain is the most common symptom.

Characteristic features of pancreatic pseudo­cysts include high amylase levels associated with the absence of mucin and low serum carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) levels.

Observation is the preferred treatment in:

  • Asymptomatic patients
  • Pseudocysts smaller than 4 cm in diameter (6 cm according to Bailey)
  • Located on the tail
  • No evidence of pancreatic duct obstruction or communication with the main pancreatic duct

Endoscopic drainage is usually curative and surgical drainage is done if endoscopy is contraindicated or if:

  • In close contact with the stomach: Cystogastrostomy
  • In close contact with the duodenum: Cystoduodenostomy

In cystogastrostomy, an anterior gastrostomy is performed. Once the pseudocyst is located, it is drained through the posterior wall of the stomach using a linear stapler. The defect in the anterior wall of the stomach is closed in two layers.

The image below shows the procedure involved in a cystogastrostomy-


Other options:

Roux-en-Y Cystojejunostomy (Option-B) is generally done for cysts that are neither in close proximity to the stomach nor to the duodenum.

Observation and symptomatic management (Option-D) cannot be the line of management for a case of pancreatic pseudocyst of size more than 6cm and especially when the patient has symptoms secondary to gastric obstruction.  

Percutaneous drainage (Option-C) to the exterior under radiological guidance is associated with a high recurrence rate and high incidence of pancreatic-cutaneous fistula. Hence, it is done only in septic patients with infected pseudocyst fluid.

questions.text: You have conducted a case-control study for which you calculate the cross-product ratio to be 0.5. What would you infer from this?

choices.text: The factor can be considered as a risk factor
The factor cannot be considered either as a protective or a risk factor
The factor may be considered as a protective factor

questions.solution:
A cross-product ratio, also known as the odds ratio, of 0.5 indicates that exposure is associated with lower odds of outcome and may be a protective factor for the disease.

The odds ratio (OR) or cross-product ratio is derived from a case-control study. It is a key parameter used to assess the strength of association between the risk factor and outcome. It is a measure of effect. It means it measures the effect of exposure to a risk factor on the risk of developing a disease. Relative risk and attributable risk are the other measures of effect. 
 
OR < 1 indicates that exposure to the factor is associated with lower odds of the outcome. It implies that the factor may be considered a protective factor for the disease. 
 
Other options:
 
Option A: The prevalence cannot be calculated using the cross-product ratio. It is defined as the total number of cases (both old and new) in a population at a given point in time or over a period of time. It is given by the following formula:
Prevalence = Incidence x mean duration
 
Option B: OR > 1 indicates that exposure to the factor is associated with higher odds of the outcome. This means that the factor may be a risk factor for the disease. 
 
Option C: OR = 1 means that exposure does not affect the odds of the outcome. It indicates that a person with the disease is no more likely to have been exposed to the risk factor than is a person without the disease. It is not related to the disease and cannot be considered either as a protective or a risk factor. 

Related Pearl: Odds Ratio

  • Odds ratio is a measure of the strength of association between risk factor and outcome in case control studies.
  • Odds ratio can be arrived at from case control studies.
  • It is also known as cross product ratio.
  • A representation of the odds ratio (OR) is given in the picture below:

Calculation of odds ratio (OR) = (a/b)/(c/d) = ad/bc where, 

  Cancer
Exposure   Yes No
Yes a b
No c d
  • OR < 1 indicates possible protection (negative association) as the frequency of exposure is lower among cases than controls.
  • OR = 1 indicates no association of risk with exposure, or that the event is equally likely in both groups.
  • OR > 1 indicates increased risk (positive association) as the frequency of exposure is greater among cases than controls.

Related Pearl: Incidence and Prevalence

  • Incidence in Epidemiology:

Incidence is the number of new cases occurring in a defined population during a period of time. The incidence rate is expressed in person-time units, usually per 1000 per year. It is given by the following formula:

It is generally used for acute illnesses. It provides insight into the effectiveness of health services and programs. Incidence can be determined from cohort studies and longitudinal studies.

The incidence rate of spells of sickness =  (Number of spells of sickness starting in the specified period/Mean number of people exposed to that risk in the specified time) x 1000.

Special types of incidence rates:

1. Attack rate: It is used when there is a risk for a limited period of time.

2. Secondary attack rate: It is the number of exposed persons developing the disease within the range of incubation period following exposure to a primary case.

  • Prevalence in Epidemiology:

Prevalence is the proportion of all cases, old and new, of a particular disease at a given point in time or over a period of time in a given population. It is a proportion, not a rate or ratio. Prevalence is always expressed in percentage.

It is given by the formula:

It is useful to determine the magnitude of health problems. It can be determined from cross-sectional studies.

Types:

1. Point prevalence is the prevalence at a point in time. Usually, prevalence is point prevalence unless otherwise specified.

2. Period prevalence is the prevalence over a period of time.

Relationship between Incidence and Prevalence:

Prevalence depends upon incidence and duration.

Prevalence = Incidence x Mean Duration

Longer the duration of the disease, the greater the prevalence.

Few examples:

  • In acute diseases, because of rapid recovery/death prevalence will be relatively lower than incidence. This is because, in some diseases (eg. food poisoning), the disease is so short-lived, there are no "old cases".
  • In chronic diseases like TB, prevalence will be higher than incidence.
  • If a new treatment for a disease is effective, incidence does not change but prevalence decreases as the duration of disease decreases.
  • If the treatment only prevents death but doesn’t cure the disease, it may cause a paradoxical increase in prevalence.

Related Pearl: Case Control Study

In a case-control study, progression is from effect (disease) to cause (exposure) as the outcome or disease has already occurred. It is also called a retrospective study.

Design of case-control study:

 

  • Steps of case control study:
    • Selection of cases and controls
    • Matching
    • Measurement of exposure
    • Analysis in the form of exposure rates, risk ratio, and odds ratio
  • Advantages of case control study:
    • Easy to carry out, rapid and inexpensive
    • Requires few subjects, no risk to subjects
    • Used to investigate rare diseases
    • Different etiological factors can be studied and risk factors can be identified
    • No attrition problems, minimal ethical problems
  • Disadvantages of case control study:
    • Relies on memory or past records giving rise to bias
    • Selection of appropriate control groups is difficult
    • Incidence cannot be measured
    • Does not distinguish between causes and associated factors
    • Not suited for evaluation of therapy or prophylaxis
    • Representativeness of the cases and controls is often inadequate

questions.text: Damage to which of the following glycosaminoglycan will likely result in elevated albumin: creatinine ratio?
questions.solution:
Elevated albumin: creatinine ratio is seen in proteinuria (albuminuria). This happens when there is damage to the glomerulus, which normally repels proteins like albumin because of its negative charge. This property of the glomerular basement membrane is attributed to the glycosaminoglycan heparan sulfate, along with type IV collagen and laminin.

Glycosaminoglycans are negatively charged compounds of heteropolysaccharides, comprising small amounts of protein-forming groups called proteoglycans. There are various types available in the human body and they play significant roles:

Glycosaminoglycan Significance
Heparan sulfate Charge selectiveness in glomerular basement membrane
Heparin Anticoagulant
Hyaluronic acid Durability of cartilage, synovial fluid & vitreous humor of eye
Chondroitin sulfate Cartilage & extracellular matrix
Keratan sulfate Corneal transparency
Dermatan sulfate Wound healing in skin


Inborn errors of metabolism that result in defective enzymes that degrade glycosaminoglycans will lead to lysosomal storage disorders called mucopolysaccharidoses.

questions.text:
A woman undergoes a routine Pap smear which reveals atypical squamous cells of undetermined significance (ASCUS). Further evaluation with colposcopy and biopsy confirms high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesions (HSIL), for which she undergoes LEEP. Which of the following is the level of prevention of cervical cancer indicated by this scenario?

LEEP: Loop electrosurgical excision procedure
questions.solution:
In this scenario, the woman undergoes LEEP (Loop electrosurgical excision procedure) following abnormal Pap smear and biopsy results, which is a form of secondary prevention of cervical cancer.

Secondary prevention aims to detect and treat disease at an early stage before symptoms develop. The intervention can be early diagnosis and adequate treatment to limit the progression of disease. The detection of ASCUS on Pap smear and confirmation of HSIL through biopsy indicated the presence of precancerous changes. Subsequently, the woman undergoes LEEP to remove the abnormal tissue and prevent the progression to invasive cervical cancer.

Other options: 

Option A: Quarternary prevention is a new term that refers to actions that protect patients from medical interventions that are more likely to cause harm than good, such as unnecessarily invasive treatments or medications with questionable adverse effect profiles.

Option B: Tertiary prevention focuses on managing and reducing the impact of established disease and preventing complications. This would involve interventions after cervical cancer has already developed, such as treatment modalities to prevent recurrence or manage complications.

Option D: Primary prevention is defined as any intervention that removes the possibility that any disease will occur. Examples include HPV vaccination to prevent HPV infection, which can lead to cervical cancer.

questions.text: A multigravida who is a known case of diabetes delivers a newborn of weight 4.5 kg as shown in the image below. Which of the following complications can be seen in the neonate?
questions.solution:
Small left colon syndrome is one of the complications which can be seen in this neonate. 

The birth weight of 4.5 kg and the image provided indicates that the baby is macrosomia (large for gestational age).

In pregestational diabetes and gestational diabetes mellitus, maternal hyperglycemia causes a higher amount of blood glucose to pass through the placenta into the fetal circulation. It results in fetal hyperglycemia leading to fetal hyperinsulinism. As a result, extra glucose in the fetus is stored as body fat causing macrosomia. These newborns are at risk of developing various complications due to fetal hyperglycemia. They are:

  • Gastrointestinal: These infants may demonstrate abdominal distention caused by a transient delay in the development of the left side of the colon due to fluctuations in maternal and fetal glucose resulting in small left colon syndrome.
  • Metabolic: Hypoglycemia, hypocalcemia, hypomagnesemia
  • Neural: Neural tube defects like caudal regression syndrome, encephalocele, anencephaly 
  • Respiratory: Respiratory distress syndrome, transient tachypnea of newborn, persistent pulmonary hypertension
  • Cardiac: Cardiomegaly, cardiac malformations like a ventricular or atrial septal defect, transposition of the great vessels, truncus arteriosus, double-outlet right ventricle, tricuspid atresia, coarctation of the aorta
  • Hematological: Polycythemia, renal vein thrombosis
  • Others: Hyperbilirubinemia, insulin resistance, diabetes, sudden intrauterine death

Other options:

Option B- Hypermagnesemia is not seen in infants of diabetic mothers. Hypomagnesemia is seen due to the perinatal asphyxia.

Option C- Hyperglycemia is seen in the fetus and not in the neonate. Neonates present with hypoglycemia due to increased insulin.

Option D- Umbilical hernia is seen in congenital hypothyroidism.

questions.text: A patient of myasthenia gravis is most likely to develop
questions.solution:
A patient with myasthenia gravis is most likely to develop type II respiratory failure.

Type II respiratory failure occurs when alveolar hypoventilation results in the inability to eliminate carbon dioxide effectively.  

Mechanisms:

  • Impaired central nervous system (CNS) drive for breathing:
    • drug overdose
    • brainstem injury
    • sleep-disordered breathing
    • severe hypothyroidism  
  • Reduced strength with failure of neuromuscular function:
    • impaired neuromuscular transmission- e.g., myasthenia gravis, Guillain–Barré syndrome, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis
    • respiratory muscle weakness- e.g., myopathy, electrolyte derangements, fatigue
  • Increased load on the respiratory system:
    • resistive loads e.g., bronchospasm
    • loads due to reduced lung compliance e.g., alveolar edema, atelectasis, intrinsic positive end-expiratory pressure
    • loads due to reduced chest wall compliance e.g., pneumothorax, pleural effusion, abdominal distention
    • loads due to increased minute ventilation requirements e.g., pulmonary embolus with increased dead-space fraction, sepsis

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman at 37 weeks gestation presented with rupture of membranes 14 hours ago. Rectal culture for GBS performed at 36 weeks gestation is negative. She was treated for GBS bacteriuria at 10 weeks. Which of the following should be recommended for further management?

GBS: Group B Streptococcus

choices.text: Monitor and proceed with routine care
Repeat GBS culture from rectum and vagina
Perform cesarean delivery to prevent vertical transmission of GBS

questions.solution:
Intrapartum penicillin prophylaxis is recommended for mothers with a history of GBS bacteriuria during pregnancy, regardless of treatment for the same.

GBS (Streptococcus agalactiae) is a leading infectious cause of morbidity and mortality among newborns. Maternal GBS infection ranges from asymptomatic colonization to maternal bacteriuria, pyelonephritis, osteomyelitis, postpartum mastitis, and puerperal infections. GBS can overcome protective cervical mucus barriers during pregnancy and cause ascending antenatal infections. In infants, early-onset GBS infection (<7 days after birth) often presents as neonatal sepsis whereas late-onset disease usually manifests as meningitis between 1 week to 3 months after birth. Hence maternal intrapartum antibiotic administration is important for the prevention of early-onset GBS disease.

American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) recommends universal vaginal-rectal culture screening for GBS at 36 to 38 weeks gestation. It is followed by intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis for women identified to be carriers. The recommended regimen is Penicillin G IV, an initial dose of 5 MU (million units), followed by 2.5-3 MU IV every 4 hr continued until delivery.

Indications of intrapartum GBS prophylaxis:

  • GBS bacteriuria in the mother
  • Prior infant with invasive GBS disease
  • Positive GBS screening culture in the current pregnancy
  • Positive GBS status in a prior pregnancy
  • Unknown GBS status at labor onset with any of the following intrapartum risk factors:
    • Labor onset <37 weeks gestation (Preterm labor)
    • Membrane rupture for ≥18 hours
    • Intrapartum fever with temperature ≥100.4° F (38.0°C)
    • Intrapartum NAAT result positive for GBS

Intrapartum GBS prophylaxis is not indicated when:

  • Patients planned for cesarean delivery before the onset of labor or membrane rupture, regardless of GBS status or gestational age
  • Negative rectovaginal culture at ≥36 weeks gestation in current pregnancy
  • Unknown GBS status and intrapartum NAAT result negative and no intrapartum risk factors present

Other options: 

Option C: This patient only underwent a rectal culture, and could benefit from a recto-vaginal culture. However, given that she had GBS bacteriuria in the current pregnancy, she must receive intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis regardless.

Option D: Prevention of vertical transmission of GBS is not an indication for cesarean section.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old child was referred to the Ophthalmology department for evaluation of upper eyelid ptosis. Previous photographs suggest that it has been present from birth. The external eye measurements are given below. Which among the following surgeries is used to manage this case?
  Right eye Left eye
Palpebral fissure 4mm 4mm
Levator function Normal Poor
questions.solution:
Frontalis sling suspension is done for congenital ptosis with poor levator function.

Ptosis refers to the drooping of the upper eyelid such that it covers more than 2 mm of the superior cornea. It may be congenital or acquired.

Congenital Ptosis may be classified as:

  • Simple - isolated abnormality
  • Complicated -associated with ocular motor anomalies, blepharophimosis syndrome, and Marcus Gunn ptosis.

The presence of congenital ptosis should be confirmed by photographs taken during childhood. It is usually bilateral and is due to defective development of the muscle.

Measurements to assess ptosis:

  • Margin-reflex distance: The distance between the upper lid margin and the corneal reflection of a torch held by the examiner on which the patient fixates. It is normally 4–5 mm.
  • Palpebral fissure height: The distance between the upper and lower lid margins. It is measured in the pupillary plane. Normally it is 7–10 mm in males and 8–12 mm in females. Ptosis can be graded as
    • mild (up to 2 mm)
    • moderate (2-3 mm)
    • severe (4 mm or more)
  • Levator function (upper lid excursion): It is measured by placing the thumb firmly against the patient’s brow with the gaze fixed downwards. The patient is then asked to look up as much as possible and the amount of excursion is measured with a ruler. It is graded as:
    • Good:12–14 mm
    • Fair: 5–11 mm
    • Poor: 4 mm or less

When the levator function is poor (3 mm or less), the eyelid is suspended from the frontalis muscle using sutures, a fascia lata sling, or a silicone band. Infection of the suture bed is a complication of this surgery and the suture should be monitored.

Surgical treatment of various types of ptosis:

In patients with  good to moderate levator action:

Surgery Amount of ptosis that can be treated Indications
Fasanella Servat < 2 mm Horner Syndrome
Levator Resection – Anterior approach Any Larger resection in ptosis
Levator resection – Conjunctival approach Any Moderate resection in ptosis
Levator resection with aponeurotic reinsertion Any Acquired ptosis

In patients with poor levator action:

Surgery     Amount of ptosis that can be treated Indications
Frontalis suspension – Fascia lata > 2 mm Congenital ptosis, especially Marcus Gunn Ptosis

questions.text:
A new diagnostic test is being studied for detecting influenza infection among a sample of 400 people. 200 are confirmed to be positive by RT-PCR, of which 150 are detected to be positive by the new test. What is the sensitivity of the new test?

RT-PCR - Reverse transcriptase - Polymerase chain reaction
questions.solution:
The sensitivity of the new test is 75%.

The sensitivity of a test is calculated using the following formula, sensitivity = (True positive)/(True positive + False negative).

In this scenario, out of the total sample of 400 patients, 200 have been diagnosed with influenza as RT-PCR is confirmatory. The new test detects influenza in 150 out of 200 patients. Hence, the number of true positive cases is 150 and the number of false negative cases is 50.

Therefore, the sensitivity of the test would be (150)/(150+50) X 100 = 75%.

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.

questions.text: An elderly man presents with complaints of sudden jerky movements of his hands, which is present even when he is asleep. There is also a history of impaired memory. He underwent a corneal transplant 6 months ago. His electroencephalogram showed periodic sharp waves. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an elderly man with a history of corneal transplant presenting with myoclonic jerks, signs of dementia (impaired memory), periodic sharp waves on the electroencephalogram is suggestive of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease.

Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) is a prion disease that causes higher cortical function deficits. This infection can be acquired by corneal transplantation, contaminated electroencephalogram (EEG) electrode implantation, dura mater grafts, and contaminated human growth hormone (hGH) preparations.

Patients commonly present with myoclonus and dementia. EEG shows characteristic periodic bursts of diffuse, high-amplitude sharp waves (as shown below). 


MRI shows increased intensity in the basal ganglia and cortical ribboning (ribbon-like signal hyperintensity of cerebral cortical gyri). On light microscopy, the pathologic hallmarks of CJD are spongiform degeneration and astrocytic gliosis.

The given image shows the MRI findings in a CJD patient:


Other options:

Option A: Sturge Weber syndrome is a neurocutaneous syndrome characterized by angiomas of the leptomeninges and in the ophthalmic and maxillary nerve areas of distribution. Affected patients might have developmental delay, learning difficulties, and seizures. CT shows the presence of a tram-track appearance.

Option C: Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE) is a progressive demyelinating disease of the brain that occurs due to a previous infection with the measles virus. Most patients have a history of measles infection many years ago. SSPE presents with intellectual disability, poor school performance, and mood and personality changes. EEG shows high voltage slow sharp waves that occur every 3-8 seconds followed by a flat background.

Option D: Patients with tuberous sclerosis present with seizures, mental retardation, adenoma sebaceum (facial angiofibromas), shagreen patch, hypomelanotic macules, periungual fibromas, renal angiomyolipomas, and cardiac rhabdomyomas. Imaging may show the presence of subependymal nodules, cortical tubers, and subependymal giant cell astrocytomas.

questions.text: A microbiologist uses the staining technique to identify the causative organism in the slide as shown below. Which of the following properties is shown by the organism so that the microbiologist can identify the causative organism?

choices.text: Gram +ve have thick peptidoglycan layer retaining primary stain
Gram -ve has low lipid content and so uptakes secondary stain
Gram +ve undergoes decolourisation and does not retain primary stain
Gram -ve has more acidic protoplasm retaining primary stain

questions.solution:
The given microscopic image shows gram staining and Gram +ve organisms have thick peptidoglycan layer and this helps in retaining primary stain, crystal violet or methyl violet.

Gram staining is an essential procedure used in the identification of bacteria and is frequently used. It differentiates bacteria into two broad groups: Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria. 

The suggested theories in Gram staining are that a gram-positive organism has an acidic protoplasm (Option D) and also a thick peptidoglycan layer present in gram-positive bacteria that helps in retaining the primary stain. The lipid content in gram-negative bacteria is very high (Option B), which makes it permeable to secondary dye after decolorization with organic solvents like acetone.

Therefore, gram-positive bacteria retain the primary stain and appear violet. Gram-negative bacteria appear red because they get decolorized and take up the counterstain(Option C).

The image below shows the steps of Gram staining

The order of Gram staining is as follows:

  • Primary staining with para-rosaniline dye (crystal violet, methyl violet, or gentian violet)
  • Application of dilute iodine solution
  • Decolorisation with an organic solvent (ethanol, acetone, aniline)
  • Counterstaining with the dye of contrasting colour (carbol fuchsin, safranine, neutral red)

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in microbiology

A. Simple stains: Provides color contrast but gives same color to all bacteria and cells.

Type of stain Applications
Acidic stains

These include eosin, acid fuchsin, rose bengal, congo red, etc.

Used to stain pathological specimens
Basic stains.

Loeffler’s methylene blue stain is used in Quellung reaction. 

Polychrome methylene blue is used in McFadyean’s reaction.
Neutral stains

Wright and Giemsa stains are Romanowsky stains used to stain peripheral blood and bone marrow smears.  

Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and other protozoan blood parasites.  

 

B. Differential stains: Imparts different colors to different bacteria. (These contain more than one stain).

Type of stain Applications
Gram stain: To differentiate between gram positive (stain purple/violet) and gram negative bacteria (stain pink or red).
Acid-fast stain:  Used in Ziehl–Neelsen staining technique for identification of acid–fast microorganisms such as M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, and Nocardia.
Fluorochrome staining: Auramine-rhodamine is used in fluorochrome staining for screening for tuberculosis.

C. Special stains:

Type of stain Applications
Staining volutin-containing organisms Corynebacterium diphtheriae stained by Albert’s stain. Green colored bacilli showing "chinese-letter" pattern, containing bluish-black metachromatic granules of cells.
Flagella stain Salmonella typhimurium stained by modified Ryu stain to show peritrichous flagella
Endospore stain Used in Schaeffer and Fulton staining technique to stain the endospores, where the primary stain is malachite green, and the counterstain is safranin.
Capsule stain Used in negative staining (Cryptococcus neoformans), McFadyean’s reaction, Polychrome methylene blue (anthrax bacilli).
Silver impregnation Fontana’s silver impregnation method used for staining treponeme and leptospire.
Silver staining Used in Grocott’s – Gomori’s methenamine silver stain. GMS stain is used to identify Pneumocystis jirovecii, which classically appear as crushed ping-pong balls.   Warthin–starry silver stain for spirochetes.
Calcofluor white staining The cell walls of fungi will bind the stain calcofluor white. It is especially useful for the identification of mucor and the causative agents of zygomycosis.  It is also used in staining acanthamoeba
Chance's staining For cell wall demonstration

questions.text: A patient with left lower limb shortening was planned for a circular external fixation procedure. What is the principle behind this procedure ?
questions.solution:
The planned procedure for this patient is an Ilizarov external fixator and the principle behind the procedure is distraction osteogenesis.

Distraction osteogenesis (distraction histogenesis) is the mechanical induction of new bone that occurs between bony surfaces that are gradually pulled apart. This is described as the tension stress effect.

The most important application of the tension-stress principle is known as callus distraction (or callotaxis). A careful fracture of the bone is performed, followed by a short wait. The young callus formed is gradually distracted using a circular or unilateral external fixator. This is used in limb lengthening or filling of large segmental defects in the bone.

Distraction or compression is carried out at the rate of 1 mm per day. This is done in four sittings - 0.25 mm, four times a day. It is used in the following scenarios:

  • Non-union
  • Deformity correction
  • Osteomyelitis - as it offers the possibility of liberal excision of bone
  • Arthrodesis - crushing articular surfaces can stimulate union between opposing bones

questions.text:
A 38-year-old woman presents to you seeking contraceptive advice. Which of the following would be an absolute contraindication to prescribing COCs for her?

COCs - Combined oral contraceptives
questions.solution:
Hepatic adenoma is an absolute contraindication to COC use. 

Combined oral contraceptives are one of the most effective methods of reversible contraception. They contain a combination of estrogen (eg. ethinyl estradiol) and progestins (eg. levonorgestrel, desogestrel) that act by inhibiting ovulation. In addition to contraception, they are also used for the management of irregular menstrual cycles, dysmenorrhea, and abnormal uterine bleeding (due to fibroids or endometriosis).

Absolute contraindications to COC use (WHO Category - 4):

  • Thromboembolism - history of deep vein thrombosis, stroke
  • Uncontrolled diabetes with vascular complications (like coronary artery disease)
  • Uncontrolled hypertension
  • Valvular or ischemic heart diseases
  • Migraine headaches with focal neurological deficits
  • Active liver diseases - jaundice, hepatic adenoma or carcinoma
  • Pregnancy or breastfeeding (till 6 weeks postpartum)
  • Breast cancer

Relative contraindications to COC use include:

  • WHO category - 2 (advantages outweigh risks) - age >= 40 years, smokers < 35 years of age, mild hypertension, well-controlled diabetes, sickle cell disease, gallbladder disease, cervical cancer, or history of headaches
  • WHO category - 3 (risks may outweigh advantages) - past history of breast cancer, hyperlipidemia, unexplained vaginal bleeding, or heavy smokers

COCs are safe to use in patients with uterine fibroids, seizure disorders, endometriosis, ovarian or endometrial cancer, thyroid disorders, and varicose veins. These conditions are classified under WHO Category - 1.

Related Pearl: Hormonal contraceptives

Oral pills:

  • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COC)
    • Mala D - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate
    • Mala N - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate (Govt. supply, free of cost)
  • Progesterone only pills (POP) - suitable for lactating women
    • Norethisterone 350 μg
    • Norgestrel 75 μg
    • Levonorgestrel (LNG) 30 μg
  • Once a month or long-acting pills - highly disappointing results
    • Quinestrol (long-acting estrogen) + short-acting progesterone
  • Gossypol - male pill : Cottonseed derivative and causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia
  • Post-coital pills or interceptive
    • Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg, 2 doses, 12 hours apart
    • Mifepristone 10-600 mg
    • Ulipristal 30 mg, within 5 days of intercourse
    • Centchroman 60 mg, 2 tablets, within 24 hrs of intercourse
    • GnRH agonists  
    • CuT IUCD, inserted within 5 days

questions.text:
A biochemist was asked to demonstrate PCR-based microsatellite instability testing. Choose the correct statement regarding microsatellites in a chromosome.

PCR - Polymerase chain reaction

choices.text: They are found in eukaryotes only

questions.solution:
Microsatellites are simple sequence repeats (SSRs) in DNA and they are heritable traits in a particular family.

The DNA in an eukaryotic genome can be divided into two broad “sequence classes.”  They are nonrepetitive DNA and repetitive-sequence DNA. 

The microsatellites are one category of repeat sequences which consists of 2 to 6 base pairs that repeat up to 50 times. They are evolutionarily relevant because of their instability as a part of tandem repeats. They are found in both prokaryotes and Eukaryotes (option D). They consist of mostly dinucleotide repeats of AC on one strand and TG on the opposite strand (several other forms including CG, AT, and CA also occur ). Thus there is heterozygosity of the number of particular microsatellites in an individual.

They are widely distributed (option A) throughout the genome, especially in the euchromatin of eukaryotes, coding, and non-coding nuclear (option C), and organellar DNA.

Microsatellite repeat sequence change in length (show instability) when mismatch repair is not functioning. Defects in mismatch repair genes (as in Lynch syndrome/HNPCC) lead to microsatellite instability. Bethesda criteria is used to select patients for microsatellite instability testing.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about hepatitis B serology is false?

choices.text: High levels of IgM-specific anti-HBc are detected at the onset of clinical illness
At the start of resolution of the disease, HBeAg is replaced by anti-HBe, even before HBsAg disappears
Positive Anti-HBs is always indicative of HBV infection in the past
Small amounts of HBV DNA are usually detectable in the serum as long as HBsAg is present

questions.solution:
Positive Anti-HBs may also be seen in those who have undergone Hepatitis B vaccination, not just those with recent infection.

High titers of IgM-specific anti-HBc are detected at the onset of clinical illness. Its appearance in the serum is indicative of viral replication.

Antibody to HBsAg is first detected at a variable period after the disappearance of HBsAg. It is present in low concentrations. It may also be seen after vaccination

At the start of the resolution of the disease, HBeAg is replaced by anti-HBe, even before HBsAg disappears. But, interestingly, some patients can develop HBeAg-negative chronic hepatitis with pre-core HBV mutants that result in absent HBeAg production but with continued viral progression.

HBV chronic carriers have persistent HBsAg for more than 6 months, in the presence of HBeAg or anti-HBe. HBsAg may persist for years after the loss of HBeAg. In acute disease, high titers of IgM-specific anti-HBc are observed, while low titers of IgM anti-HBc are found in the sera of most chronic HBsAg carriers. Small amounts of HBV DNA are usually detectable in the serum as long as HBsAg is present.

World Hepatitis Day is commemorated each year on 28 July to enhance awareness of viral hepatitis, ‘I can’t wait to get tested’ is the new campaign theme for the year 2022. It will highlight the need to accelerate the fight against viral hepatitis and the importance of testing and treatment for the people who need it.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old woman presents with recurrent episodes of flushing, diarrhea, wheezing, and abdominal pain. These symptoms worsen after consuming certain foods, such as cheese and red wine. On examination, she has telangiectasias on her face and upper chest. Tests show elevated levels of urinary 5-HIAA. What is the most likely diagnosis?

5-HIAA: 5-hydroxy indole acetic acid
questions.solution:
This patient is suffering from carcinoid syndrome, which is characterized by recurrent episodes of flushing, diarrhea, wheezing, and abdominal pain, often triggered by foods such as cheese and wine. Elevated levels of urinary 5-HIAA, a serotonin metabolite, help confirm the diagnosis.

Flushing and telangiectasis on the face and neck are due to the release of the vasoactive substance serotonin. 

The carcinoid tumors are neuroendocrine tumors arising from enterochromaffin cells that can occur anywhere in the GIT. The most common site is the appendix followed by the ileum and rectum. A tumor with liver metastasis is likely to produce carcinoid syndrome. The image below shows the histopathologic appearance of carcinoid tumors.

The diagnosis is made by assessing 5-hydroxy indole acetic acid (5-HIAA) in a 24-hour urine sample. Ultrasonography, CT scan, and MRI may show the primary tumor and metastases. The best method for staging carcinoid tumors is by octreotide scan or somatostatin receptor scintigraphy (SRS).

Somatostatin and its analogs are used in the symptomatic treatment of carcinoid syndrome. Surgery should be undertaken as soon as the diagnosis is made, even in the presence of liver metastases.

Other options: 

Option B:  Serotonin syndrome is characterized by a triad of autonomic instability, altered mental status, and neuromuscular hyperactivity. It occurs due to the combined side effects with any drug that increases serum serotonin levels like MAOIs (monoamine oxidase inhibitors), SSRIs (selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors), SNRIs (serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors), TCAs (tricyclic antidepressants), tramadol, ondansetron, triptans, linezolid, MDMA (amphetamine), or dextromethorphan.

Option C: Cheese reaction occurs due to ingestion of products with large quantities of tyramine (cheese, red wine, aged meat, and fish) by patients who are on monoamine oxidase inhibitors. It causes the release of large amounts of noradrenaline causing a hypertensive crisis.

Option D: Zollinger-Ellison syndrome is caused by gastrin-secreting neuroendocrine tumors, which usually arise in the small intestine or pancreas. Patients present with duodenal ulcers or chronic diarrhea. Ulcers may occur in unusual locations such as the jejunum. 

Related Pearl: Carcinoid syndrome

A 60-year-old man was brought with a high-grade fever, productive cough, and confusion for the last 2 days. His vitals and chest radiograph are given below. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?

Temperature: 102°F

Pulse rate: 130 bpm

BP: 86/58 mmHg

Respiratory rate: 32/min

choices.text: Start oral antibiotics and send the patient home
Admit the patient in non-ICU setting and insert intercostal drainage tube
Admit the patient in non-ICU setting and start IV antibiotics
Admit the patient in ICU and start IV antibiotics

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with fever and productive cough and the chest radiograph showing lobar consolidation point to a diagnosis of pneumonia. Since this patient's CURB-65 score is at least 3 (1 point each for confusion, BP <90/60 mmHg, and respiratory rate >30/min), the most appropriate management would be ICU admission and starting IV antibiotics.

Once the diagnosis of pneumonia is made, the next step in management is to determine the site of care for the patient. To identify the patients that require in-patient and ICU management, CURB-65 score is used. It includes:

  • Confusion
  • Urea ≥17 mg/dL
  • Respiratory rate ≥30/min
  • Blood pressure: SBP ≤90mmHg or DBP ≤60 mmHg
  • Age ≥ 65 years

1 point is given for the presence of each of the above. The total score determines the site of care, as shown below:

0 Outpatient treatment
1 or 2 Inpatient treatment in non-ICU setting
≥3 Inpatient treatment in ICU setting

questions.text: Which is not a feature of Perthes disease?

choices.text: Adduction is limited on the affected side
Thomas test reveals fixed flexion deformity

questions.solution:
Abduction and internal rotation are affected in perthe's disease, not adduction. Thomas test reveals a fixed flexion deformity at 15 degrees.

Perthes disease, also known as Legg-Calve-Perthes disease, is the avascular necrosis of the proximal femoral epiphysis. It is most commonly seen in the age group of 4-8 years. The incidence is more in boys than girls. It is usually a unilateral disease but can occur bilaterally in 10% of the cases. Risk factors include low birth weight, passive smoking, family history, low socioeconomic status, and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder. Perthes disease is associated with thrombophilia, protein C and S deficiencies.

Disruption of blood flow to the femoral head leads to osteonecrosis and cessation of growth. The lateral epiphyseal artery, a branch of the medial circumflex femoral artery is involved. Over time, healing and fibrosis occur by new blood vessels infiltrating the dead bone and removing the necrotic bone which leads to a loss of bone mass and weakening of the femoral head. 

Clinical features include limping and hip pain, which aggravates with activity and is relieved by rest. Examination reveals pain on passive movement of the hip and abduction with internal rotation movement is limited. Children can also present with referred knee pain. Trendelengurg test is positive.

Note:

  • Most movements are full but abduction, especially in flexion, is nearly always limited and also usually internal rotation.
  • When the hip is flexed it may go into obligatory external rotation called as Caterall's sign.

questions.text: Which of the following methods is not useful for controlling epistaxis caused by over anticoagulation?
questions.solution:
Tranexamic acid, an antifibrinolytic agent, has not been shown to help in cases of over anticoagulated patients.   

Agents that work include Fresh frozen plasma, clotting factor extracts, and vitamin K. Vitamin K takes more than 6 hours to work, and it can delay anticoagulation for 7 days after warfarin is started.  

If the international normalized ratio is greater than 4, the warfarin should be stopped, and fresh frozen plasma should be given.  Clotting factor extracts should be given with extreme caution because of the risk of thromboembolic complications.

questions.text: A bullet that causes fire on hitting the target is:
questions.solution:
Incendiary bullets are those filled with explosive (e.g. white phosphorus) at the front end that causes fire on hitting the target.

Frangible bullets are those which are designed to disintegrate into tiny fragments upon target impact.

Dumdum bullets are also called expanding bullets. The tips of these bullets are designed to burst or expand into fragments on impact causing damage over a larger area.

Tandem bullet is a phenomenon seen when two bullets are fired in one shot with one lying right behind the other. It occurs in old, dirty or country firearms. Sometimes an ejected bullet may get lodged in the barrel and comes out when the next shot is fired – in tandem with that bullet.

questions.text: A 36-year-old female patient is in a starved state for the past 36 hours. The glycogen stores in her body have been completely exhausted, and lipolysis has begun to meet the energy requirements. Which of the following enzymes is required for the final step of beta-oxidation?
questions.solution:
Thiolase is the enzyme required for the final step of β-oxidation of fatty acids.

Thiolase (3-ketoacyl-CoA-thiolase) enzyme splits 3-ketoacyl-CoA  at the 2,3-position to form a molecule of acetyl CoA and new acyl-CoA with two carbons shorter than the original acyl-CoA molecule. The acetyl CoA so formed enters the citric acid cycle to eventually form ATP. The new acyl-CoA with two carbons shorter than the original re-enters the β-oxidation pathway.

Thiolase is also involved in ketogenesis, when two acetyl-CoA molecules produced via fatty acid breakdown, condense to form acetoacetyl-CoA by a reversal of the thiolase reaction.

Other options:

Option A -  Thiokinase catalyzes the only energy-requiring step in fatty acid oxidation. In the presence of ATP and coenzyme A, the enzyme acyl-CoA synthetase or thiokinase catalyzes the conversion of a fatty acid to acyl-CoA, the active form of fatty acid for oxidation using one high energy phosphate and forming AMP and PPi.

Option B - Thioesterase is the last enzyme in the fatty acid synthase complex. It catalyzes the final release of the newly formed fatty acid. It is not involved in fatty acid oxidation.

Option D - Thiophorase is also known as a succinyl-CoA-acetoacetate-CoA transferase. This enzyme is involved in keto-lysis in extrahepatic tissues. Acetoacetate is activated to acetoacetyl CoA by thiophorase enzyme. The CoA is transferred from succinyl-CoA to form acetoacetyl- CoA.

                                           Thiophorase
Acetoacetate+Succinyl CoA ------------------> Acetoacetyl CoA + Succinate.

questions.text: A senior resident who is in charge of the labor ward asks you to perform cardiotocography (CTG) in a G2P1 patient. The tracing that you obtain is as shown in the image below. This finding is associated with which of the following condition?
questions.solution:
The given CTG shows early decelerations. It is seen in fetal head compression.

In early decelerations, the onset, nadir, and recovery of deceleration coincide with the beginning, peak, and ending of uterine contraction respectively.

This finding in CTG is suggestive of fetal head compression causing vagal nerve activation.

 

The CTG given below shows late decelerations, Here the fetal heart rate begins to drop after the end of uterine contraction. It is mostly associated with uteroplacental insufficiency and fetal hypoxia.

Other causes of late decelerations include:

  • Placental pathologies like- postmaturity, hypertension, diabetes, placental abruption
  • Excessive uterine contractions
  • Excessive use of oxytocin
  • Epidural anesthesia

 

The CTG given below shows variable decelerations as seen in umbilical cord compression.

 

The CTG given below shows a sinusoidal pattern. It resembles a sine wave. It is often associated with fetal anemia, fetomaternal hemorrhage, and fetal acidosis.

Related Pearl: Deceleration patterns on cardiotocography (CTG)

Early deceleration: seen in head compression

 

Late deceleration: Seen in uteroplacental insufficiency, foetal hypoxia

 

Variable deceleration: Seen in umbilical cord compression

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman complains of difficulty in swallowing for the past few months. She also complains of bluish discoloration of fingers on exposure to cold for the past 5 years. On examination, she is found to have thickening of the skin of the hands and multiple dilated capillaries over the face. Which of the following is most specific for this disease?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of CREST syndrome / limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis, and anti-centromere antibodies are most specific for this disease.

CREST syndrome consists of :

  • Calcinosis cutis
  • Raynaud’s phenomenon
  • Esophageal dysmotility
  • Sclerodactyly
  • Telangiectasia

Systemic sclerosis (SSc) is a chronic autoimmune disease. Progressive fibrosis due to the deposition of extracellular matrix components in different tissue and organs is the prominent feature of SSc. 

The characteristic features of SSc are vascular damage, inflammation, and the presence of specific autoantibodies. 

SSc is classified into two based on the extent of skin involvement.

  • Limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis / CREST syndrome
  • Diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis

In limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (lcSSc), fibrosis in the skin of acral parts of the body, like the face and limbs (distal to elbow and knee) takes place. 

Skin fibrosis in limited type has a slow progression but microcirculation disturbances like Raynaud's phenomenon start long before the skin symptoms and are associated with the involvement of the lungs and esophagus. 

Since it has late and slow organ involvement, it is associated with a good prognosis with a 10-year survival of over 90%. 

Antinuclear antibodies (ANA) are present in 90 - 95% of cases with SSc.

Autoantibodies specific to Limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis include,

  • Anti- centromere
  • Anti-Th/To
  • Anti-U1-RNP
  • Anti-hUBF

Management is based on disease-modifying and organ-specific drugs. For peripheral vasculopathy and digital ulcers, calcium channel blockers like nifedipine, amlodipine is used and for refractory cases, phosphodiesterase 5 inhibitors are recommended.

Intravenous prostanoids are used for the healing process of digital ulcers and the improvement of microcirculation. The commonly used immunosuppressants for skin fibrosis are methotrexate, cyclophosphamide, and mycophenolate mofetil. When these drugs are ineffective or contraindicated, low-dose glucocorticosteroids or rituximab (anti-CD20) are used. 

Other options:

Options A and C- Anti-ds DNA antibodies and  Anti-Sm antibodies are specific for SLE.

Option D- Anti-SRP antibodies are characteristically seen in necrotizing myopathies.

questions.text: A man was brought to the hospital after he suffered a stab wound. CT-scan revealed an injury to the part of the artery that lies lateral to pectoralis minor muscle. Which of the following vessels is least likely to have its flow cut off completely?
questions.solution:
The third part of the axillary artery lies lateral to the pectoralis minor muscle. Injury in this part causes decreased blood supply in all branches of the third part of the axillary artery. The superior thoracic artery is a branch of the first part of the axillary artery, and is, therefore, the least likely to be affected.

The axillary artery is the continuation of the subclavian artery. It extends from the outer border of the 1st rib to the lower border of teres major, from where it continues as the brachial artery.

Pectoralis minor divides the artery into 3 parts (proximal to, posterior to, and lateral/distal to the muscle).

questions.text: Which of the following is not a suitable method of contraception after suction curettage of molar pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Intrauterine contraceptive device (Cu - T 380 A) is not a suitable method of contraception after suction curettage of molar pregnancy because of the potential risk of uterine perforation.

If surgical sterilization is not possible, then other methods such as hormonal contraceptive or barrier methods can be used.

Contraception has to be adopted by all patients who underwent suction curettage until HCG levels become undetectable and remain the same for a period of 6 months. This serves to avoid pregnancy and confusion regarding the source of HCG if there is a subsequent rise.

questions.text: The graph shows the percentage of filtered load remaining at various levels of nephrons for different substances. Select the correct options for inulin, alanine, and PAH respectively.
questions.solution:
The given graph shows the substances which are freely filtered (C - inulin), freely filtered and secreted additionally from tubules (D - PAH), and substances that are filtered very little and reabsorbed subsequently (A - alanine).

The given graph basically measures the amount (not concentration) of a particular substance in renal tubules after it undergoes ultrafiltration. 

Substances like inulin which are freely filtered (100%) are labelled with C. It further doesn't undergo any reabsorption or secretion. It is hence a straight line i.e., its concentration doesn't change throughout the length of the nephron.

Substances like PAH which are freely filtered and further secreted are labelled with D. This is because its concentration keeps increasing throughout the length of the nephron due to secretion into tubules.

Substances like amino acids or glucose are not freely filtered. And in normal conditions, they are almost completely reabsorbed. Hence they have a graph that is sloping down. And since they are completely reabsorbed within PCT itself, their concentration is not detected after proximal convoluted tubules.

questions.text: As an intern in the department of ophthalmology, you are asked regarding the indications of trabeculoplasty. In which of the following conditions would you advise this procedure?
questions.solution:
Trabeculoplasty is the procedure of choice for treatment of open-angle glaucoma. 

Indications include open angle glaucoma, pseudoexfoliative glaucoma, and pigmentory glaucoma.

In this procedure, laser spots have to be put on trabecular meshwork, that contracts and opens the channels at the rate of 50 spots on the anterior half of the trabecular meshwork over 180°. Argon Laser or Nd-Yag Laser can be used for trabeculoplasty

Complications include a transient acute rise of intraoccular pressure, which can be prevented by pretreatment with pilocarpine and/or acetazolamide. Inflammation which can be lessened by the use of topical steroids for 3-4 days.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is incorrectly paired?

choices.text: Bartter syndrome - Descending  loop of Henle

questions.solution:
Bartter syndrome occurs due to a defect in the Na+/K+/Cl- channel in the thick ascending loop of Henle.

A defect in the Na+/K+/Cl- channel impairs the transport functions of the thick ascending loop of Henle. It results in the following features:

  • Polyuria and polydipsia
  • Natriuresis with high aldosterone (due to RAAS activation)
  • Hypokalemia
  • Metabolic alkalosis
  • Hypomagnesemia 
  • Hypocalcemia and hypercalciuria

The clinical features of this condition are similar to the effects of loop diuretics. These drugs also act on the Na+/K+/Cl- channel. Hence, response to loop diuretics may be blunted. Treatment is with potassium-sparing diuretics like spironolactone and amiloride.

Option A: Defect in the proximal tubule results in Fanconi's syndrome. These patients have acidosis, with glycosuria, generalized aminoaciduria, and phosphaturia.

Option B: Defect in the Na+/Cl- cotransporter in distal convoluted tubule (DCT) results in Gitelman syndrome. These patients also present with hypokalemic alkalosis and hypomagnesemia. However, they also develop, hypocalciuria, and chondrocalcinosis.

Option D: Increased activation of the epithelial sodium channels (ENaC) channels results in Liddle syndrome. This causes increased reabsorption of Na+ exchanged for K+ causing hypokalemia. Increased Na absorption leads to hypertension.

Related Pearl: Renal Tubular Syndromes

questions.text: A G2P1 woman has presented to the hospital in active labor. You conduct the delivery and now proceed to the active management of the third stage of labor (AMTSL). Which of the following is  recommended in active management of the third stage of labor according to WHO:

choices.text: Early cord clamping to prevent blood loss
Sustained uterine massage to prevent atony

questions.solution:
Postpartum abdominal uterine tone assessment is recommended according to the WHO guidelines for active management of the third stage of labor (AMTSL). 

AMTSL recommended by WHO :

  • Immediate administration of prophylactic uterotonic (Oxytocin). Oxytocin 10 IU is given IM or IV.
  • Controlled cord traction during placental delivery (in cesarean section and in vaginal birth where skilled birth attendants are present)
  • Delayed cord clamping
  • Postpartum abdominal uterine tonus assessment for early identification of uterine atony is recommended for all women. Continuous monitoring of uterine tone is done every 15 minutes for 2 hours. If uterine atony is detected, a fundal massage is performed.

Uterine massage is not recommended routinely.

The goal of this is to prevent postpartum hemorrhage (PPH). Hence, uterotonics are the most important factor to decrease PPH. Delayed cord clamping is a less important component in this direction and similarly, cord traction is not as critical. Uterine massage does not form the main component of AMTSL.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of secondary active transport?

choices.text: Movement of oxygen across cell membranes
Proton pumps in the gastric glands of the stomach

questions.solution:
Sodium-Iodide (Na-I) symporter in the thyrocytes is an example of secondary active transport.

Secondary active transport is a type of active transport where a primary active transport mechanism creates a difference in ionic concentrations across the cell membrane. This difference in concentration acts as a driving force for the movement of other ions across the membrane. 

An example of this mechanism is the Na-I symporter in the thyroid gland which is responsible for iodine uptake into the follicular cells of the thyroid. It is mainly present in the basolateral membranes of the thyrocytes. It transports two Na+ ions and one I- ion into the cell against the concentration gradient. The energy for this transport is derived from the Na+-K+ ATPase pump.

Na+-K+ ATPase pumps sodium outside the cell and causes low intracellular sodium concentration. This causes sodium to enter the cell by facilitated diffusion. Along with sodium, iodide ions also enter the cell via the  Na-I symporter. Since the energy to transport sodium and iodide ions in Na-I symporter is derived from Na+-K+ ATPase pump, this is called secondary active transport.

Other options:

Option A. GLUT transporters in the enterocytes are examples of facilitated diffusion. The molecules are transported via carrier-mediated proteins along the concentration gradient. This transport does not require energy.

Option B. Movement of oxygen across cell membranes in our body is an example of simple diffusion. In simple diffusion, the molecules pass directly through the cell membrane along the concentration gradient. It does not require energy and is not carrier-mediated. Examples include the movement of water, carbon dioxide, and nitrogen across the cell membrane. 

Option D. Proton pumps in the gastric glands of the stomach are examples of primary active transport. Primary active transport obtains energy from the hydrolysis of ATP to transport molecules against an electrochemical gradient.

questions.text: Pseudopapillitis is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Pseudopapillitis is seen in hypermetropia.

In hypermetropia, fundus examination shows an optic disc that is small, has ill-defined margins, appears highly vascular, and simulates papillitis. However, as the optic disc is not swollen, as seen in papillitis, it is also called pseudopapillitis. A shiny retina is seen due to the greater brilliance of light reflections known as shot silk appearance.

A fundus image showing the same is given below.

In hypermetropia or long-sightedness, incident parallel rays of light come to a focus behind the light-sensitive retina, with the accommodation at rest. It may be axial, curvatural, index, positional and due to the absence of a crystalline lens.

Patients can be asymptomatic when the refractive error is small and corrected by the use of accommodation. Sustained accommodative efforts can give rise to symptoms such as tiredness of the eyes, headache, watering and mild photophobia. It may also lead to esotropic (convergent) squint in children. When the hypermetropia is high enough to not be corrected by accommodative efforts, patients experience defective vision.

On examination, the size of the eyeball may appear small and the cornea is slightly smaller. The anterior chamber is comparatively shallow. Other features on fundus examination include a shot silk appearance, where the entire retina may shine due to reflected light. It is usually treated by using convex lenses, which help focus the light rays on the retina.

Other options:

Option A: Myopia or short-sightedness is a condition where parallel rays of light come to a focus in front of the retina. Fundus examination shows an optic disc that is large, pale and has a crescent at the temporal edge, degenerative changes in retina, choroid, vitreous and presence of posterior staphyloma.

Option C: Aphakia refers to the absence of a crystalline lens. Fundus examination only shows a hypermetropic, small disc.

Option D: Presbyopia is a condition of physiological insufficiency of accommodation, leading to a progressive fall in near vision.

Related Pearl: Grading of Hypermetropia

American Optometric Association (AOA) has defined three grades of hypermetropia:

  • Low hypermetropia: error of + 2D or less
  • Moderate hypermetropia: error from +2.25D to + 5D 
  • High hypermetropia: error is > + 5D
